This is the heart of the left bank and a wonderful way to spend an afternoon just walking and exploring this part of the city.You'll find all the cafes and restaurants made famous by the many writers and artists who lived here over the years but you'll also find some really great little stores and quirky not so famous places to grab a drink or bite to eat.Take the time to just wander in whatever direction takes your interest and enjoy.

I thinks it's more interesting at night. this street is highly recommended for a visit in Paris by a blogger so we wanted to know if it's really interesting. We went there day time but we just ended up with "people watching" quite cool to see people just pass by while having coffee.. I think it's more interesting at night..
Interesting and quirky area. Ah Paris! Saint Germain des Pres, lovely quaint streets, interesting shops and just a lovely place to wander the streets without any real purpose but just to be there

Reminds me of The Village in NYC...neighborhood of boutiques and bistros, eclectic and very French.... and houses the best shopping experience under 1 roof called Le Bon Marche...If you are short on time, you are well served if you stop in for gifts or a treat for yourself...Great customer service! Very Neiman Marcus, only French!!!

The Heart of the Left Bank. So If you've not been to Paris or just to the major sights, you may wonder what is and where is the left bank. Well, the left bank is actually the entire south side of the Seine River. If you stand with your back to the flow of the river the area would be on your left hand while places like the Louvre, Place de La Concorde, Montmartre and the C hamps Elesee are on your right. The Left has a bohemian reputation and feel to it. It is the home to the Sorbonne, Paris' University so it has a very young feel to it. Boulevard St. Germain and Boul.St. Michel intersect just a few blocks away. It has very old colorful neighborhoods with narrow winding allies and streets off both sides of Boul. St Michel between the river and Boulevard St. Germain. It is the part of Part of Paris that I can spend hours walking through and sitting with a cup of coffee and people watch. Cafe Les Deux Magots is a historic cafe that sits right across from the beatuiful and historic Church of St. Germain des Pres. There are plenty of other great cafe's and pubs also to enjoy the crowds and yes there is great shopping here, though not so cheep as it once was.
great area. this was close to our hotel- we had some great meals and did some good shopping here. Lots of fun just walking varound

Great place to soak up Paris!. This is a great place to soak up the atmosphere of Paris. The hustle and bustle of Paris while dining on some very different delights i had never even heard of. All of which were superb.

live like a local. It is so lovely to walk and walk though Saint Germain, we felt as though we were experience a more authentic Paris.This is an area where you will find so many prints to buy, just do it, we regret not buying any.Saturday we stumbled upon a mini-market which gave a true insight into the Parisian way of life.We felt as though we were living like a local.

Enjoyable. We had a lovely day in the area. We visited the cathedral and abby, (a must) and had wondrful creme brulee and espresso at a quaint restaurant nearby. The area is bustling and has lovely shops while still being low key and relaxed.

What a wonderful neighborhood!. Perfect neighborhood through which to wander aimlessly. Always easy to find a bistro to eat or have a glass of wine. Cute shops - nice quintessentially Parisian streets. Spend a couple of hours wandering with no particular destination.
Amazing. I don't know what it is but everything in this city is amazing. I recommended swinging by and checking it out
Esential part. Paris is very famouse with street cafes, but mist know 2 of them is there , must visitAlso many nice shops for shoping , sometimes strett jazz concerts Always beutifull

Magnifique. An amazing and central area of Paris. There, you can go everywhere. However, Distances are still quite far from most touristic places. It is a must go, and you can even find reasonable food prices.

Great for wandering, shopping and dining. There is a lot packed into this easily walkable section of Paris. Yes, parts of it are very "touristy" but there are many wonderful restaurants, cafes, small hotels and shops.Be discerning and look at reviews, wear comfy shoes, bring an umbrella, and enjoy.

Arty and fashionable district. I love this district of Paris on the left bank. It is known for the art shops and antiques and so many good restaurants. It is atmospheric and chic and very well located to walk along the embankment to get to the main tourist sites of Paris.

Best part of Paris!. I love staying in a particular "boutique" hotel in the Latin Quarter. One block from the Metro and Saint Germain des Pres, 2 blocks from Notre Dame Cathedral and Saint Michel. This is the oldest part of the city (I think). You really have to hunt for the small medieval area of tiny streets and ancient architecture, but it's worth the search. You're also really close to the University so there's a lively student community feeling. It's a bit of a walk to the Luxembourg Gardens, but not if you walk fast. Get off the beaten path of the main streets and you'll find all kinds of great little cafes, bookstores and restaurants - without the overpriced Saint Germain or Saint Michel boulevards themselves. There's an interesting outdoor "museum" of Roman ruins, inside of which is a Museum of medieval Jewish life and artifacts. I love this area, there's an ambience of "closeness" (as opposed to the wide open Champs Elysee, for example).

Had a wonderful time staying in Ste Germain--great restaurants, beautiful old apartment buildings, some touristy places. You can walk forever here--we took a Context Tour (highly recommended) of the area and met at the first church in Paris which is in this quarter. Couple of big old brasseries that are tourist traps (Les Deux Magots?) but in Paris, everything looks and feels delicious.

L'esprit Saint Germain / Paris. A favorite venue for painters and sculptors whose works aredisplayed in the nice Gallery St. Germain. I enjoy strolling and shopping in the Rue des Rennes and having a drink on a niceterrace, parisian atmoshere; Students, tourists enjoy the American book-chop and other librarys.

tres pricy. Very nice place to eat ot have a coffee and watch people; however, it is very touristy and there are chaper places to do the same. There are many othe bistros in the area to frequent and do the same.
Have a crepe. Tourist prices but we've had a crepe at this corner on each of our visits. It's a sentimental favorite if not the fanciest food but a convenient stop that we'll make each trip.
Crowded and Pricey. It's always crowded there. Sidewalks are narrow with many people wandering, so you can't move fast. Every restaurant there is pricey.

Perhaps my favorite area in Paris!. Saint Germain des Pres is a wonderful area with a great selection of restaurants and cafes. The streets are lined with so many great options and it is a fun area to explore. I'll likely stay in this area again on my next trip to Paris.

Quaint but expensive. This area was a fun splurge. Hotels were lovely and there are so many good cafes, crepe rise and excellent restaurants. The shopping in this area is wonderful. Lots of small shops that are open fairly late so it's easy to shop after a day of sightseeing.

Central location. The area is a good hub for a short stay. There is easy access on foot or by metro to all the main sights. It is expensive though, with high prices for drinks in cafes, mitigated by happy hour discounts in the evening. Our hotel de Buci was excellent. Interesting shops in streets between the boulevard and the river. Plenty of restaurants though better value available elsewhere.

Nice part of the city.. It's a great part of the city.Very nice places to eat in the narrow streets. Nice shops. Has a different feel as compared to the other districts. I did not stay here, but in the next visit, this will be my preferred district.

St Germaine quarter. We love this area! Lots of shops and cafes! Lots of furniture and fashion shops that are boutique-ish. Not stuffy! Our hotel is in a safe place so walking to resturants has been easy. Easy to get on the metro or buses from this area. So fun!
Shopping!!!!!!. Saint Germain is for shopping and for architecture! Also nice small street side cafes and the famous Cafe Florie!

The Left Bank- Wow!. Hemingway,Gertrude Stein, Shakespeare and Company Bookstore, restaurants, sidewalk cafes, famous churches, the Sorbonne- wow,wow and wow again!. You can't go anyplace in the world ,probably ,and see so much charm, history and culture all so close together. We have stayed in the 5th Arrondissement in previous visits to Paris and we love this area.

Great buzz and fun to people watch. Love this area but gets very busy so beware. Nice crowds generally. Watch out for the increasing amounts of dog poo on the pavement - this is the only downside but it is Paris and not as bad as areas around Invalides/ Tour Eiffel areas.

Great neighborhood. A neighborhood I always visit when I'm in Paris. Great little shops for clothing and leather goods. Some typical cafes nothing too special until you turn the corner and travel down the Blvd. Saint Germain.

Must see for sure. Restaurants, Coffee bars, shopping, The Church (Saint Germain des Pres), Metro Stations and buses stops, intetesting, fashion and famous stores. Music attarctions and performances everywhere.

Nice neighbourhood to stay in. We stayed near Saint Germain des Pres station, and it's just 10min walk to Rue du Buci which is where the cafes are. Croissants were GREAT! Must try. Breakfast sets typically consist of orange juice, a coffee, 2 or 3 breads with jam which ranged about 8 to 10 euros. Nice to do people watching at Buci. We went on a Sunday so not many shops were opened. Supposedly to be Parisian resting day. Laduree macaroons and Lush soap is in the neighbourhood too if you are a fan of theirs.

Great area to stay in and great window shopping. When we have visited Paris, we have always stayed in St Germain Des Pres. It is so convenient to most everything we like to do when in Paris. The shopping is great, and it si fun to visit the galleries. Highly recommend

The Perfect Paris Neighborhood. After multiple trips to Paris, the Saint-Germain Quartier remains my favorite area of the city in which to spend time, eat, stroll, and just be. Specifically, the intersection of Boulevard Saint-Germain and Rue de Rennes (home to the Saint-Germain-des-Prés church, Les Deux Magots, Brasserie Lipp, many high-end retailers, and a lovely Christmas market in the season) is one of my favorite places in the world.Everything one can hope to see in Paris is easily reachable from Saint-Germain by Metro or a lovely stroll, and it is possible to have all your Paris meals in this area and eat very well doing so.One last thing, though: please help keep this amazing neighborhood clean, quiet yet vibrant, and free from tour buses.

Great Location. We stayed in a hotel on the Saint Germain Boulevard. What a great location, only a couple of blocks to the river Seine. Plenty of places to eat in the alleys/road that lead to the river.

Paris' Most Vibrant Neighborhood. This district (Arrondissement 6) is on the Left Bank south of the river and is arguably the city's most vibrant neighborhood, albeit touristy. It's full of cafes, restaurants, boutiques, and narrow alleys to explore. While many prefer Le Marais (Arrondissement 3) or Montmartre (Arrondissement 18), Saint Germain is more lively and energetic with more activities, while the others have a more local feel. Regardless of what you like, all the aforementioned neighborhoods should be visited to see the true character of Paris.
Food, food and more food. We ate so much in this area and bought so much fruits, cheese, wine, baguettes and pastries. Spend half a day here enjoying the foods and strolling the streets.

gourmet cafes, bistrot, great boulangerie and pattiserie with greens. I would love to come back and stay in this area on my next time in Paris. The park, nice shops, good restaurants, organic marche...they have everything. Last time we stayed near Lourve and Opera but it was pretty commercial and busy.

Put it on the to-do list. Lively buzzing, safe atmosphere. Lots to see. Some touristy restaurants and plenty of tat but we also found some much better places as well. Recommend the walking tour with Discoverwalks

The center of intellectual and political life in Paris. This district is famous for its bookshops, publishers and cafés where true born Parisians love to meet to discuss about literature, politics , and catch a glimpse of famous peopleThe 3 famous cafés : The Flore, Les 2 Magots and the Brasserie Lipp are all a must to understand the spirit of true Paris

The hippest neighborhood in Paris. Been to Paris over 30 times.... My favorite neighborhood to visit and hang out! The cafe's, winding streets, cobblestone, and of course the church showcase Paris and France for that matter at it's finest.

One of my favorite areas in Paris. Everyone should definitely take an afternoon or a day to hang out in St Germain. It's a lively area. Definitely go to Le Bon Marche - if you're there in January or July they have huge sales (called soldes) everywhere in Paris but got great stuff at Le Bon Marche for more than 50% off. Stroll throughout the area and stop at Cafe del Flore for a coffee and eclair.

touristy area, not great food, lots of little trinkets for cheap. I thought this area was nice, but the food was meh. There are a TON of restaurants and little touristy shops here. If you want a scarf or an eiffel tower keychain, the stores here were by far the cheapest. Nice walking around tho

Lovely place. Stayed in this quarter while in Paris for over a week and did not regret it one bit. You will not run out of places to eat, sit, relax, and shop. I will most likely stay in this quarter again.

Adorable!. This area is adorable. It has tons of nice of shops and restaurants. People are polite and there are little treasures to be found in the antique shops. This is a great walking area for getting to know a very relaxed area of Paris.
You must walk here. Very nice district with fancy restaurants and all kind shops. Odeon theater located here. You must walk here during your Paris trip

Great place to lose yourself. Close to St. Germain boulevard this area is place to walking a lot to see a lot of great architecture, to feel an old Paris atmosphere.I would strongly recommend to visit this place, to "breath Paris"...
great place to stay and eat. We walked all the way to the Sorbonne and I wished we had stayed here! Food was good and less expensive than in other sides, and it was beautiful!

Never dull!. So much to see and do just walking, every turn something new to enjoy. Rue du BAC is our favorite, great shops, cheese, butcher shops along with wine stores, shops, a must when visiting! Christmas was especially beautiful, the magical lights all around made it all so special!

It has Character. Romantisied area of Paris. Beautiful buildings, great restaurants, lovely shops - what more do you need? This was the home of existentialism and of course Jazz. Just try and avoid the pseudo restaurants , and look a little bit further for the true Parisian restaurants.

Tourists , Stay in this area. Quite a vibey safe clean area.
Tourists , Stay in this area - I would should i visit Paris again. Very Central to quite a few attractions. Shops & Cafe Galore. Felt pretty Safe as well ... as much as there are tourists so too are there locals in this area.

Worth visiting but probably not staying here. We stayed in this area for a week with our little 6 year old boy. It is undoubtedly an interesting area with much to see, but quite touristy and very busy/rushed compared with, say, the Marais area on the right bank.
awesome part of Paris. loved St Germain, it has so much character great restaurants and shopping! its a short walk from the city too!

Romanticized Paris--but there is nothing wrong with that.. Boulevards, boulangeries, bookstores and cafes. It's the romanticized paris of books and movies. Great for a morning stroll, an afternoon coffee and a lazy day with a book. What more can I say and what more would you want?
Great area. A pleasure to walk around. Love to watch People and the splendid shops. You need a big wallet to shop, so windowshopping is a must
60th birthday treat. This building is also lovely. We actually sat outside and had a glass of wine, while watching the hustle and bustle.

A Central place to stay in Paris. I recently stayed six nights in a hotel located in this area of Paris which is located close to,restaurants, transport and good shopping. A number of must see attractions are located nearby eg Notre Dame, Luxembourg Gardens, La Sainte- Chapelle, together with many museums and galleries. all within walking distance of accommodation to suit all budgets. I have stayed in this area twice and it appears to be a relatively safe area.

stayed at st Germain Odeon. GREAT location, safe and close to everything, walk to the Lourve, the metro and RER, the latin quarter and goof cafes, bakeries and chocolate shops. loved this are will stay here again next visit.

Will stay here next trip!. We stayed in the 1st, which I enjoyed but next time I want to be in this area. Love the buildings, the cafes, the shops, everything! Great base for a trip to Paris and within walking distance to all the tourist sites!

The best part of Paris. This is my favourite part of Paris. It's central, hips, safe, interesting, beautiful, lots of shopping, plenty of restaurants etc etc. There is much to do and see here. I would recommend tourists find accommodation in this quarter as it is central to all of Paris' attractions. For the tourist who is concerned about safety, this quarter meets this concern.

Great walk and shopping. Great walk, lots of bistros and restaurants, good shopping but not fancy at all. Around Odeon, check out the many great options, including movie theatres, and restaurants such as Le Comptoir, or Les Editors...
Famous cafes and steak frites.. You will see lots of locals here enjoying their day. Famous cafes and steak frites. Nice old church and Luxembourg park. Great home base for a vacation in Paris.

Out of this time. Saint Germain des Pres will 100% make you feel like you have slipped trough time. Especially if you have read any book by Honore de Balzac. And if you didn't: read it before visiting Saint Germain.

Left Bank Shopping. A fabulous area and although I like the Champs Elysees I adore Rue St Germain. It is just so classy, not touristy and full of all sorts of designer and boutique shops. Sonia Rykiel, Ralph Lauren, Boss, Burberry, Lanvin to name just a few. Beautiful cafes and restaurants and of course, some magical chocolate shops too!
great restaurants. Lovely cafes and restaurants, perfect place to sit, eat, drink wine or coffee and watch the world go by.

The best known Boulevard on the Left Bank. The Boulevard St-Gerrmain begins at the Pont de Sully near the eastern end of Ile St-Louis and runs for more than two miles throughout the left bank before ending at another bridge across the Seine, Pont de la Concord. The street is rich with cafes, galleries, bookstores and designer boutiques and is a wonderfully attractive thoroughfare on which to wander.
beautiful. this is a really good spot to stop and breathe in Paris. You are in the heart of tourism but it is still fun to people watch and see the sites.
Great neighborhood to stroll . This area is beautiful with many small shops coffee places and restaurants. Our favorite coffee place is les deux maggots.
Great shopping area. A very pleasant area to shop in with lots of arcades and big department stores we particularly like the security in all large stores
Awesome!. The is one of the best neighborhoods in Paris for Cafes and nice shops. there are quite a few art shops that are cool to check out.
My second favorite neighborhood. Just wander the streets and alleys. Look at the architecture. Stop I the cafes. Window shop. I always make time for this area when I am in Paris!

Our favorite!. Love this area...historically significant for its early 20th century writers and artists. Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Gertrude Stein and others favored the cafes here, and especially Shakespeare and Company bookstore. Art is everywhere and boutiques are fun to shop...or window shop. This location is close to museums, Notre Dame, Eiffel Tower, Louvre, and more, most within walking distance.
We loved this area.. A bit bohemian and but a very friendly and interesting neighbourhood with lots to offer. Loads of interesting shops and restaurants.

Fantastic neighborhood in beautiful Paris . This is a must see while in Paris, it's a beautiful area with lots of restaurants, cafes shops and historic churches and buildings. Watch the locals stroll around the streets at their leisure in a quieter part of the city. The choice of restaurants and cafes is very good and most places have outdoor seating.
Adorable neighborhood. This was my 4th trip to Paris and I really enjoyed staying in the 6th. Can be very touristy in spots but convenient if you want to walk to many of the big destinations.
Great architecture . Musee Cluny, St Sulpice and Luxembourg gardens in walking distance. Terrific restaurants and cafes frequented by locals and tourists. Safe district.

Stayed here for a lovely week. This area is rife with history but that seems to have very little impact on its current incarnation. There is little evidence of Sartre and the other thinkers and artists that called this area home anymore. Instead, beautiful shops and restaurant command the majority of the area. It was a very busy, bustling area even in December with the streets picking up steam as the evening progressed. Traffic is unforgiving so beware when crossing the street. It really is every man for themselves!Hotels and restaurants are pricey in this area but its proximity to everything "Paris" makes it worth the extra money.

If you like it by daytime, come back for dinner. Very authentic "old Paris" spot, with monuments galore, next tothe Sorbonne, Politechniques, etc. At night, the little streets arestuffed with restaurants for all tastes and budgets, and a greatplace to sit outside in a cafe.... and do what we do: watch people
Favorite place in Paris . Very old church on the square which is incredibly beautiful. The 2 cafes are world famous Le Flore and Les deux Magots. Shops and sightseeing everywhere.
Interesting for shopping and walking around. Great location, easily accessible, good food options, great for shopping, very charming, great for walking or biking, a favourite area of mine in paris!
Loved this Quarter. Saint Germaine des Pres has it all. Great food, shopping and proximity to entertainment venues. We dined in the Quarter several times.

Stay here!!!. Brilliant location. Walk to all the major attractions and some great shops, restaurants, markets all in easy walking distance. Very quiet at night. Would definitely use this area again as my base in Paris.

A charming, intimately paced section of Paris. We started our 5th trip to Paris in a different Arrondissement -- but could not wait to get back here. It is just where we feel completely at home. I don't think you could possibly get enough of the unique shops, the cafes - with a new surprise around every corner. I biked extensively around this area using the Velib bikes - felt like home!!

What I imagined. When thinking Paris, think street cafes/restaurants, quaint side streets etc. All present here. My favourite area is around Rue de Buci. Very lively and full of restaurants and shops/galleries/cafes.

Fun part of Paris and very artsy. This area in the Left bank is famous for its cafes, art galleries and shops/boutiques of all kinds. It has tons of cafes where you can sit have a cope of coffee or a beer and see world go by. it is indeed fun to just walk around and see what you can find.
Lovely area to mooch around. There are plenty of one-off shops, art galleries and authentic cafes in this area. Definitely worth a few hours of your time in Paris.

So many options for food and shopping. I was lucky enough to stay in the Saint Germain Quarter, and I don't know if I'd want to stay anywhere else. There are literally hundreds of restaurants to pick from and places to shop. I went to multiple restaurants here and each one of them was delicious in their own way- so pick away and don't be afraid of which one you pick because they're all delicious.

Don;t walk to this are. Run. So nice, clean, fun and great tood.. Went to this area twice during our trip. Find a great restaurant here and go. We did a Paris by Mouth tour here. I recommend it highly. Lots of great shopping and people watching.

Buzzing with activity and plenty to see and do. Typically Parisien quarter where just walking around the little alley ways and dropping into interesting shops is a relaxing thing to do. Not forgetting the superb eateries and restaurants to keep you fortified.

awesome neighborhood for SHOPPING. In order to enjoy this neighborhood, you should be prepared to either eat pastries, spend money on shopping, or both. There are many wonderful pastry shops in this area -- most of the best in Paris are here. There are many wonderful places to shop of all varities. For the most part this neighborhood doesn't feel crowded and touristy in the same way that the Left Bank areas closer to St. Michel are. Here in St. Germain there is a lot more space to walk around and everything also costs more. It's maybe like walking around Upper East side in New York? The apartments/buildings around here are for the most part very pretty and nice. Definitely one of the more upscale Paris neighborhoods.

A must do. You have to walk around Saint Germain des Pres. Its full of restaurants shops, its so Paris. You can't say you've been to Paris without walking around Saint Germain des Pres district! A lot of hotels are also located there.
Christmas stalls. We visited the area to browse the Christmas stalls and enjoyed the visit. There are not too many stalls so you are not overwhelmed. The stalls were selling good quality merchandise.

If you haven’t been here you haven’t been to Paris!. Each one of us has "its own Paris”, mine is Sant Germain. I would (and normally do) keep walking on the same streets for hours, over the years, and still every time I am in this region is like the first time. Just mesmerized by the beauty of it.

This was Great Walking Tour. So we went on a guided walking tour around St Germain. It was great. The guide was excellent and we had a fun group. We stopped at all these little food places and had samples - some of the cheeses were amazing. Takes about 4-5 hours, so wear your best walking shoes.

A Wonderful Neighborhood!. Saint Germain des Pres (6th Arrondissement) is a wonderful neighborhood with lots to explore from Jardin du Luxembourg, other parks and monuments, shops and restaurants to name a few. As it is located next to the Latin Quarter (5th Arrondissement) which is my Paris neighborhood, I always end up visiting the 6th. There are many hidden gem from shops to restaurants, etc.. that can be discovered by just picking a street and walking down it. If you want touristy just head across Boulevard Saint Michel by the Fountain, there you will find many places like in the 5th that cater toward tourists (Some are excellent). Take sometime and just wander...you won't regret it!

Best French Onion Soup :-). The hotel is gorgeous, but I only walked around and didn't stay there. I had lunch at their restaurant and they truly have the best french onion soup ever. Once you have it there, you never eat it anywhere else.

Revitalized in last years, shops, bars, cafes, restaurants, hotels, all. My favorite to stay and walk, eat, shop, meet friends or business contacts, more fun than the more serious central areas, many independents, a break from big chains, relaxed confort.

Hustle and Bustle of a thriving area. We visited the area on a Saturday just before CHristmas. The area was saturated with tourists and shoppers. Ther are a lot of high end shops in the area including Hermes (who's basement was a swimming pool) before becoming a retail outlet). There is also Le Bon Marche and Au Bon Marche which are quite upscale. Au features lots of fine wine, fine food and international food. There are lots of antique dealers here including second hand clothes stores and stores that deal in high end second hand jewelry and watches.. There is no shortage of bakeries, chocolatiers as well. One of the most unique stores in the area is called Deyrolle. On the first floor is a very nice very expensive gardening shop. The second floor however is a very unique and well odd taxidermy shop full of stuffed exotic animals. From Lions to tigers to water buffalo to a moose head, you'll find it all here. Made me a little uncomfortable but it is unique. BTW, the area spreads across the 6eme and 7eme arrondissement.

Full of Life. We were staying at a hotel near by and there was do much to do in this one neighborhood we couldn't do it all. There are cafes open late throughout the week. Boutiques with original pieces. Two movie theaters right across from each other. We'll have to stay longer next time.Great people watching with great food!

Fun place and LOTS to do. I love this area of Paris It really is beautiful and there is so much to do You can shop, eat, drink and wonder the streets and every turn makes you fall more in love with Paris. Get lost in this area and then find your way out taking turns to experience a very incredible part of Paris I have spent many days and nights here
Simply charming. One of my favourite areas of Paris. Close to many of the attractions, yet still maintains its appeal. Cafes, walking and shopping are the highlights

Chic part of Paris. We visited this neighbourhood on a Saturday. Initially we walk around an area which was very quiet... most of the small art galleries were closed as were the shops... so probably worth visiting during the week. However, another part of this area was teeming with activity. The shops were open and it was buzzing with people. It is a very upmarket beautiful part of Paris... there is one street, with lots of cafes and restaurants. We sat and ate a light lunch and enjoyed watching the Parisian street life while resting our tired legs.... definately worth visiting

'The Place' to stay in Paris. We stayed at the Hotel Pont Royal in the Saint Germain des Pres Quarter of Paris. It was the perfect place to explore all the famous museums and landmarks in Paris as most of them were reachable on foot. The Seine is only 5 minutes walk away. The area itself is not touristy at all but has a superb selection of quality restaurants, cafés and shops. All the locals we met were friendly and welcoming. This is definitely 'The Place' to stay when visiting Paris.

J'adore this area. Have stayed here many times and feel very comfortable. Easy to walk around and have experienced no problems with anyone or anything. Locals going about their business, so a homey atmosphere but also a high tourist area. Lots of restaurants and interesting shops which are great for fossicking in. The more you visit the more you see! Lots to see and do and close to the Jardins de Luxembourg and the Seine.

Ah . ... the left bank. We began a walk into the left bank from Notre Dame Cathedral Saturday morning. It was a pleasant sunny autumn day. Our mission was to have brunch at Les Deux Magots which we had failed to find on previous visits. This time we were successful and the walk took us along quite a stretch of Rue Saint Germain which is a really buzzy area - but there is even more action in the side streets between Rus Saint Germain and the Seine. Just across the road from Les Deux Magots is the stunning old Abbey of Saint Germain des Pres. Large parts of the old abbey were destroyed in the fires of the revolution - it is just over1 km from the Louvre and the Tuilleries which were also burned at the same time. The lovely old church was open - with very few people walking through and as we walked through we could hear this ethereal chanting from the front of the church. There was a small Taize group worshipping in a small chapel singing simple chants and reading from the scriptures and it created a very special atmosphere inside the vast space. It is worth dropping into this church. We then continued our walk down to the Seine and worked our way past Hotel de Ville looking for the well known pet shops on the right bank - which we found. All in all a pleasant days activity and we were able to soak up the atmosphere of the left bank in the process.

Vintage Paris!. Our hotel was located in an area that used to be like this, but now has become an area of cafes and souvenir shops. I was thrilled to find the "old Paris" along the Blvd. St. Germain. There was an open air market full of stalls selling FRESH food and as well as various other sundry items. Behind the market, there is a row of specialty shops - the green grocer, the fishmonger, the wine shop, the cheese shop, the charcuterrie, the boulangerie, the patisserie. Each one offering the freshest, highest quality food. We've traded down for the so called convenience of having large supermarkets.

Best area in Paris to visit and stay. We love this neighborhood. Its not a tourist trap, and you feel ike you are just living the Parisian lifestyle. More restaurants than you can ever visit, lots of shopping, great boutiques and larger stores as well.

Lots of great places and safe area. My wife and I loved this area, it was very busy with many different kinds of businesses and plenty of good restaurants. It is also easy to access other parts of the city from here with the metro and rer.
Arty Quatier. This is a wonderful area of Paris where there is a vibrant art culture along with some grat eateries and drinking spots.

A must-see if you're in this part of the city. A great area to explore. So many different architectural styles and an array of interesting shops, none of them predictable. One shop even sold vintage clothing by the kilo. Lots of Bohemian type cafes and restaurants.

Chic shopping and eating quarter. Loved walking the streets and waiting outside many shops while my wife shopped for everything form jewellery to shoes.Very pleasant area for a couple of hours with many cafes and restaurants.
Walking Area. Spent a morning just walking around the area, going from street to street following the most interesting path. The architecture, the patisseries - all worth the visit.
Very nice area. Lovely to shop and have a cool (pricy) meal. Not much variety in terms of restaurants though. However I think I would come back here to explore more.
Lovely stroll. This is a lovely area through which to stroll. My friend and I couldn't stop commenting on how cute it is and how picturesque it was from every angle.

Follow the steps of J.P.SARTRE. St. Germain is the subversive bank of the Seine, although nowadays this reputation is vastly overdone. You will still enjoy being seen at Les Deux Magots or at Le Flore where Sartre had is daily espresso. Avery nice street to walk starting at St.Michel.
ao beautiful.. we visited this area with a bike tour; learned a lot about it, it is very lovely and fun. there is a tremendous amount of history in this area, well worth discovering.
Cafes. This is another neighbourhood you can walk and hangaround and have a coffee in the street cafes.This is an area of mix locals and tourists.
Wonderful to Stroll. A wonderful quartier to look at art shops, people and shops. Feel the vibrancy of the area and enjoy its sights!

Excellent cafe - good atmosphere and food. After an afternoon shopping with my wife, we welcomed a friendly cafe with attentive and responsive waiters. The duck was excellent, and the speed of service perfect for our hunger. Great beer selection too
Afternoon stroll. What a beautiful neighborhood make sure to have your camera handy lots of picture moments of small streets ,lots of cafes, stores, just beautiful

A great palce. One of the items on our list to do in Paris was to walk through Saint Germain. We took a leisurely stroll from our accommodation and were pleasantly surprised how quiet it was for a Saturday morning. We then turned into Saint Germain. Quiet became a hub-hub of noise, activity, restaurants and well-known churches and cafes. We brunched, we walked and we wondered at this place. Another wonderful attribute of Paris. See it.

Old Paris feel with ritzy shops and restaurants.. This is one of my favorite areas of Paris. I've been here for 2 weeks and I've walked Saint Germain des Pres everyday. I love the little shops, the art work, the restaurants. I also enjoy looking at the beautiful buildings, some ancient and plain and others laced with amazing wrought iron balconies. It's a walkers paradise.

We love this part of town. There is no Ritz, no Bristol and no George V but there are charming boutique five star hotels like the fabulous Pont Royal nearby in the 7th. Brasserie Lipp is always a trip. L'Atlas still has the best Moules Frites in Paris and if you can get in, Yves Camdebord's Le Relais St. Germain has a great Prix Fix menu on week nights. Be sure to have the Pate Maison.
A Nice Walk. A good place to walk around, stop for a coffee and maybe a pastry. There are some interesting shops and galleries.
Paris in Feb. One of my favorite areas, so close to Latin quarter, the Seine and rue de dragon for shoe lovers. Easy access to metros and trains.
Our go to place in Paris . We almost always stay in or near this part of the city when in Paris. It is full of quaint shops and nice cafes. Easy walks abound. In a word, it's fun.

Cafes!!!. Best place to go is late in the afternoon---- take a stroll along Saint Germain.... Sit and have drinks at the cafes..... Visit the stores around the area..... And stay until dinner and after dinner .......

Fun to walk around!. We were on a quest to do some serious shopping and only ended up eating in this Quarter. (We were disappointed that many American stores are now in Paris. If I wanted to go to the Gap and Banana Republic, I have plenty within a few miles of my house in Atlanta!)We did enjoy walking around and couldn't decide if we wanted to eat at several famous cafes. We finally picked Brasserie Lipp and enjoyed the formal dining.

Only go there by bike. The literary-spirit you can find anywhere else. This area is located near a major traffic artery, and the seine. Therefore it is so expensive, because of the accessibility (!) Do not think you will find authenticity here, but if you want to drink a coffee and one of the people want to be on the terrace, go ahead. Although it is a neighborhood that you must visit once. Price of coffee is about 6 euros each. Breakfast starts at 20 euros.If you have a bike, be sure to visit!
Morning Coffee. An ideal place to it and watch the world go by whilst having you morning coffee and reading the local paper, excellent coffee and excellent service.

Saint Germain off the cusp of Paris. We got a ride to St Germain on one of the many passenger bikes. The driver rode us from the Eiffel tower to St Germain within 15 minutes. St Germain is lovely with wrought iron balconies and a cafe on every corner. Lots of upscale shops and a good place to people watch.
An annual Visit. we walk this area everytime we come to Paris.I great place to sit in a bistro and people watch. Left bank at it's best. Plenty of shopping and cafes adn bistros.

Les Deux Magots. This is a famous cafe that once had a reputation as the rendezvous of the literary and intellectual elite of the city. Patrons included Earnest Hemingway and Picasso. It was fun to sit outside with a glass of wine and watch the world go by.

timeless. It can be trashy but the bulk of it is an enticing melange of art galleries - some in nooks and crannies, classy bars, and classic bistros and brasseries. There will always be a lot of people.
More restaurants per block than anywhere I've seen. Just a fun place to walk around- The Pantheon, the food, the people watching, the cheese store behind the Pantheon etc, etc

Wonderful district - a true Paris experience to be had. Some of the best restaurants, cafes, and hotels in Paris are located in this District and if you truly want to experience Paris the right way... Il faut flaner a un de les Cafe pour des heures avec un bon livre et apprecier tout qui vous entour... My heartfelt condolences go out to all the families that lost loved ones in yesterdays senseless attacks... May the world stand with you and support you and put an end to this senseless violence... On vous aime Paris
One of my favorite areas. What a fun area with beautiful windows, historic cafes, and meandering streets. Antiques, fashion, design, art are all there for acquisition and admiration.
Interesting area of Paris. Busy, stimulating and very bourgeois but a great area to stay with its shops, cafes, and university atmosphere.

quintessential Paris. This is how people imagine Paris. The small side streets that curve, filled with lovely shops, bistros. bars and bakeries. Beautiful neighborhood. Stopped in Le Hibou for dinner and of course a bottle of wine. Dinner was so good we stopped back the following evening.

A good place for sightseeing. A great place to walk especially in the morning.I took a walk in here as I try to getting around the area.I love this area very much and been thinking to go back someday.

great neigborhood,restaurants,bars and shops. we love this neighborhood for the atmosphere,lovely shops and restaurants and bars.enjoying drinks at cafe deux margots and cafe flore,cute little shops and great t walk around and explore the neighborhood...
very chic. Bon Marche! The best shopping ever. The food side is like disneyland for foodies. I often fill an extra suitcase with my purchases!
The Latin Quarter. Full of shops, restaurants, cafes and clubs. Lots of energy, sights , things to do or just people watch!

It's how you pictured Paris. When you think of Paris with the cobblestone streets and side walk cafes this is it. My wife and I stayed here for a week and after a long day of activities we would always come back here to sit for a few hours and regain our energy over a few glasses of wine; Cote de Rhone to be more specific. There's a lot of upscale boutiques throughout the neighborhood so if you're into that, you could easily spend an entire day scouting them out. There's also plenty of bakeries, chocolate shops, ice cream parlors, etc. so if you're a foodie you'll definitely enjoy exploring the area.

Great walking street.. I walked this street daily for exercise and window shopping along the way. Wide street with one way traffic so street crossing is easy. Up scale shops but smaller ones than on the Champs Elysee or Honoree
My favorite neighborhood.. We stayed in the 6th district and carefully observed the atmosphere, the great food and the pastries. I would return here in a heartbeat. It is "home" to us.

Great Area To Visit With Many Good Restaurants. This is a great area of Paris to visit with many boutique shops and practically a restaurant on every corner including the World renowned Les Deux Maggots frequented by many famous writers. Window shopping is free, just ignore the price tags!

Wonderful breakfast. Had breakfast here with the family before heading out on another day of sight-seeing. Great atmosphere on a Sunday morning to sit outside (in November!) and watch the world go by. Excellent fresh pastries, omelettes and the like.

A great place to get lost.. We walked around the ST Germain quarter for several hours looking all the little shops and alleys that the place offered. The cafes and restaurants offering fresh food and the cobble stone roads were just wonderful. No rush, take your time and immerse yourself in the Parisian culture of the place. Enjoy some snails and freshly shucked oysters with a glass of wine.
Shop to you drop. This district is superb for shopping, with gorgeous boutiques on just about every street. From top designers to up and coming the area is a treasure of fabulousness.
Lots of History . Great for shopping and for visiting cafes that were once visited by famous writers. Nice to just walk around and explore.

Proper Paris. Along with the Marais my favourite part of Paris. Every other shop is a brasserie or if not something artisan and special. A combination of wide boulevards like Boulevard St Germain full of boutiques and then the small cobbled streets around L'Eglise St Germain and the more lively area towards the St Sulspice.
Charming area of Paris. I love the quaint streets of St. Germain - nice to get away from the crowds and noise of Paris for a bit. Wonderful cafes for relaxing and taking in the Paris vibe.
Another fun neighborhood to just get out and walk. Another fun neighborhood to just get out and walk with top end stores and very interesting outfits to people watch with.

Feel like a Parisien. I love this area. Lots of restaurants, cafés and shops to wonder around. We always stay here and it is within 5-10 minute walk of the Louvre, Notre Dame and the Latin Quarter. Je l'adore.

really good place to shopping and enjoy. it's a place where local people shopping and take cafe, restaurant , not too much tourist, and also there's a pharmacy very cheap to buy something there. I love this place
Nice area to enjoy a few drinks!. This area is typical of Paris. It's gorgeous for a stroll or just to layback and have few drinks while enjoying the scenery!
Vibrant neighborhood. Vibrant neighborhood with great restaurants, cafes, patisseries, chocolatiers,and boutique shops. Also famous Cafe Flore, les Deux Magots, and Brasserie Lipp.

easily avoidable. If you are staying for a week in Paris, you may try to walk around Saint Germain des Près, the fanciest residential area in Paris. But let's face it: there's nothing extremely essential there. For iconic tourist destinations you should go to Montmartre, Marais and the area by the Louvre, for the authentic Paris lifestyle you should go to Belleville or the area by Place D'Italie
You must go there!. There is everything there. It's a big long street/area having restaurants, pubs, shops, and historical sites worth visiting.

Our favorite neighborhood in Paris. Our favorite neighborhood in Paris. Quintessential Paris. Sophisticated but not snobby like the right bank, lively and with so much history. The best place to stay.

The heart of Paris. I read somewhere that the 6th is the heart of Paris and from my experiences I would have to agree. It oozes charm and character and feels like the place to be, anywhere else and you'd be missing out. The streets are alive on a night with live bands and numerous bars, restaurants and cafes full to the rafters and people pouring out onto the street. Highly recommend staying in this area.

Left bank charm. Smaller scale and more approachable in many ways than the right bank. Diverse, safe, and home to some of the better galleries and restaurants in the city. Extremely walkable day or night.
Nice Area. This was a nice and reasonably safe area to walk through. It has nice shops and cafes with lots of history.
loverly area. visited this area on our extended stay and enjoyed it very much so much to see and quite an upmarket area with many restaurants
Good shopping place at centeral location. There are many good stores for shopping both brands and independent stores. The area is convenitly located at the center of Paris.
Great historical place. It's a lovely area with a great history. Beautiful streets and fountains lots to see and do. Great cafes and restaurants

Another small corner of Paris. Take an hour or so out of your busy schedule if you can, and stroll around this area of Paris. It is charming, with houses and shops crowded together, and cobblestone streets. You can imagine Paris as it was 200 years ago.
Love the side streets. A fun area to walk and explore. Famous cafes, cute shops, neighborhood restaurants, sweet hotels, bookstores, good location near the Seine. True Paris.
So much to do!. There's just tons of things to see and do here: restaurants and shops galore! It's so much fun to poke your head into all the shops!

Class … elegance . . . crowds!. This quarter was one of our highlights of our visit to the Left Bank during our most recent stay in Paris. We found a great array of restaurants, cafes, boulangers, up-market shopping opportunities, sports stores, bookshops, art outlets and souvenir shops. If you happened to be a fan of the Paris-St.Germain Football Club, there were plenty of opportunities to purchase some of their supporters’ merchandise.The area obviously has great drawing power for tourists as the streets were alive with people whilst we were there. The people ranged from elegant Parisians promenading in their fashionable attire and many, many tourists like ourselves through to some people who were obviously “down on their luck”.The Saint Germain des Pres Quarter is certainly a worthwhile area for tourists to visit on the Left Bank. If you happen to be an avid shopper, then you should really enjoy yourself there.

History and and variety in St Germain. This is an area best explored on foot. Starting at the River Seine and heading south. Some of Paris' very early and historic cafes are here but visitors need to shop around to obtain value for money. The journey is neatly concluded at the St Germain church - a historic effigy dating back to the 9th century. From bridge-to-church the walk is about 2 hours at a leisurely pace but there is always time to stop for coffee and just soak in the atmosphere and the huge cross-section of pedestrians strolling by.
one of the best neighborhoods in the city. Every time I go to Paris I enjoy walking around this quaint and historic part of the city, which has some of the best food and shopping. Don't miss it!

The most fun arrondissement!. We stayed here and we did last time in Paris. We could hear music from the streets in our hotel with the window slightly open. Close to 2 metros. Many places to eat snacks, dinner buy wine for the room, gelato, anything you want. Great walking area along the Seine and around the streets..
It's Paris!. We love this area of Paris....it is worth going and spending time...be sure to sit out at the cafes and enjoy the people watching and a great meal!
Paris life. what a nice place to visit , lot of restaurants and nice food , crowded with people from everywhere hang out there for couple of hours

A nostalgic trip. St Germain des Pres is an amazing part of Paris! It brings back memories from the youth and the evenings at Cafe de Flore, Deux Magots, Lipp... entre autres! Near the famous eglise, in the picturesque narrow streets... I enjoy walking, discovering new galleries, antiquities... I enjoy discovering the new titles in the bookstores and rediscovering the old ones. I can almost hear the voice of the great lady of the French chanson - Juliette Greco...

Great Neighbourhood for a stay in Paris. Packed to the rim with fine dining opportunities,, centrally located when you like to walk around Paris and with nice, slightly upschale places, this is the location we prefer when in PAris.Many good and well known places around the Church of Saint Germain des Pres. Rue de Seine, full of nice eateries, many bars where you can sit and sip a drink while enjoying the endless stream of different people passing by.The place to be, at least for us.

Interesting. This is an historiuc and interesting part of Paris. Within it you can find those trying to capture the essence of a time gone by and those pretending to do so. There are the obvious attractions that relate to literary and celebrity figures of North American lore. But then again you can witness sites related to French philosphers, artists and explorers. Saint Suplice, for example, sponsored the voyageurs who over-wintered in Norfolk County, Ontario and famously produced the first wine in the region (and perhaps in North America).

Wonderful Neighborhood. Saint-Germain is Left Bank chic. We rented an apartment here for ten nights and explored thoroughly. What an absolutely charming place. The shops, hotels, restaurants, museums and parks give you the feeling you are in the Paris of the locals, without the tackiness of some of the other less affluent neighborhoods. Nor is it as touristy and cold as the 8th arr. A truly wonderful area of Paris.

I always stay here. while often a bit pricey, I feel that I make it up in not having to use taxis. the 6th is like a hub with all,of Paris, like the spokes of a wheel, easily accessible from St G des P. overflowing with restaurants, many v good, and with Gerard Mullot at hand for the stuff of a picnic (or anything else if you want great food) in the Luxembourg. I recommend the Petite St Andre fa value meal and the Hotel Angleterre as the place to stay.

Charming; colourful. My favourite part of Paris. Good restaurants; charming hotels; many interesting little shops. Close to the University, the Parthenon, the Musee d'Orsay, Notre Dame, the Marais. If you like nightlife this is the place to be.
Always nice to be there. I visited the area many times and can't miss it while in Paris. It has everything for intellectuals and shoppers.

Lovely. St Germain has a beautiful Gothic Cathedral not far from the Louvre. Quiet compared to Notre Dame. Beautiful paintings. Really good cafés and bakeries. Nurseries for flowers and plants. Good French feel but quieter. I liked the area

Wonderful Area of Paris. We stayed nearby at the Hotel Relais St. Sulpice and walked to the Saint Germain de Pres Quarter every morning for breakfast at the The Croissanterie on Rue St. Germain, a great inexpensive place for a coffee (latte) and croissant next to the Catheral St. Germain de Pres. The whole area is dotted with fine shops, restaurants, and Brasseries (many too expensive for what they serve, IMHO; we paid about 22 Euro for one small, one large beer at Lipp). However the entire Rue St. Germain is a wonderful boulevard for a stroll down toward the Seine and the Latin Quarter.
Paris at its best. This area still holds the romance and excitement of the time of Hemingway, Sartre, de Bouvier. Even the traffic holds magic. Most beautiful Boulevard in Paris.

Best part of Paris. This part of Paris retains its old charm amidst modern facilities. It is very popular with the locals who are all friendly. A stroll around the streets off the Boulevard is most intriguing.Our favourite part of Paris undoubtedly.

Great place to say in Paris. We recently stayed in Paris for a weekend and choose to stay in the St Germain des Pres area. I would highly recommend this as a base location for touring Paris. The area has lots of lovely cafes and restaurants and lots of bakeries. I would say it's also good for shopping (although that wasn't something we did). I like that it's a busy area but didn't feel crowded like some other areas of Paris. The main tourist attractions are all easily accessible from the St. Germain area. We used the Paris Velib (bicycle) service and this was a great way to get around. There are lots of museums in the area, including the Rhodin musem, Musee D'Orsay and others. It was nice to spend the day touring around but then to come back to the St Germain area in the evening. There are plenty of restaurant options within easy walking distance and a café at every corner.
My favorite. Part of the city I like the most. From Cafe de Flore till St.Michele. Paris as IT used to be last century.
The real Paris. This is the real representative quarter of paris - touristic in one hand but on the other - not to much

Great Place to Wander. Interesting Quartier with lots of cafes & restaurants, and art galleries to browse. Close to the Siene where you can hop on a Batou Bus to the Eiffel Tower or cross the river to Notre Dame.

Art and trendy cafes. The area of Saint-Germain-des-Pres is one of my favorite areas of Paris. It has many well known cafes, art stores, fancy fabric stores (lots of beautiful silks), and antiques. Be very careful if you park your car in one of the underground parking lots because of the pick-pockets. One of my bags was stolen when I was paying for my parking ticket.

Convenient and charming. We stayed here in the Rue de Placide ,in a beautiful apartment , with many good restaurants in walking distance , close to Bon Marche and lots of shops and the Luxemburg gardens .

The best place to stay. The 6th is the best district to stay while in Paris. The streets are buzzing with people, and there are so many shops and restaurants! The Rue de Buci is so much fun to visit. Can't wait to go back!
never forget to visit Sait germain des Pres. Always in our planning : Saint Germain des Pres for Galleries, Restaurants, Cafes, shopping and just struggling around

for art lovers. this quarter is my favourite in paris, where you can visit lots of art galleries and studios with differnt piece of artwork.
extensive choices of cafes and restaurants in the neighborhood.
recommending to stay around in a hotel as well.

Vibrant area and plenty of places to dine. Also some lovely shoppiing!. If you get your map out and study it, you can find a good route to get to most of the landmarks in the centre - it is a great place to stay

Gorgeous area - fabulous shops and cafe's. We loved this quaint little quarter of Paris, and found the worlds best French macaroons!! Pierre Herme baby! Put this section of Paris on your list! :) Also some of the worlds best chocolate boutiques are in this area!
Sidewalk cafe. We went to this quarter just on a whim. When we got off the metro I spotted Les Deux Magots so of course we stopped for wine and people watching.

Lots to do and great shopping. The church is one of the oldest in Paris. Streets wide and yet many smaller quaint side places. Many good places to eat. Great fun in the evening. Rue de Buci very entertaining.
Great place to stroll around. I love this area, great night life, close to all the attractions. Awesome restaurants . A little more touristy than some other parts but all in all a great area to stay
I try to avoid.... Full of tourists, expensive souvenir-type area. Visit only off-season. Nice to walk trough though...
Classic student scene. Rive Gauche of the river Seine, this Paris arrondissement is bustling with activity, students and tourists invading the streets, bars and restaurants at all hours
Great shopping. A neat area for walking and window shopping. Some amazing children's clothes stores will give you an idea as to what the well-heeled Parisian toddler is wearing this season.

One of the oldest neighborhoods of Paris ( the year 600 !). One of the oldest neighborhoods of Paris ( the year 600 !)At first it was just the Abbaye Saint Germain, formed by the equë of Paris ( the same name) ; can you imagine that there were meadows and pastures there? and yet it was. Today the shelter of the oldest bell tower in Paris , find themselves artists and intellectuals (Both Magots , the café de Flore ) , politicians and businessmen , in short, life is intense and exciting . Do not miss the place Furstenberg , Rue Christine , rue Jacob ... you fall in love inevitably

“Wonderful for shopping and people watching”. Good for shopping, many surprises.We visited this Quarter and were amazed by the things there are. Many prety restautants, coffee shops, and while you keep walking you will find the Eglise de Saint Germain des Pres,
Feels like Geneva. This lovely area is dense and hilly, with plenty of reasonably priced shops full of curiosities. It makes for a pleasant afternoon.

Just loved all of it!. We rented an apartment on rue Bonaparte for our three days in Paris. It couldn't have been a more convenient or sublime location for seeing the sites and simply sitting on gorgeous terraces, drinking a glass of rose and people watching. Plenty of great restaurants across the food and price spectrum. A terrific place to wander at night - safe, fun and full of joie de vivre!
Vibrant neighborhood. Vibrant neighborhood that is easy to get around. Lots of restaurants and hotels and shops. I slways come back here. Also close to great high end shopping on the rue du four.
Magical area. Great walking area, book stores, movie houses and lots of students, great food spots and shopping, make sure you hit Luxenbourg Garden
great for shopping and people watching. Never stayed in this area,prefer the right bank.Enjoy shopping here and has some good cafes for sitting and people watching,
OK for a stroll.. Good for restaurants and cafes. It's kinda touristy but that's OK if you're going for a stroll. Close to other sites.

Summer 2014. Louis Vuitton at Saint Germain des Pres does not disappoint! The service is quite professional yet attentive without the usual line at its much larger flagship store. At this more intimate site, you are able to find the jewelry and shoes near the more desired handbags. And yet the choices presented here have a more definitive style for those who don't necessarily follow the crowd. If you need a moment to decide, you can request for some champagne. Well, there is also the famous Les Deux Magots just a few steps away where my Mom, sister and I celebrated for lunch.

Quarter where you will find many surprises. We visited this Quarter and were amazed by the things there are. Many prety restautants, coffee shops, and while yuu keep walking you will find the Eglise de Saint Germain des Pres, which first buildig was made aroun the VI century, which makes it one of the most ancient buildings in Paris. In this church you will fin Rene Descartes tumb. Around the church you will find many high end stores. Continuing through the street from the church's main entrance, you will find many antique's stores with great things to see, So this is a quarter that has many surprises for you.

Great Place to Stroll, Shop and People Watch. Saint Germain is exactly as everyone describes it: lots of shops, noise, restaurants and people. It's a exciting part of Paris, always filled with hustle and bustle.

Again. Stayed here for a week a couple of years ago. Visited after a trip to tower Montparnasse . Down rue Rennes and onto Rue Bonaparte .then followed boulevard Saint Germain to the river. Always plenty to look at and plenty to eat. Nice area especially at night.

My Favotite. The minute you step out of the metro station, you will feel the Parisian spirit all around this area. Just pick any cafe, sit with your news paper, order a baguette, butter and jam and one cup of coffee...Enjoy..

Love St. Germain!. Most wonderful neighborhood! Wonderful restaurants, grocery stores, bakeries and shopping all in a beautiful and charming area! We rented an apartment for a week in St. Germain des Pres, we choose the best location ever on our 5th trip to Paris. Perfect place if you are staying more than a few days in Paris, because you are not going to want to leave here!
True gem!. True French spirit, with beautiful and stylish bars, restaurants, shops.Feel the Paris and spend hours here, won't regret it!

Excellent area. Great location within walking distance of Eiffel Tower, Seine, Luxembourg Gardens, Notre Dam, full of fabulous cafes, restaurants, boutiques, shops with a fabulous selection of produce especially all the delicious cheeses and breads. Great to just sit in a café and people watch

Fun on the Left Bank .... My favorite Parisian quartier, for good reason - loaded with history & filled with easily accessible shopping. The big names are here, only in smaller & friendlier shops than on Rue St. Honoree. Plus Cluny, LUX Gardens, Pantheon & IIIE de la Cite' / Notre Dame. Quaint neighborhoods & a plethora of fine restaurants. Can't be beat. Enjoy...

Hidden gem area.. I really like this area. Many unique restaurants... And quaint shops. Hidden streets and little nooks and crannies that had wonderful goodies. Really special area. Felt like the real Paris.

Go here vs the Champs!. The shops on St Germain are more unique compared to the Champs and fewer bus tour type of groups. Clearly a Parisian neighborhood vs a tourist trap area. Great restaurants and cafes in the area. We ate at Au 35 Rue Jacob which is just off St. Germain. Great little place for a dinner.

It Is a Wonderful Place to Live, but You WOULD Like to Visit There!. This neighborhood is simple wonderful. It would take a book, not a short review, the list all of the pleasures to be found here, from wonderful boutique hotels, to heavenly cafes, to a multitudes of shops, to beautiful churches, to gorgeous Parisian architecture. I love the Left Bank much more than the Right Bank personally, and this area is a wonderful plum to experience of the Left Bank's many treasures. And the atmosphere is warm and welcoming everywhere you go. It gives you the most sublime feeling in Paris: simply that YOU ARE IN PARIS!
How the Other Half Live. We went through the district on an open top bus and it was obvious that this is an extremely rich area of the city.
Great area. We loved staying in this area as it close to many sites, the trains, and restaurants. It also has the RER access to CDG which we used. Would stay in this area again.

Designer shopping and galleries. The SoHo (NY) of Paris, quieter than Latin Quarter and much more upscale. Shopping is mostly designer clothes, fine art, furniture and high end decorating goods. Lovely area to stroll and window shop

Fantastic location!. This is a fantastic location. Beautiful architecture. Within walking distance to the Seine, Louvre, Luxembourg Gardens, Saint Michelle, Notre Dame and many more sights. Great shopping, restaurants, cafes, metro stations and also a pick up point for LOpen Tour hop on hop off bus on Boulevarde St Germain. Loved our time staying in this area.

A little less busy at night, but great shopping during the day. Great neighborhood between the Luxembourg Garden and the river. Plenty of places to visit. The area is in a good location to walk to most of the sights, but is a little more quiet than the Latin Quarter or across the river in the First.

This is Paris. Do it properly.. This is a pure atmosphere area of Paris. Find a cafe (of which you'll find some of the best in town) and stop to soak it all in. Maybe find a George Larnicol chocolate shop for Macaron's and have them with your espresso. If you're in this area in the evening, have a Kir Royale while you watch the street life. A ton of museums, ancient churches, galleries... Your town does not have this... Unless you are Parisien.

Art! Art! Art!. If you are looking to purchase works when you are in Paris, this is a great area to start your search. The streets are lined with galleries, and you never know what you will find if you take the time to wander!

The most entertaining arrondissment in Paris.. No matter how many times I am in Paris the St. Germain area has the best visuals in the city. Small cafes, tiny hotels, Snobby cafes and great restaurants combine to make this area the best.

Liked is as a student; love it now. This is Paris to many of us. Cafes. restaurants, churches, boulevards, - people. For 40 years I avoided Cafe Deux Maggots: too expensive and trendy. My wife said, GO. We went. Great hot chocolate. No more expensive than others. Walk, sit, walk, eat. I am biased but it is great.
Following Proust steps. Loved the small strees and upscale boutiques! The restaurants offer both authentic and a wide selection of choices.

Charming character doesn't go away. There is something special about the left bank and this area in particular.I won't say how long ago it was that i first fell in love with this quarter. But my love affair continues.Whether it's the "bouquinistes" by the Seine, the charming cafes or the clubs at night, I love this area. Make sure you spend some time here
Saint Germain des Pres!. The 6th arrondissment is the best part of Paris! Excellent cafes, boutique hotels, the best museums, shopping and quintessential Paris architecture.
Very "Paris". Very "Paris" just to walk around, shop, eat and drink - but a good guide book with history, map, and background info makes it even better.

My local neighbourhood!. The Saint Germain des Pres Quarter - which is in the 6eme arrondisement is a chic quintessential Parisian quartier. Shops, cafes, restaurants, jazz clubs, markets, old churches - a beautiful and charming district. Lively fun and active - not to missed during your trip in Paris. Was in Paris last week and spent many an evening walking around this lovely area with my friends. Highly recommended!
Lively and pleasant. St. Germaine is a lively, pleasant section of Paris with many shops, a great selection of eateries and an enjoyable place to walk.
Nothing good at all to see after walking more then a mile. Its a small chuch after walking a mile from boat stop .In busy itinerary of Paris its not worth spending you precious time

Perfect place to base yourself. Centrally located and within walking distance of all the tourist areas in Paris, but a very attractive area to stay in. Close to transport and not far from Jardins de Luxembourg my new favourite place on Earth.
Wine and Shellfish.....need I say more. Busy, crowded and noisy, but a shellfish tower in the right location and some people watching offsets any of that. It's worth an afternoon of exploration.
A Great Place to Walk. Great place to walk and experience upscale shopping and eateries. Take some time to see St. Germain des Pres Church.

Great area to stay, eat and shop!. Great restaurants, shops, cafes, and chocolate shops - what more could you ask for. Very close to the Louvre and many other sites. Don't miss a boat trip on the Seine.
More upscale!. My husband liked this area a lot. It was very upscale and seemed pretty friendly. Love the different architecture everywhere. So much history!

Shop til you drop.. We did a walking tour of,this district and truly loved it. The boutique shops as well as the gourmet markets and department stores were all one can ask for if shopping is on your agenda.
Authentic Paris. Always feels like authentic Paris here. Far far better than the utterly dreadful experience of the Latin Quarter.

Best of all. Best of arrondissement in my opinion. Saint Germaine is upscale but yet trendy and hip. So many great cafes and boutiques!! Many parisians live here so that you are not just bumping into lost tourists.We stay on Rue de Bac just south of Saint Germain Blvd. It is a comfortable walk to the Seine and museums.

amazing. we visited this quarter several times.
i think it is a great place to be in paris
lots of cafes resturants and shops
good atmosphere
LIKE IT
romantic. the best tip i can give you is to arrive with no knowledge and to get lost in the beautiful alleys, its a real Parisian experience
Go there!. THE place to have a perfect "classic" outdoor sidewalk Parisian experience. Coffee and croissants in the afternoon are the best.
great. Great place to wonder about going in to all shops and little restaurants. Great chocolate shops and bakeries

Great place to stay when in Paris.. I echo what all the others have said, and add that it's handy to several metro stops too! I love hearing the bells of St. Sulpice on the hour. Bread and roses cafe, the small side streets. Heaven.

One of my most favourite parts of Paris. I love this part of Paris and its nice independent stores, pretty restaurants and some artisan and specialty shops. There is too much to see, just go and walk around and also see if there are any flee markets on Sundays in area and go bargain hunting!
St. Germain is the place to stay.. We stayed in the Latin Quarter but seemed to wander over to St. Germain on most evenings for dinner. Great energy and fabulous cafes.
Nice place, good location. Lots of restaurants,very close to Notre Dame and to metro and that's why to all atractions, good location to stay in Paris.
Touristy. A very nice area to walk around . The Odeon is also walking distance from here. Very touristy but interesting. Got restaurants and cafes all over the place !
A true neighborhood. Noisier, dirtier and much more crowded than I remember from previous visits, the area nevertheless retains its bohemian charm
Saint-Germain Christmas Market. Planning a trip during December? The Christmas market is a must in this area. Fresh waffles and crepes just 4-5 Euros a piece. Great crafts and soaps, don't miss it!
A Favorite Neighborhood. This district is very near Notre Dame but far enough away to lose the crowds. It is a great place to wander in search of interesting shops and terrific restaurants.
Best of Paris. Great high-end shopping; great people watching; very busy Quartier which covers a lot of territory. Wonderful to walk (and get lost) in.

Stay in this area!. My #1 recommendation is to stay in the St. Germain area. You will be within walking distance to nearly everything from the Eiffel Tower (a bit of a hike from Blvd St. Germain, but the buses are great here!) or the Arc de Triomphe and Champs-Elysees, but most everything else along the Seine is close. Also walking distance to the Latin Quarter and Jardins de Luxembourg. Lively street day or night, upon which sit cafes and restaurants and shops and street vendors/open air markets and Cafe Flores and Les Deux Magots, as well as the church of St. Germain. Much better strolling than the Champs-Elysees, in my opinion!

MY FAVOURITE ARRONDISEMENT IN PARIS. Saint Germain hosts some of the best places in Paris to visit and enjoy. Among the cafés and restaurants I suggest Café de Flore and Café Deux Magots. Restaurant Brasserie Lipp, frequented by artists during the beginning of the past century like Picasso or Braque, le Procope, etc... Thousands of art galleries and beautiful boutiques are accompanies by other tinier shops more affordable. A must neighborhood to visit. And of course, the church of Saint Germain des Pres.

Our "home" for three days, and we miss it. We rented an apartment for three days on the Rue du Four in the heart of the Saint Germain des Pres, and it was perfect. We had brunch at Les Deux Magots, dinner in several neighborhood bistros, and felt like real Parisians for an all-too-brief time. I'd read on the TA Paris Forum that the 6th Arrond. is a good place for first-time visitors, and I agree. We can't wait to come back!

watch out for pink trousers. fab.. knightsbridge in paris. left bank french luxury. beautiful shops, restaurants, church and spending. why not. vieux paris, and forget left wing french local politics. this is where it's at. vive la france of the 30s. go to the flore, les deux magots & the lip, insitutions no less.
The best position. We only stay in this area when visiting Paris as you are amongst all of the action and can walk everywhere.

Location, location, location. For our third visit to Paris we chose the St Germaine de Pres area, Rue Jacob to be exact. There are a number of quaint, boutique hotels in very interesting old buildings in the area. Hotel Millesime was ideal for us. Restaurants abound, and it's not the cheesy tourist trap you find in most tourist areas. And don't be mistaken, this location is tourist heaven for those that like to walk an area to death. Minutes to the metro, and you should get to know the metro in this city as it will expand your visit greatly. Brasseries abound, as do cafes, patisseries, boulangeries, and fine evening dining. The area is minutes from many, many great Paris icons and further includes many hidden gems. Don't miss the eglise St Germaine des pres. Review trip advisor for things to do in St Germain as the list is far too long to go through. We have stayed in the Montparnasse area, the la Defense area, as well as close to the arch de triomphe ... the St Germain area was the best in my opinion.
Near the Sorbonne and the Université of Paris. An interesting corner of the 6th. I like Montparnasse a little better but this is a nice section with some great bookstores.

Walk, SIp Coffee, Walk Sip Wine and Eat Cheese - it is Paris at its best. This is one of my favorite walking places in Paris. The cafe's for coffee, the street vendors for chocolate covered waffles, and the street cafes for wine and cheese in the afternoon and evening are such fun. This is something you can do in the rain (with an umbrella of course).
Trendy area - but classy and high-end. Classy, trendy area. Lots of galeries and a bit less crowded than many other areas in Paris. Perfect for a stroll and some drinks for brunch

feel the energy. Saint Germain des Pres Quarter is the oldest part of the town where the arts began, where is the famous caffe Magot, where Paris town lives very very partys in the twenties. Feel that energy

Best place to stay for museum buffs. We stayed in Saint Germain and found it unbelievably convenient to the museums, Notre Dame and there are many great cafes and restaurants. It is a very walkable neighborhood.

Old little streets, antiques, cafes, art galléries, boutiques!. I have leave in Paris two years from now and I never get enough of this area. The old medieval streets that are perfectly combined with an amazing mix of antiques shops, many art galleries, and boutiques. The Eglise de St Germain des Pres is a jewel (the tower is the oldest one in France) and just across the street you find Cafe des Deux Maggots, Cafe Flor and Brasserie Lipp. Highly recommended to organize a sweet / food walking tour to try many of the delicious things around (chocolate, candies, olive oil, sweets…the list is very long!). The best second hand store in Paris - luxury brands - is located in this area (Rue Bonapart) where you can find sometimes articles that still have the tag or that have been used a couple of times at the most (Chanel, Dior, Hermes). Get lost in the little streets and jump in and out of all the little stores. Pass by Rue de Verneuil and see the funky house of Serge Gainsbourg.

Cafe Mollard - Paris, France.. Went for lunch at Cafe Mollard, very Art Deco in style and like most Paris restaurants very good and like many Paris restaurants, starts out great but tapers off at the last stages. I am not sure why or if it is merely coincidence. It has been in business since the original Mollard started selling snacks to workers in the nearby market over 100 years ago. It was recommended by our apartment owner - a French lady married to an Englishman.
Popular & fun location. Have stayed in this area twice and would do so again on my next visit. Lots of restaurants, bars and definitely more young/hip than other areas.
Paris - picturesque. It is exactly the Paris you expect, quaint cafes, beautiful flowers hanging from every level. Nice to walk through or stop for a coffee.

Cafe des Deux Maggots. My dream came true, I had a cup of coffe in the iconic Cafe des deux Maggots. This is a place where famous writers, philosophes and actors used to meet: Luis Aragon, Elsa Triollet, Ernst Hemingway and many others.And now me!
A must in Paris. I am a Paris oldtimer, come here since the 60es and always come back to this area where so much happens in Paris. Sit in Les Deux Magots, opposite the church and watch it unfold!

Touristy, but worth a visit.. Great experience and a place that always has something going on. The shops seem to have the same things, so look around, as you can find unique items.
