Saint-German-des-Pres, the Opera, and the Marais. This was hands-down my very favorite. I would highly recommend using this as your home for your visit. It is very centrally located to many of the iconic Parisian must-sees and it's selection of cafes, patisseries, and shops is wonderful. This is where I would stay again in Paris. We loved it!

Reasonable eats in St. Germain. There are a lot of pricier places in St. Germain, but just a little east of Deux Magot [heading toward the Latin Quarter] you find some charming side streets that not only have a great buzz but offer food at reasonable prices. Several offer Prix Fixe meals. The streets to go to are the corner of rue de Seine and rue Buci and go from there. They meet at a cross. Great vibe day and night.

Great central stay. Where I stayed during my first time visit to Paris. Great area and very lively. Ton of places to eat, shop, see...It was a crowd mixed with couples, singles, and families. Would definitely stay in or near this area again!

"Tu viens me visiter A Saint-Germain-des-Prés". A very energetic area to be even on Sunday. It was lovely to hear the jazz bands play and one can easily picture the writers, thinkers, and musicians that contributed to its magical status walking up and down the streets.

Oh, the 6th. We loved our short time here. St. Germain, rue de Buci, the cafes, the crowds. Lots of tourists, yes, but so were we. If only we'd had more time to tour the galleries and patisseries. There's always next time, isn't there?

Cozy, Lively Art Town. St Germain doesn't disappoint. If what you're looking for is "old Paris" scattered with nice restaurants, shops and artists, St. Germain is where you want to stay. We did an apartment-share, which was authentic and enjoyable because we felt a part of the community. We had hundreds of delicious cafes, patisseries, boulageries, and bars within walking distance. The metro runs right by and you can take the train directly from Orly International Airport nonstop in 30 minutes. The stops are St Michele and Notre Dame. There are a few chain restaurants, try to avoid those. Most people spoke English but it's more fun to try some French. There were plenty of tourists but it still retained its French charm. Notable walkable attractions include Notre Dame, the Louvre, the "locks" bridge, Jardin de Luxembourg, the justice building, and many other things. St Germain is located on the Rive Gauche, or Left Bank of the Seine.

Restaurant Central. Historic, chic, and offers many restaurants and places to shop. Enjoy strolling thru many chic boulevards and rues taking in the elegant shoppe windows, scents and sounds of the area. Be sure to visit the small midieval streets and take in the glorious architecture still present. So much to see and do.

Amazing area. This area has a wonderfully free-spirited atmosphere. So much to see and do, and just walking around looking at the scenery is exciting. Many many restaurants and cafes to choose from, and a lot of inviting shops too. We planned to go north of the river for some sightseeing, but ran out of time as this quarter was so fascinating.

love it. sitting in a cafe and enjoying your cafe creme and just watch people. listen to the sound of the street. I just love the spirit and vibe of this quarter with its boulevards and huge trees. same for Quartier Latin :-)

Great Area!. I loved this area we stayed in! Boulevard St. Germain has so many shops and cafes, one to mention is the famous Les Deux Margots. As you walk down the street there is so much to absorb and it is truly the Parisian experience. Don't miss this area.
Great area for some good restaurants and shopping. This area is very chic - with lots of restaurants, bistros and shopping. Best of all it is not as crowded!
Great to roam around. Some great streets and shops to roam around in one afternoon. Weather was perfect in late May and this area seemed very safe

fascinating quartier. Alive, vibrant, lots to do, see and eat. Loved the corner shops, the art galleries, the small streets from the middle-ages, the colours, the scents, the sound of french in the backgroound, the elegance, the summer light.

Lively and fun. I took a walk from Gare d'Austerlitz, through the Jardin des Plantes and found myself in St. Germain-des-Pres, full of open air markets, quaint storefronts and tons of brasseries and cafes. Just lovely.

Lovely neighborhood. The st Germain is a typical French neighborhood, I just love it! It's lovely to stroll around in the streets and stop by for a coffee at its famous cafes: cafe de Flore. It's not to be missed when visiting paris!

cool scene. It has everything you want as a visitor.....restaurants of every description, lively and quiet places, historical, must-see sights, and a cool vibe. I highly recommend staying here when you come to Paris.
Great shopping, cafe and entertainment.. If you want to enjoy a great afternoon, I believe St.Germain is one of Paris greatest neighbourhoods . It's a little posh and $$$. But worth it.
quieter but really nice part of paris. we stayed close by when off to see PSG; friendly and loads of choice to eat and drink and watch the world go by

Best place to stay in Paris. Of my three trips to Paris, this is my favorite place to stay. It has amazing restaurants, shops, bars and arts on the street selling their creations. This is exactly what I imaged Paris would be like.

Loved this area. Just stayed in this area for a two-week stay with my granddaughter and LOVED it. Didn't feel real touristy - not the usual souvenir shops but neighborhood cafes, locals going about their daily routines and listening to French being spoken everywhere. SOOOOO glad we stayed in this area.

Oo La La!. This part of Paris is so exciting (but where isn't in Paris). We love the ability to check out restaurants and we loved a Jazz Club. I wish I remembered the name of it. We had so much fun, not only listening to the live music, but also dancing to it and watching others thoroughly enjoying. I also enjoyed the diversity that exist there. Every race and culture seem to be one big happy family.
THIS IS PARIS. If one conjurs up thoughts op Paris this is the quarter they had heard about. Fun wandering the broad and narrow streets and finding new sights around every corner.
Lovely Old Quarter. A great place to walk around and take in the sights. Old buildings, shops, gardens and restaurants. You get a real feel for Paris.
The best neighborhood. Great to be there and convenient to transportation for other visits. We stayed @ the Hotel Bonaparte and were able to walk around a lot.

Perfect location. We rented an apartment for a month in this area on Rue de Dragon, So convenient to everything. Walk to the Louvre, D'Orsay, Notra Dame.and many other things. Many many restaurants fun little streets to explore. I would stay in this area again and again.

Excellent Shopping and Sites. This area is a fantastic area to shop, eat and sightsee in. It is interesting to see that Les Deux Magots and Le Café Flore are right next to each other. There are some interesting antique shops. It is also a great place to people-watch and it is nice that if you go in the morning it isn't full of other tourists. A great place to spend a morning.

One of the most vibrant quarters in Paris. Home to the St.Germain-des-Pres Boulevard with its chique stores, restaurants and Paris' oldest church: Saint-Germain-des-Pres. It is also home to the Boulevard St. Michel with its student population. The fantastic medieval Cluny museum is right on the corner of the 2 Boul's and also nearby is the old massive Saint-Sulpice Church. Wander the small side-streets north and south of the Boulevard St.Germain and discover a multitude of interesting places, restaurants, shops, squares, etc. Definitely one of the nicest quarters in Paris.
Walk and Walk. Home of the famous Cafes and many many shops- you can spend days walking , shopping and eating your way aorund this quarter on the left bank.
As always very chic and very lively. Always love going there. Very chic and a great area to sit with a glass of wine and something nice to eat and watch the world go by.

Love it!. This area is busy but a great place to visit. There are a lot of shops and food places to go to as well as a lot of chocolate shops (which of course were sampled). Great part of Paris, very unique and very individual. Would go back to that area again.

Maybe the best district/quartier to stay, shop and go to museums.. This district has everything, museums and galleries, movie theaters and theaters, shops, bookstores, food stores, boutiques, restaurants, cafés and more... One could, if a frequent visitor tho the french capital city, stay there and never leave the district.

Great part of Paris for strolling and exploring. In my three trips to Paris I always gravitate back to Saint-Germain. It is a fun walking neighborhood for exploration; lots of history, shopping, architecture and people watching.

Busy and exciting area. It is a busy area and I did not feel safe. Lots of café and bar opportunities and some quality shops. However the crowds became difficult to walk in easily and I needed space to recover a sense of balance.
Dinner in St Germain. very nice area.. next to Luxembourg Gardens.. we had a nice Italian dinner there.. at Del Pappa Restarutant..

Buzzy. This area is great for its bars and restaurants , sit on a sidewalk and watch the passing crowds.so busy at late afternoon so not always easy to find seating. We travelled as 4 people so a little harder.
St Germain- I love it. This is my favourite area in Paris, just window shopping is fabulous-especially the interior designer shops. A vist to La Grande Epicerie de Paris is a must
Great area. Stayed here and loved it. Enjoyed all the sidewalk cafes. Not touristy, lots of local Parisians. Great sites to see also.

my favorite place in Paris. Boulevard St Germain is jthe heart of Paris , just walking and have a coffee in Le Flore or Les deux Magots, visit the church of St Germain, walk to the streets of Rue Bonaparte and see the nice shops all around , everywhere there are gallerie, shops and bars and restaurants... Enjoy....

St Germain by night. To me its the nicest area in Paris, all the streets and avenues are wide, clean and beautifull Hausmann apartment buildings.
The streets like rue de l'Ancienne Comedie and rue de Buci off of Boulevard St Germain are full of little restaurants and Musique..
Boulevard st Michel all the way down to the statues, and the Seine..is a must see..

A Vibrant If Touristy Heart of the Left Bank. Guidebooks would have you believe this is where the "Lost Generation" of Hemingway, Joyce, Faulkner and Gertrude Stein hung out at Deux Maggots, but the vibe is more touristy than literary these days. The bookstore Shakespeare & Co. still exists along the Seine, and the views of Notre Dame are divine at night, but this is more about cheap drinks and outdoor cafes filled with foreigners than the "real" Paris.That having been said, it's a very vibrant neighborhood at night, especially from the Rue de Rennes eastward to the Pont St. Michel. One of Paris's best restaurants, Le Reminet, is nearby, just off the Quai de la Tournelle, but overall try to avoid the restaurants on the main streets.
Great atmosphere. I loved the narrow streeets, bustling with life.There's also plenty of bars and reastaurants here. Well worth a visit more than once.
Very nice district. We walked around in this district and enjoyed the atmosphere, the coffee shops, and small stores. There was also a nice market on the main street.

Shopping + Food + Locals. We stayed in an apartment in this area and had an excellent time. Several cafe and brasseries and markets for food. Shopping was fun, lots of cool and funky shops as well as cute places to buy scarves and other knick-knacks. The area we stayed was residential so it was fun to go to our corner cafe and have dinner with those who are fortunate enough to call Paris "home".

Great pedestrian experience.. If you like to eat and drink, there is a wide variety of cafes, restaurants, bistros, bars and other food and beverage options in this zone. There are many architectural landmarks. There are quite a few plaques, on various buildings, commemorating the members of the Resistance who helped to liberate Paris in 1944. They are not necessarily all that obvious unless you slow down and wander around. You won't see them (not many anyway) if you drive through. This is not an area to rush through, there are many layers of things to see and do, essentially every building here has a story to tell. The variety of places to eat and drink is huge.

Not really an 'attraction" per se, but a highlight of our visit, for sure. We spent one night on the Champs Elysee, and moved over to a small boutique hotel on the left bank, 1/2 block from Boulevard Saint-Germain, for the rest of our visit. Everything in St Germain du Pres is just so...French. Quaint shops, bistros, bars, chocolatiers, boulangerie, charcuterie, pastisserie, glacier, wine shops and the list goes on. Stroll the cobblestones. Be open to the street barker - you may just have a great time in their establishment. Travel is about being open to serendipity. There is serendipity in abundance here.

One of the nicest areas in Paris. Buzzing area with lots of art galeries, bars, restaurants, the beautiful Musee d'Orsay. Just wander around on a sunny day or warm evening to get the feel of this wonderful area!
Lively Quarter. This is also known as Latin Quarter with a lot of eating joints at a budget price in the small lanes. This is a very lively place in the nights.

Find the Original Gates to the City. This is the old Paris! Wonderful area to wander around and enjoy the scenery. My favorite thing to do here was look for tilting buildings that have stood the test of time. Great place for people watching and enjoying a charming afternoon.

Very expensive area.. We visited this area while we were looking for somewhere to have dinner. This is obviously a very busy area for tourists. In contrast to where we were staying in 75003,the prices of dining were outside our budget in Saint-Germain-des Pres-Quarter. It was an interesting place to walk around nevertheless.
Great restaurants and galleries!. Wherever we walked, shopped or ate in this quarter was fabulous! We loved wandering past all of the galleries and the variety of restaurants and cafes!

Charming area, so Parisian. When we first visited Paris nearly 30 years ago we stayed near Etoile / Champs Elysees for the first few years. Then we discovered Saint Germain which is a lot cheaper and has a more typically French flavour with small but excellent restaurants and cafes. St, Michele or Luxembourg stations are on the direct RER line from the airport. If you are staying in the more typically tourist areas like Etoile or Opera or Republic, get on the metro, wander round St. Germain and the Latin Quarter and see what you think. More interesting things happen in the smaller, quainter areas of Paris.

Foodie's Heaven. Nice place to stay for visitors and almost too many good restaurants to try. Not recommended if you are on any serious diet because the competition among chefs here is more than serious. Served by many metro lines and walking distance to many top places to see in Paris.

Smart sophistication.. Lovely part of the city with a true Parisienne feel.Good shopping experience and lots of browsing potential.some interesting stalls around the Eglise Sulpice,selling antique books of all genres.
love this area. I love stayng in this area. Lots to do and see and a safe location. Many metro stops so easy to get around.

Make time to wander St Germain des Pres. Lots of people head to La Marais but St-Germain-des-Pres, to my mind, is much more low key and fun. It has a different vibe and is, traditionally, the arty-cafe-student side of town. Lots of book shops and quirky shops.

Visiting St Germain des Pres. This really is a fun area to explore and check out the little streets and alleyways and the Abbey is quite stunning. Check out more information on my post about this lovely arrondissemont below.http://travelphotodiscovery.com/spending-a-perfect-day-in-paris/

It is worth a visit. It is worth a visit.
Very tourist place but still gives you a good feel of Paris.
Prices are above average.

Wonderful area to explore. Great base for a trip to Paris. Fascinating art galleries,museums, shops, cafes, restaurants, churches and crowded with history. Expensive if you're not careful - but quite possible to eat well and enjoy on a more modest budget.

Must visit. One of the landmarks of Paris. I must visit every time I visit my lovely city. I enjoy very much walking through all these narrow alleys and see the restaurants. Just be carful of your wallet in the crowd. I heard stories of people lost their wallets. Many restaurants, bars, and cafes. Full of tourists and street shows. Enjoyable for the whole family.
Love the Cafes and Resturants. We loved this area its food , cafes, and local characters this is an area you must visit when in Paris

Interesting but a little seedy in some places. We stayed at Hotel Mayet in this area and spent much time walking around this arrondisement. There are some very lovely buildings. Construction and reworking buildings going on around and about. There were a few questionable streets. Near St. surplice it's pretty active with things going on most of the time - art or music or people watching. I prefer the Marais area.Several cafes and restaurants available.
Great shopping & restaurants. There are a couple of lanes off Rue de Sevre with lots of choices in bars & restaurants that are worth hunting out.

Real France. Beautiful area, wonderful shopping, fantastic food. Loved walking and sightseeing. This area is a must to enjoy. Highly recommended - wear comfortable shoes for take aBlue Bike tour through some of the streets.
Lovely atmosphere. Super area of Paris - really enjoyed wandering around the streets and discovering quirky shops. Lovely part of Paris and would certainly be very nice to stay in.
Great place for a walk. Excellent place to explore the ancient architecture of Paris with many excellent restaurants / bistros. Hard to choose which are the best!
Come for the atmosphere. The place is full of little cafes and restaurant, where the times seems to have stopped. People enjoy their life while sipping coffees. Great place!

Such a beautiful and charming neighborhood. Such a beautiful and charming neighborhood. We stayed here for a week and felt like a Parisian. If you can do stay here, its really nice. Boulangerie, cafes, restaurants, shopping all around. And still not at all noisy. Quiet and charming. The church which i believe is the oldest church in Paris is lovely, small but more warm than Notre Dame.
Parisian as you imagine it. So many cafes and shops put on your walking shoes and visit this area, shopping is expensive of course but fun to look
Loved this neighborhood. Was bustling when it needed to be, and quiet when it needed to be. We loved strolling around and trying different bars & restaurants.

Great neighborhood for shopping. Forget the Champs-Élysées and shop here. Many more shops and less people. They have all of the high end shops as well as the ones you can actually afford. Very nice area for cafes as well.
Great spot for food and drinks.... One of my favorite areas of Paris and near the metro there is shopping besides some of the best restaurants in Paris... take a walk and get lost walking around.
Intriguing area. We were walking to the Pantheon and strolled through this area. Wow we loved the cafés and the artiness of the area. And the people just seemed so relaxed. Can't wait to return
Left Bank Paris. There are lots of brasseries, restaurants, and shops. Also home to Julia Childs and Gertrude Stein. Easy walking.
loved it. architecture unbelievable,we had such a long walk to gallery laffayette,so much to see on the way.had coffees and wine on the way,many places to do that

Lovely place to walk around Paris at night and take in the friendly nightlife. This area was busy and full of interesting side streets. We loved walking around here in the evening, lots of people watching to enjoy, fine restaurants and tourist shops to look around in. This was our favourite area to walk around in and stop for a drink along the way.
great area. walk around, shopping and restaurants, perfect spot for a great days outing, also close to the river
Little Parisian Cafes. A really nice part of town to stroll and eat brunch. We ate at Le Deux Magots and it was very quiet and relaxed.

Fun neighborhood. Many great and unique boutiques mixed in with high-end stores and the usual American stuff (The Gap?! Skip it.) Sainte Sulpice is beautiful, the restaurants are great and you are in the heart of Paris.
One of the many gems of Paris. Always enjoy Paris and especially dining in the may great restaurants in St Germain district. People speak English and are friendly.
Wonderful Shopping District. Lovely small shops moderately priced of all kinds. Nice restaurants. Would like to return on my next trip.

It's All There!. So what is Paris? It's the Latin Quarter or Saint-Germain-des-Pres Quarter with all it's historical charm, landmarks and Parisian Ambiance. The Louve, the Siene River,Cathedral Notre Dame and several other major attractions are all in walking distance. Fine food and easy assess to the Metro, Bato Bus Boat and RER transportation make this an attractive area to stay in.
wonderful area to set up base. Near many famous sites and a short walking distance to many more. Well connected by metro/RER. Lovely, safe neighborhood. Loved exploring the little side streets.
quaint and atmospheric. Great for a relaxed stroll on a sunny afternoon Prepare to come home stuffed - great little cafes, restaurants and local food shops

vibrant and fun. We love discovering small streets with delightful shops. The whole village really comes to life in the late afternoon and evening with lots of cafes and bistros. A great place to explore.

We have stayed in and near here many times.. There is so much going on that unless you are totally disinterested in living, you would never get bored. Many shops, famous restaurants/bistros, sidewalk cafes, tourist destinations (e.g., the churches), and entertaining pedestrian traffic. We always stay in the 5th or 6th arrondisement for just this reason.

Boutiques and restaurants galore. Boutique shops and restaurants abound in this beautiful part of Paris. If there's anything unique you're looking for that you can only find in Paris, this is the place to go.

Great place to stay, to walk around, to fall in love with Paris. We chose to stay in this area and now I think it was the best decision. There are lots of cobbled footpaths, roads, designer shops, cafes, ancient churches, gardens and more. We used to wrap up the day's visits to museums and attractions by evening, and later just walk around the Saint Germain neighbourhood. It felt really safe and was absolutely beautiful. It is the more expensive part of town, but if you dont mind that, it is just perfect. There are more affordable places just a short walk away,

The best people watching in Paris. I like almost nothing more than to spend some hours parked in an outside seat at a Parisian bistro or brasserie watching the people go by. You will see the world in all it's diversity I promise you. The Cafe de Flore and Deux Magots are two of my favorites. They're pricey and the food struggles to justify the prices but no one will hurry you out of your seat and one has to love Parisian waiters for that at the very least.

Loved Saint-Germain-des-Pres!. Lots of cobbled streets with small designers and boutique shops to wander and get lost in… also close to the Latin Quarter so you can walk both quarters on the same day if you're keen to see a part of Parisian history that isn't locked up in a museum!
A design lovers paradise. The best shops imaginable, with great service. If you love antiques, dishes, furniture, fabrics, you're home free.
Strolling. Great place to walk around. Tons of places to shop. Restaurants and cafes galore. Food is wonderful. Great architecture. Lot of fun.
Must go. This is a must see! Take some time to stroke around all the shops and stop off for a coffee and watch the world go by!

Awesome. . This is the first time I've stayed in the St. Germaine area, and it's been fantastic. Loads of restaurants, shopping, commercial and/or boutique. Many things to see and just a great strolling area.

Cosmopolitan area with some great bars and shops . I've stayed in this area on previous visits to Paris and it's a good central location to stay and eat.Had a walk along the boulevard on this visit and it's still great to amble along, window shop ( bought one of my favourite art pieces here) and stop at the numerous cafes and play the Parisian. Walk along the side streets to the Seine or visit the Jardin du Luxembourg.I finished off in the Les Deux Magots. Ok it's a tourist trap but it sort of feels good to be sat where Camus, Hemjngway and Satre et al used to hang out, even if they wouldn't be seen dead in its present carnation!

Great Place to Visit. Excellent weekend destination for touristy stuff like visiting cafes, shopping and just soaking in French culture. Easy access to the Metro as well from here. We will visit here again.

Lots to do and see. Be picky. It's almost unfair to rate this as this area holds lots of interest. It's fun to walk around and window shop. I love to shoot photos, so between the store fronts (some of which are outstanding!) to the couple of ancient churches, (St. Germain, Sulpice, Cluny) you can visit those. If you like to walk along the river, (who doesn't?) there's that as well. And then Of course there's Jardin du Luxumbourg which is a DO NOT MISS. But save it for a day when there are blue skies. Get off your feet, get a chair or two, and rest! So yes, the area has cafes, people watching, lots of tourists, but get off the main drag and enjoy the sights & scents. DO NOT GO ANYWHERE WITHOUT A MAP. And bring strong glasses so you can read it, or pick up one of the great little paperback books divided into arrondissements with blow ups of each area, bus maps, a metro map, etc. the metro is great!

Trendy bars blended with old Paris. This is a great place to wander and take in the atmosphere of old and new, some lovely old style bars and restaurants for the Parisian feel blended with the younger vibe, architecturally beautiful buildings from the early days of the city.

Walking.. Walking through this area of Paris is as good as visiting a museum.Beautiful buildings abound in every street.Window shopping is an experience.you can buy everything from exquisite antiques to hand-made umbrellas and when you need refreshment the choice of bars and cafes is endless.

Great area. We lived in this part of Paris for 5 days and loved every minute of it. There are so many cafes and restaurants, it was hard to decide where to eat each night. Sitting outside at a café drinking coffee, and on one occasion, French champagne, was a wonderful experience. The waiting staff wherever we stopped were friendly and could always speak English. As well, public transport such as the Metro, Batobus or bus were easily accessible. The whole atmosphere in this area sums up Paris for me.
Cafe Life. This area is so full of cafes, wine bars and fine restaurants you could spend a lifetime here and never get bored with eat or drink. The nightlife, often until 5 am is friendly and lively.
Worthwhile to visit. If you are not staying in this area you will want to stroll through and absorb the feel of the neighborhood. Try a restaurant or do some shopping. It is worth your time
Hang out a little.. Have lunch, shop, just walk around. It's such a lovely neighborhood. Sit outside and have a coffee, pay the four Euros and be glad you've made it to Paris.

the best area to stay in Paris. The area has everything Restaurants ,Cafes, Shops close t the Luxembourg Gardens and lovely hotels we spent a week staying there with the metro close to hand you are only a metro ticket away from the whole of Paris. Famous cafes like café de Flore and Le Deux Magot make great place to unwind after sight seeing

Coolest Place to Hang Out. Being in Paris for the first time and not really knowing where to go; Our wonderful concierge Alan suggested the St Germain area. It was a long wonderful walk past the Louvre and Notre Dame. This neighborhood is full of cafes, restaurants and little shops. We sat at an outdoor table and watched Paris go by- how cool is that?? If you do go to St Germain, find a bookstore called Shakespeare and Company. It is a cool bookstore that was the haunts of famous writers. By all means - visit St Germain

Charming Parisian Neighborhood. St-Germain-des-Pre's is one of the more swanky, upscale neighborhoods in Paris. Situated along the Seine River, the area is also an artistic hub. It is here that you will find Jardin du Luxembourg and Musee d'Orsay. Tons of charming cafe's to choose from including Café Procope which is the city's oldest café. Perfect place to just take a stroll and see what you find!

Good Vibes in this part of town!. I love this area. It's cute, trendy, nice, relaxing, very neighborhood like. If I lived in Paris I would want to live here. Go find a cafe and sit outside to enjoy your surroundings.

One of my favorite areas of Paris. If you are a chocoholic, don't miss this area of Paris. There are 15 world class chocolatiers in Paris (see ChocoParis.com for self guided FREE tour details). There is also the oldest church in Paris (St. Germain des Pres Church) and Notre Dame. Plus we found that when we got out from the more touristy places like the Eiffel and the Arc we found better places to eat.

nice vibe. nice place to live in and pretend to be a Parisian. Easy access to subway,, easy walk to river and other attractions. We walked to the Louvre, Notre Dame, Luxembourg and of course the metro.

Perfect place to watch the world go by!. This is a perfect area for shopping and people watching at some of the fine cafes that line the streets. Our favorite eye glass designer is here, France's Klein, who has been making fashion eye wear for almost a hundred years. Handmade in France by the Klein family, their fashion forward frames are in custom colors, shapes and hand embellished. There are many similar shops that have one of a kind merchandise to enjoy.
Very tourist friendly area!. The personnel in restaurants and stores were friendly and welcoming to tourists and helped with French/English. Would highly recommend this quarter for visitors.
My favorite Paris Neighborhood. Charming, tree-lined streets, surrounded by classic French architecture. Got off during bus tour and walked for hours.

Love most of the St. Germain areas. We have stayed in the Saint Germain des Pres Quarter a number of times and love the feel of most of the area. There is much to explore. Lots of shops (many good chocolate shops.) We appreciate more of the residential side of things so find the areas around rue de Buci, Mazarine, Saint Andre' des Arts to be too hectic and filled with people for our taste. Our younger friends really like that vibe so reviews always depends on the travelers personal likes and dislikes.

The best bit of Paris!. The Saint Germain area is my favourite area of Paris. The area itself could occupy you for days with it's many sights, cafes etc but so many places (Louvre, Notre Dame, Jardin de Luxemburg) are within walking distance. There are a plethora of cafes and restaurants - keep your eye on the menu prices as basics such as breakfast can vary quite a bit in price from one place to the next. Enjoy!
Great area. This is a great area full of restaurants and shops and historical buildings. We had a great time exploring the area and sampling all of the local menus.

The Soho of Paris. Definitely one of my favorite areas in Paris. I love the quaint streets & cafes, which are super exciting for a literary geek like myself. Hemingway and the like sat at some of these very places! Great area for shopping. All of your favorite designers have a store here. I was really happy to come across a few surprises like the Karl Lagerfeld Store. I also had the best crepe of my life on Saint-Germain Boulevard. This quarter just has the perfect mix of trendy & homey vibes.

A must.. just walking around the area gives you a sense of belonging. the fruit and vegetables markets are just great and dont forget the bread I will never taste bread again as good as the french cook it.
Wonderful shops and restaurants. All the best designers in the world are located in this quaint setting. Restaurants and bakeries are fabulous too.
The place to be in happy hour.. After 6 PM, this is the place to be. Lots of bars, restaurants, bistrots. Beuatiful and happy people. Choose a place, sit and order wine, food. Enjoy your time there!

Pray visit!. This sixth Parisienne arrondissement is definitely worth a visit. I started my visit from the church- an apostle of grandeur and meditation. I was delighted by the cafe Deux Magots, frequented by Picasso and the surrealists. The entire place is steeped in history. The place vibrates!

A gem. This museum is always interesting with a special exhibition downstairs and many beautiful paintings, as well as purposebuilt rooms for Monet's Waterlilies. It is not well known that this museum opens at 9AM on a Sunday, and visiting at this time will be crowd free and very personal.

Heart of Literary Paris. For me, this was the biggest draw to Paris. To see where great writers and philosophers spent their time, the atmosphere that inspired them, and the coffee that fueled them. We loved walking down the winding side streets, window shopping, people watching, pastry tasting, wine sipping, church sampling, and walking in the rain. For me, it was the perfect introduction to Paris.

The only place to stay. Location location location. If you want fancy schmancy Paris, go to the Right Bank and stay at the Paris Hilton or Ritz.If you want to feel, smell, breath Paris...stay on the Left Bank and in particular the Ste Germain des Pres area. Tons of restaurants, bakeries, wine stores, flower shops, ambience to die for. Put on a scarf, pull up a chair at an out door cafe and just watch Paris go by.

Fabulous food and window shopping.. The best food of our trip is what we found in St. Germain (Polmard meats, chocolate at Un Dimanche a Paris, Acide Macaroon). Cute little streets to wander through and lots to look at everywhere (sidewalk cafes, shops, and food stores). I recommend booking a tour to help figure out what's worth trying- there's so much it'd be hard to sort it all out on your own. We used HiddenParis and were very happy with our guide.
Deux Magots. The mad adventures of Rabbi Jacob with Louis de Funes was shot here and it was fun to see it with my own eyes

Shopping, food, and sight seeing. I love this part of Paris. The buildings are beautiful, the streets seem more quaint. The shopping is terrific and the food here is diverse. What I like is the there are many places to eat, fresh farmers vegetables, bakeries, and cafés one after the other. We've walked all over Paris comparing food. There is one area in Montrmarte like this, but ALL of Saint Germaine area is like this. The antiques here are museum quality. If you people watch, you'll notice that there are few cameras hanging around necks, like other areas where tourists walk and tour buses dump crowds. Shopping and eating here is enjoyable without the throngs and hoards of pushy herded travelers.

Apartment with Paris Attitude. Hi everyone ! I rented an apartment in Saint Germain des Près with Paris Attitude Agency. My trip in Paris was wonderful, I really love this city ! Saint Germain des Près quarter is a very nice place to live. The apartment was wonderful, our sale advisor was very professionnal and helpul ! I recommend this agency to everyone who want to rent an apartment.

Another fantastic walking & watching area. Historical,charming, bustling - everything that is Paris. You can find the 'famous' cafes with high prices; you can settle in to many, more affordable options with the same character and observation points.

Stayed for five days. Sainte Germain is the perfect place to stay in Paris. Right between the Eiffle Tower and Notre Dame and the Ilse de Cite. Less than a mile and a half walk to virtually any point you might want to go. We stayed at The Signature StG and we were one block from The Bon Marche. So shopping? Ch-Yeah! Tons of cafes everywhere and less touristy than the Latin Qtr (IMO).
Great shopping & restaurants. Don't just go to Champs Elysee - This is a wonderful area to stroll around & see the plentiful boutiques & various restaurants.

Couple. Great place to walk around. Sip wine and people watch. Smaller crowded streets are better for walking than biking. Close to museums and shops. Very romantic if you are with the right person of course :)

A classic Parisian experience. Come wander the winding streets lined with high-end fashion shops, small boutiques, cafes of literary fame, book stores, purveyors of mouth-watering food-stuffs. Walk in the steps of Hemingway, Sartre, Picasso. Gaze at the 1,000 church, or better take in a free concert in it's stone belly. This old refuge of aristocrats who didn't want to chose between Paris and Versaille is still a joy to explore.

A great area to walk around and take in the atmosphere. This area is so quaint and I really enjoyed walking around taking in the atmosphere and the architecture. We were at Notre Dame and decided to check the area out which wasn't too far. It wasn't very touristy and not very busy when we were there. There are lots of places to choose from if you're looking for a cafe and restaurant. Next time we come to Paris we'd like to stay in this area.

Would pick it again!. Loved staying in this area, shops, restaurants and if you are a walker you can walk everywhere, Notre -Dame, le Louvre, Musee d'Orsay, even the Eiffel tower on a nice day. A great way to take it all in.

Couldn't be better. This neighborhood is perfect with its many small streets. It is ideal for walking around holding hands, doing a little window shopping, remarkable people watching, and incredible restaurants and patisseries.

best area in paris. so much to see and do- really well located for shops museums ,churches bistros. close to notre dame and the latin quarter and so colourful and stylish- a tree lined boulevard that leads to little shops and restaurants as well as the more up market- walk to les deux maggots and have a vodka sorbet- wow! if it is your first visit to paris stay in this area- you will not regret it

Loved this district. This is the arts district. I loved the african galleries, boutiques and shops here. This area seemed less touristy than the 1st arrondissement. Local Parisians live and est here. A great place to stay away from the crowd, if you don't mind walking to the major sites. Cafés on every corner. Try Cafe de Buci on Rue Dauphine. Great desserts (tart and cake ) and good service !
FABULOUS!!!!!. I loved this area. My hotel was located here. Toward the end of my trip I found the need not to go anywhere else. Shopping, food, sweets, art it's all here.

Good place to stay. This is a great area to stay. We spent 3 nights here. Ate at a different restaurant each night. All good and very reasonable. The shopping is also good and not expensive. I always stay in this area when in Paris.
Latin Quarter. had a great time waliking this area, Musee Cluny with Tapestries was breath taking, eat at Bouilly Racine on Rue de Racine great food less crowded

Saint-Germain - wonderful cafes in Paris. I highly recommend that you visit the Saint-Germain area of Paris. There is alot of history in this area and wonderful cafes - good for food, drink and people watching.

Superb window shopping and cafes on ever corner. Loved the variety of shops and the streets. Beautiful buildings and lots of art were everywhere. Stopped at Cafe Du Flore and enjoyed people watching. Dodged kids on scooters. Didnt like the narrow sidewalks, but there isnt much space here for man or vehicle, so wemt with the flow,

Great area. A very vibrant atmosphere at day and night. No shortage of cafes, restaurants, bars and plenty of boutique shops offering unique items. It pays to do some reconnaissance by day so you can get your bearings and then go back at night otherwise you can easily get lost in the myriad of small streets. The area feels very safe and there is something here for everybody.

the best area. I have fallen in love with this area of Paris. In my opinion it is the most characteristic and the best place to stay as it is near all important attractions and just a few metro stops away from the others. It is full of restaurants and lovely shops. The heart of traditional Paris

My favourite area in Paris. Loved walking the streets and admiring the architecture. So many good restaurants and sidewalk cafes with enjoyable window shopping as well. Very scenic and so many small nooks and crannies to explore. Many, many quaint little shops on busy and cobblestone side streets. It's relatively close to Notre Dame and the Isles but this is a veritable destination on its own. I would stay in this area when I return to Paris just because I love this area immensely.

Great for browsing the many bookshops. This is one of my favourite areas in Paris and you can while away many an hour just exploring the streets. Try and get off the main tourist area. There are lots on interesting bookshops/bric a brac to browse. It is an area of restaurants, good, bad and indifferent - choose wisely.

Lots of sights. We enjoyed spending a day wandering the various streets of the area. Whether you like to shop, are looking for food, want to view some art or just stroll to take in what Paris has to fear, you can find it here. Wear good walking shoes and bring a map.

Gorgeous Parisian streets. This part of town is really lovely! It has really great high end shopping, great cafe culture and a fun vibe. We came back a few times and found something new to explore each time.
Shoppers dream. So many chic and stunning shops. A must for designers labels. Plenty of restaurants and patisseries selling delicious fresh baked goods.
Nice area to stay in.. ...and a good base to do Paris from. Walking distance if you like or close by to the Metro... Also many nice smaller restaurants to choose from

Bohemian Rapsody. Wow, quaint area, with some of the finest shopping in all of Paris. Stopped by the Cucinelli Shop / Etro Shop / Emporio Armani Shop and found some terrific peices to take home. Do your homework before coming to this area because although most shops are on the main road, within a short walk there are plenty more

This is typical Paris life. Walking in Saint Germain des Pres is about touching Paris.There is a lot of activity from cafes everywhere and little shops.Parisians enjoy time in the cafes enjoying life.There are also some pedestrian streets full of little gems for shopping for food.You will find bakeries, fish markets, meat markets, pastry shops, mixed along with cafes and flower shops. Really enjoyable walk in this quarter.

Great location for solos. It can be noisy at night, but it feels active enough to feel safe alone. Some places can be overpriced, but it is fun, vibrant, and close to everything. What I didn't like was how far it was to find a bar with a beer that wasn't a blond or a Guinness.
Favorite Place. Just go to Saint-Germain and walk the street. Eat or just have cafe at Les Deux Magots - imagine yourself there with Hemingway!
What we think of as Paris. This lovely area of Paris is justifiably famous. Fabulous shops, leafy boulevards,tasty cafes. A great area to wander around in on a sunny afternoon.

Its Paris. Great area in Paris. Great cafe's, great stores and great time. Its what you expect from Paris. Small street just worth walking around and finding all kinds of cool stuff. I actually found a small book store all Nautical and high seas adventure and the women running it was exactly how you would imagine Fantastic!!

My Favorite Part of Paris. First visited in 1966 and have returned often because it is a genuine Left Bank neighborhood with history and spirit. The church of St Germain des Pres is like stepping back in time.
So Uptown. Do not miss Deux Margot. Has not lost its charm, and I thought reasonable for the ambiance. At least ONCE
Love this Neighborhood. Great food, wine, shops...just fun to walk around. We ended up eating here almost every morning and night and were very happy with our hotel.

Full of life de Paris. There cannot be a part of Paris more full of life than this.
We're old, but all of energy of this part of the city of lights kept us alive well past our normal bedtime.

Classy Place People Watching. This part of paris that is so classy and crowded. I like the famous shops Cafe Del Flore and Les Deux Magots. Nice to sit and sip Chocolat Chaud and Watch People passing by :D

ne of the oldest churches in Paris. This church,probably one of the oldest in Paris,is all that remains of a vast and very powerful Benedictine Abbey.The abbey buildings were destroyed during the Revolution of 1789.The church has the oldest belfry in Paris.Much of the church dates from the 11th century;inside it is incredibly peaceful,and a wonderful place to relax.The choir and tower are original,together with some beautiful stained glass.Outside are wonderful examples of flying buttresses.The ashes of the 17th century philosopher Rene Descartes are interred under a window in the second chapel.Nearby on the corner of the Boulevard Saint-Germain-des-Pres are the legendary literary cafes Cafe Flore and cafe Les Deux Magots.St-Germain is full of designer fashion shops,chic cafes and restaurants,and many tiny but elegant streets and squares.

Quintessenial Parisien neighborhood. You must stay in this area, if you can. It is full of wonderful reataurants, cafes, boulangeries, patisseries, and amazing chocolatiers. Plus there is great clothes shopping and convenient metro stations where you can connect to anywhere in the city. We walked every arrondisement and St. Germain captures the Parisien vibe.

must do area although very crowded. Fun area with lots to see. Many restaurants and food outlets. We found several great 3 course meals of classic French food for only 10€ each. Bought books and souvenirs. On one Sunday enjoyed a choir singing in the street.

Residential and Touristy at once. I rented an apartment right on Boulevard Saint Germain. I can tell when an area that as a lot of attractions is also residential by the amenities there: supermarket, bank, laundry, etc. This area is close to the Sorbonne, the Luxembourg Gardens and the Notre Dame as well as the immediate area near the Saint Michel train stop. Yet, despite that, it seems to be a lively area for locals: cafes, night spots, boutiques, etc. Although some of the restaurants seemed touristy looking, the food was actually good and authentic. We ate mostly in that area since we were staying there. we had a variety: crepes, seafood, cafe food for breakfast, etc. There is a street market right outside the Maubert-Mutualite stop (10 train) that makes the area charming. There were plenty of markets and wine shops for evenings in the apartment. Finally, this area abounds with public transportation, including the RER-B, which takes you to Charles de Gaulle airport. I would definitely stay in this area again.
A live. Nice shops good restaurants very alive Has been always like that And really ParisNice to walk around

Can't miss this even if you wish. OK, so it is touristy, full of kids looking for pleasures, noisy, crowded and you feel stupid at times if you are a sophisticated traveler... but, you have to at least visit and walk the area when in Paris.
Wish I'd had more time to explore. Stayed here but seemed to always be Seine bound. Wish I had spent a day exploring. Nice shopping and great food.
great neighborhood to wander. lots of beautiful buildings, sidewalk cafes, epitome of Paris! We spent many evenings at various cafes, watching the world go by!

The heart of Paris. We stayed in a hotel on rue Dauphine, and had plenty of time to walk around the area with its narrow streets, lovely shops, street musicians, great bookshops, cafés on the pavements, fantastic mix of people... delightful.
Great. Loved this quarter great atmosphere, wonderful restaurants and cafes. Recommend this quarter for all.
ambience rich romantic. the evnening is superb, a very very happening place, the restuarants are full with people hogging on to it

Lovely local neighborhood. We stayed in an apartment on rue de rennes and enjoyed the many shops, supermarkets, patisserie and cafes where you get a feel for how the locals live. There are many parks too for the children. A great little area.

A Bustling Shopping and Dining Area. It is fun to walk this shop-filled area, as well as visit St. Germain des Pres and St. Sulpice. As one walks further away from the Seine, the area seems to become an attractive neighborhood of apartments.
Fun neighborhood. Lots of walking quaint little shops..can walk along la Seine ..lots of restaurants and the Pantheon of course
Best neighborhood in Paris. Convenient to everywhere with smorgasbord of choices for all kinds of tastes. A really fun place to stay or go in Paris. Hemingway did it.
Too crowded. Don't like the crowds, there are no notable sights and the so=-called great restaurants of the past stopped being great a long time ago

No longer. Il n'y a plus d'apèrs à Saint-Germain des Prés. The Latin quarter is no longer. Students, professors, universities, and, chiefly, publishing houses have gone, replaced by clothes and fashion shops.

Charming Neighbourhood. We've missed this area on our other visits to Paris, so we spent a full day here this time. Quieter than some of the other neighbourhoods in the city with some wonderful restaurants and the nearby Shakespeare and Company book store, which is well worth a visit.
EPIC! Great atmosphere. I ate lunch at Le Deux Margots.. it was great.. expensive but great...walk around and just soak it up.

getting too gentrified. Highly valued neighbourhood with more and more riches make the quartier loose its memorable ambiance. The drugstore disappeared the first two decades ago in favor of Emporia Armani, but so followed numerous typical adresses, like the famous late nite opened library "La Hune", now converted into a cold Louis Vuitton exhibition store between Le Flore and Les deux Magots. Arny's, the famous french politicians clothier changed for Berluti, and the legendary Lutecia hotel is now closed for a total revampement. Luckily there is still Lipp Brasserie, the Montana club and the recently re-opened Castel. Let's hope life comes back soon.
Best area to stay. We stay in this area and is so worth it! You have a lot of movement because of the university being there. Lots of places to eat, hang out and shop.
Lost its flair. It was terribly crowded over Easter, and some of the shops and cafes looked like tourist traps. The old quarter I remembered from 20 years ago had mostly vanished.
Lovely area to look around. A place to wander and browse the shops and stop and people watch at one of the many cafés and restaurants
Stayed in St Germain. The left bank is a beautiful historic area and well worth visiting. Restaurants and cafes abound as well as art galleries and markets.

favorite walking area. walk around, window shop, stop for "un cafe" (BTW, that's an espresso, not a cup of coffee. if you want a coffee you have to ask for an "american") get lunch. look up, take pictures. You're in Paris.
A little bit of everything. Saint Germaine quarter is a must visit. The little shops and wonderful cafés will please everyone. Whatever you are looking for, you will for sure fine it there.
great church. really enjoyed the mass, even though we didn't understand what was being said, the music was beautiful.
Such friendly Parisiens. This quarter of Paris is my favourite. So many bookstores, antiques, cafes, restaurants, boutiques and florists. I could definately move here.

Probably my fav place in Paris. so many beautiful historical buildings in this area. you can spend days there wandering and not getting tired of it. every corner you turn, there will be some wow moments. Filled with history and great architecture.

Saint-Germain is the Heart of Left Bank Paris. Whenever I am in Paris, as a visitor or France travel writer, I usually find myself wandering through Saint-Germain-des-Pres. This area is basically the Left Bank middle ground between the Latin Quarter/Sorbonne on the east and the Eiffel Tower on the west. It's a great locale to visit churches, art galleries, boutiques, and famous cafes like Les Deux Magots were Hemingway huddled with other passionate writers. It's accessible from many metro stops. And you can walk here from Notre Dame on the banks of the Seine. If you wander through the streets between Boulevard Saint-Germain and the Seine you can view ancient Paris--the winding atmospheric little byways where Victor Hugo may have meandered as he pondered his characters for Les Miserables. It's also a marvelous place for people watching and mixing with "real life" Paris.

Nice neighborhood. Interesting Church.. Expensive and pretentious stores, but a nice area for a walk nonetheless. I popped into the church, Pay attention to the outside mural, and have a crepe in the corner.

the Paris you envision. This neighborhood cannot be beat for people watching, cafe lounging and high end shopping. Despite the cliché of Les Deux Magots, we enjoyed a leisurely meal our last night in Paris. Great to people watch and our kind waiter made it enjoyable.

Lively area, close to all the main tourist attractions. Ideal base to start a Paris must see day tour. Breakfast in rue du buci, walk to Norte dame, than louvre, lunch at rue de Benoit, than orsay, and eventuallly enjoy your dinner around rue mabillion. If you love losing yourself in cities and discover by walking

It's old. Old is good.. Evidently this is the oldest standing church (and building?) in Paris,. It sits on busy urban streets in the Latin Quarter. Inside, it's a serene and peaceful break from the busy streets outside. I visited on a Friday morning in April, and was treated to music from the church's wonderful pipe organ, which blasted throughout the open space of the church.I was there at around 11am on a Friday. The crowd was not large, and there was plenty of room to move about, sit, and meditate. This place is near to many other attractions, and is a no-brainer half-hour visit while you're in the neighborhood.One note. It's free to enter and look around, but they are asking for donations for restoration of the building. Do your part to help preserve this wonderful piece of Parisian history and drop some Euros in the box!

the Latin quarter. We really enjoyed this section of the old city as there are many sidewalk cafes. The side streets are narrow pedestrian streets with restaurants, shops and atmosphere. The smells of the meat cooking on spits, and the smell of bread is wonderful. Explore and enjoy.

Such a fantastic place for a nightly walk. If you have the strength to walk around in the night after a tiresome sightseeing day in Paris, be sure to do it here. The shops are open until late night and you are surrounded by lovely cafes, nice restaurants and secret bars. This is a unique place to be.
fabulous restaurants. beef bourgignon was delicious at Le Bistrot D'Henri, the area is fantastic for shopping and eating, we will definitely be back

The real paris. If you want to really enjoy the real Paris experience you should head to or even better stay in the area SAINT GERMAIN DES PRES QUARTER,and give the LATIN QUARTER a miss,as good as that area is ,it cannot touch this part of Paris.Great hotel's,fantastic shop's but what makes's this area so truely Parisian is the amazing nightlife,superb restaurant's,bar's and cafe's abound in this quarter.Cafe de flore,cafe Laurent,cafe de magillon and the surreal but wonderful ,cave au des legends,to name but a few of the many fabulous establishment's you can see the local's letting their hair down.The architecture around here is unbelievable,if you enjoy taking photograghs don't forget the snapper.Great area,great shop's and superb nightlife,an area to really enjoy.
A quaint little place. I love the cafes in this quartier and the quaint little streets. I like exploring in this area. This area can be very crowded and touristy, too.

A must to visit or stay. Good hotels, shopping and eateries. I try to stay in this area every time I visit Paris. The Trios Maggots is one of the best places to people watch made famous by Picasso, Sarte, Hemmingway and Oscar Wilde.

A True Parisian Stroll. This area is perfect for a stroll or just to get lost and wander. I prefer to stay in this area for it's authentic flair. The Boulevard is full of shops and well known cafes but just go off the beaten track and enjoy!

Loved this area!. St. Germain is a fun area with lots of restaurants and shops, and is in the center of everything on a traveler's list of must-sees. I enjoyed that it was on the Seine near the vendors. Nothing seems rushed. The metro stations are easy to find, as are taxi stands. If you are staying the night in this area be sure you ask for a room off the main streets as it can get a bit noisy at night!

Saint-Germain-des-Pres Quarter is a Favorite!. Loved to window shop here and spend time at the Church with its beautiful vaulted ceiling. I was lucky to hear the organ music on my visit last week. Many little cafes to enjoy a latte.
Always fun. Always coming back there because of the good food, the attractive and well dressed people and the cool vibe.
Variety of shops and restaurants. Such choices! Something for everyone, and friendly assistants everywhere. Many speak English if you don't have any French.

A section of Paris that is where you can experiece. The life of the Persian lifestyle. This is what Paris is and here you will see what Paris is all about the every day hustle and bustle and yet the people that make up this vibrant city.,
Great place to wander. Great place to wander and have lunch. Lots of people watching and good food not intended for the tourist traffic.
Great stop. We wandered here by accident and it was great. Ate at Le square which was excellent! Also great service. It was a bit crowded near musee d'orsay would be only dislike.

My favorite neighborhood. if you are an art lover, this is the neighborhood for you! so much energy in this area and the cafe is bustling with conversation and life. I will always come back here just to browse the art galleries and the people.

Cafes, people, markets!. This is the real part of Paris. Latin Quarter (as I recall, so named because many students at the university hundreds of years ago spoke or were Latin). So many cafes to people watch, eat, and drink coffee.
Markets all over. You can walk to most of the major Paris sites (or the Metro is always close at hand).

Visit because it is famous. There is so much to see and do, that it would be difficult to list everything here. The Cluny museum is a must see. So much shopping, sight seeing, walking, music, and etc.

Fun to wander and shop!. Latin Quarter has legendary status as a bohemian artist writer hang out. But it seems more like a cute shopping area with some good creperies. I picked up almost all of my little presents for people in this area. I really enjoyed it here.

The real Paris !!. Looking for cafes , open air markets and lively streets ? One of our favorite areas in Paris from here you can walk to all major sites visit Cafe de Paris on any night to see the lively street life on Rue de buci
Great Location. You can find most anything you are looking for in the Saint-Germain-Pres quarter - sightseeing, entertainment, food and shopping.

Cute. Go to Les Deus Magots (Brasserie Lipp stinks). This is a cute place in Paris and worth the visit to go to and stroll around, have a coffee and take in the ambiance. Many good places to eat (as in all of Paris) but some really fabulous ones as well

Great finds!. This area is ideal for walking, shopping (many shops open on Sunday, like the Champs but with much better stores) investigating small museums and other art attractions (Pantheon, Dubuffet Studio/Museum, etc.). Even Starbucks (Odeon stop) beckons for those seeking familiar beverage stops.
One of the most charming parts of Paris. Full of great boutiques, even better patisserie creations with the best master bakers. Historic bars and restaurants ....

This was our homebase for our vist, best choice ever!. After much research my daughter choose this area and I am glad she did. I felt like a Parisian. We stayed at and AIRBNB on Rue Mazarine. It was lively during the day and at night. You always felt safe. The was plenty of Cafes and shops. It was so close to Notre Dam and the Louvre and the River Siene. Charming. I will always stay here when I visit Paris.

Quiet atmosphere! The most attracting area in Paris. Walk across the bridge above River Seine from Louvre, you can feel that this area is totally different from the other side! Not so many tourists, not so many crowded people. The only feeling you will get here is relaxing! Don't hesitate! Come to enjoy the relaxing Paris

Great for restaurants and shopping. Make sure you hit the area around Rue de Buci for restaaurants and great atmosphere. The area around St. Germain de Pres is nice for shopping and people watching at the cafes. There are a number of great hotels in the area too. I like to use this arrondissement as home base when I'm in Paris.

Don't Miss this little slice of heaven. Yes it is a small area, but OH SO French....if you want to see "movie" Paris walk around this spot. Stop in the little stores, have something at the famous cafe's....To me THIS is Paris!
True Parisian. Get away from the touristy Paris, and enjoy the taste of areas frequented by Parisians. Enjoy the hustle and bustle of local shopping and eating out on the numerous sidewalk cafes.

Wonderful Neighborhood. Many highlights to this great neighborhood, like La Petite Chaise Restaurant, which is the oldest in the city, or Les Deux Magots, frequented by Hemingway back in the day, or shopping on the Boulevard St. Germain, or Le Bilboquet for jazz or outdoor markets or wine shops or great ice cream. All you want is within your grasp

The Hipster Corner of Paris. Well, here you have the best cafes and shops nearby! You are going to be comfortable with Les Deux Magot cafe for breakfast and lunch...if need be..and the one street behind has a lovely Japanese restaurant that is so delicious! Great boutiques, kids shops and hotels.I also make a little trek from here to Le Bon Marche department store to squeeze in a perfect "one stop shopping."When you want to be comfortable and walking distance to everything w/ a very Parisian experience...this quarter is for you!
Oh la la. The Saint-Germain-des Pres Quartier is ideal to walk around leisurely and enjoy the small shops and restaurants. Especially the seafood restos are a delight to have lunch.

Always an exciting place to be. Walk the streets of this district, especially the major street. PSG. The people watching is the best here, and the scenes of Parisian life are everywhere. You can envision Hemingway hanging out here.

Stunning, artisan and chic. We spent the weekend in Paris after a week of exhibiting at the Port de Versailles.
We staying in St German and had a wonderful time with our wives.
We spend two days walking around a variety of attractions, shops and eat in some wonderful cafes and restaurants.
We will be back, very very soon.
Great Vibe, Nice Shops. We stayed at Hotel La Perle (great hotel!) in the Saint Germain de Pres quarter and loved it. Great little restaurants, cafes, shops and bars and such a nice atmosphere!
So much to see. I was torn between sitting in a cafe and watching the folks go by or walking and checking out all of the folks sitting in cafes. Tons of fun and beauty. You cannot go wrong.

Lovely buzzing area with a chilled vibe. Nice mix of independent and chain shops, bars, restaurants and pretty French buildings. Well connected with several metro stations. Lovely buzzing vibe in the daytime and very chilled in the evening. Just a short stroll to Notre Dame/Ile de la Cite/St Michel/Chatelet. We'd definitely stay there again as it was a great base.

Central Location. If I ever got to live in Paris -- this would be the neighborhood. It is easy walking distance to the Eiffel Tower, Notre Dame, Gran and Petite Palais, funky shops next to high fashion. It also has great bistros, markets, and served by bus and metros.

Trendy, chic, wonderful. Loved this part of town! It is trendy with lots of buzz and great, amazing restaurants, shops and bars. Locals say this area has been commercialised and is very touristy. That said, I think many local Parisians still do spend time here and that's nice. It is close to the Latin Quarter which is certainly where the tourists flock too, and not my preference but St Germain des Pres is lively and vibrant without being a tourist trap. I would consider staying in the area on my next visit.

Too cool. Very trendy. Very chic. Very bohemian.I love this place at night. Back streets light up with a random assortment of bars and bistros.A lot of French people go here which is always a good indication of quality.

lovely area. many shops and cfe add to an aftrnoon's njoyment of thi hitoric area Forget finding the andlmaker to king It's totlly modren & could b in an US mall. Very disappointing after searching for over an hour to find it i took my sore feet to a cafe and continued to enjoy Paris.

At night .. This is the place . When the sun goes down ,, I suggest you go to this place A lot of coffee hopes and Resturant with French style. Also don't miss to go to the back street it is nice and cool areas to walkYou can use the metro or the buses or taxi to get thereYou will see also A lot of shops in the day time which is a great area for shopping too ...
This is Paris!. What a lovely area this is. Quirky side streets, cobbled paths, paveside cafes, just to sit in the Paris sunshine here and admire the wonderful architecture is fab.

In the Sixth. Well Saint Germain is Saint Germain - boho before boho and just very cool.
Also has Cafe des Flores, and its rival opposite, both teeming with stars, wannabees, artists, dreamers.....
Super boutiques and lovely houses, and boutique hotels.
Great all round. Gotta be rich though.....
A Taste of Paris. My husband and I loved this area of Paris as we literally felt like we were "home." The pace of the locals was both energetic and relaxed simultaneously.

Wish I was thinner and had more money to spend!. Amazing, unusual clothes shops - just wish I could have spent more time there. My daughter loved it and the area was busy and interesting. Fantastic interior design shops.

Very chic shopping. This is a lovely place to window shop on a Saturday morning and enjoy a coffee whilst people watching. Some posh, quirky and interesting shops, good eateries and historic cafés. Also my favourite church in Paris is here.

Our favorite Paris neighborhood. Wonderful Paris neighborhood to just be a Parisian. Whether you rent an apartment or stay in a small hotel, you can enjoy the area's many restaurants and bistros. Several convenient Metro stops so getting around Paris is very easy from St. Germain.
Great Neighboorhood. This is a great neighborhood with wonderful shops and restaurants. It is totally safe to walk at night.

famous district, famous cafe. the crowd is amazing, the cafe are full of history, cafe de flore, aux deux magots are a must on your journey on the rive gauche. beers from all over the earth @ pub st germain, rue de l'ancienne comedie, next from the oldest restaurant in paris, le procope

One of the nicest quarter of Paris.. If you have more days in Paris, just for walk around, don't miss to walk in this historic quarter, full of small passage, streets, churches and little squares, and world famous buildings like the Musee d'Orsay or the Luxembourg Gardens and the campus buildings of Sorbonne.

Five-star just for nostalgie.... I miss the old days where there were lots of bookstores, model airplane shops, nice little restaurants...Now it's all the same, Louis Vuitton, Christian Dior, etc...Even Fragonard has a branch...At least there is an Assouline bookstore...but headquartered in NYC...Comme Juliette Greco a déploré:Il n´y a plus d´aprèsA Saint-Germain-des-PrésPlus d´après-demainPlus d´après-midiIl n´y a qu´aujourd´huiTu me dis "Comme tout change!"Les rues te semblent étrangesMême les cafés-crèmeN´ont plus le goût qu´tu aimes
Street cafes, ice creams, macaroons. Big tourist spot, but we also people watched so many locals! The food is consistently good, the neverending street flow is the draw.
A must for an evening!. This is a lively area with plenty nice restaurants and bars, a truly Parisian neighborhood. If you are short on time head to Carrefour de Buci
cafes, restaurantsand shops. this are has lots of cafes and small shops we visited it after our visit to Notre dame and it was a changes from the champs-Elysses where we stayed.

We loved our little neighborhood. We stayed at the Citadines Apart'hotel, Saint-Germain des Pres, Paris. While there, we shopped the stores -- including the grocery stores, we stopped in for coffee and croissants every morning, and were able to walk to many of the storied places of Paris. For all of our other touring, the Metro, RER, busses, etc., were all within a short walk. Oh yes, don't forget Michelin Star restaurants right around the corner. Ze Kitchen Galerie needs to have more than one star! It sparkles!

Friendly, diverse and interesting area. Lots of restaurants, shops and although very central, feels a lot more like Paris proper. Very walkable and lots of small hotels. We liked the atmosphere very much.

Chic, charming and delicious. This wonderful neighborhood has the perfect combination of great cafes and restaurants, fantastic shopping and window shopping and proximity to the louvre and the d'orsay.

FAVORITE AREA OF PARIS!!!. Saint-Germain-des-Prés is an area of the 6th arrondissement of Paris, located around the church of Saint-Germain-des-Prés.Famous cafés, such as Les Deux Magots and Café de Flore,restaurants like Le Procope, Josephine Bakery and Laduree and boutiques all in the heart of the art gallery and antique district!!!! The beautiful Luxembourg gardens.and the fun and special Rue Jacob are the" cherry on top "My favorite hotel, Hotel Danube is on Rue Jacob. As well as great boutiques that give rue Jacob gives a truly Parisian "feel".

Exclusive high end shopping. For some people the streets around Saint-Germain are very appealing. The buildings are typically Parisian and the cafés of the highest quality. The best are located on the square in front of Saint Germain de Pres Church.Of course all of this doesn't come cheap. The shops are disappointing and prohibitively expensive. All the big fashion labels you can see anywhere in the world, line Boulevard Saint-Germain. There is Louis Vuitton, Ralph Lauren, Armani and many others. If you like bohemian Paris, this is not the place to come.

Paris in one road.. A very typical Paris area. Full of interesting and stylish shops, restaurants and cinemas. There really is a 'buzz' in this area which is full of tourists. A good place to take a walk and take in the atmosphere.

It's brilliant. we always stay in this area when visiting Paris, it has a great selection of bars and bistros, boutique shops, designer shops and is easy to walk almost any where, we have walked to niotre dame approx 10 mins, Eiffel tower approx 35 mins , Chaps Élysées approx 35 mins , good metro links and some lovely markets too

Great Shopping and nice resturants. This is a great place for some shopping and walking around. There are MANY restaurants in the area. If you are in Paris, spend an afternoon or evening and enjoy the walk through the St Germain area.
The heart of Paris. Sain Germain des Pres is the most typical parisian quarter, you cannot miss it! The atmosphere is very romantic, the view of the buildings is astonishing!
Congested,noisy but wonderful !. Love strolling this area, especially the markets of Maubert and the wonderful Parisienne Patisserie shop.

Stay here and explore. Saint Germain des Pres is an ideal place to stay, eat, explore, and shop. The architecture is stunning, the shop interiors are top-notch, and there are plenty of quaint little restaurants to grab a bite!

Favorite walking area. You simply fall in love with buildings, architecture and the pace. People are very artsy there, but you can easily find calmer streets if you are not up for crowds. I always take a route that begins at St Chapelle metro through narrow streets parallel to Seine. Often I grab a bite of crepe form the street (nice bite if you don't want to waste too much time eating in). I move towards Place de Concorde, cross the bridge near Louvre and walk through Jardin deTuilleries. It's a nice 1.5 hour walk which reveals many attractive places. You can also start from Notre-Dame and do the same but add extra hour, since you're most likely to visit the cathedral itself

Favorite. This neighborhood is one that you just wander around and enjoy. Each time I go back to Paris I explore this neighborhood more, Most beautiful walks in the world. Talk a stroll, find a cafe and you are in heaven.
Sit in a bistrot and watch people pass by!. Find a bistrot in happy hour time. There's hundreds! Sit and ask for a bottle of wine and cheese table! No hurry! It's one of the best pleasures in life!

Saint Germain. This the area that we always stay. Easy for transportation. Very safe area. Several beautiful cathedrals to visit. Many well known and also local places to eat..Great to window shop at he high end shops and also several street markets were the locals to their shopping.

If you like art and nightlife. We always stay in this quarter next to the Seine. You may walk around and see dozens of art galleries and restaurants. Also in a walking distance to Notre Dame, Le Louvre, and even if you dare to the Champs Elysées.
Eat and Shop. Best area we found for shopping and eating. High quality places for both. We were never disappointed and were not constantly being harassed by people begging, etc in this area of Paris.

Best place to stay. Our apartment was between St. Germain and St. Michel, so there were plenty of restaurants and supermarkets to chose from. The set menu for 12 Euros 90 was amazing. I must go on a diet now
Amazing area!!. The best place to be in Paris, a great ambience on the streets, full of bookshops and nice cafes. A place to go and spend several hours
Brilliant area. Great vegan restaurant found here and loads of bookshops. Usual tourist shops too selling tat. Good for a walk around and easy from Notredame.
Celebrating a 1000 year anniversary!. Wonderful old cathedral in a trendy (as in designer shops) neighbourhood. It is beautiful inside and therefore worth a visit.

My favourite district in Paris. I love the saint-germain area. Lots of amazing boutique hotels, beautiful architecture and churches. Very easy to walk around. Lovely boutiques and chocolates shops - Patrick Roger being a particular call out. Great restaurants inc Michelin star Le Restaurant in L'Hotel. The cherry on the cake is Le Bon Marche, the best department store in Paris. Saint-Germain is my home from home, I go at least 6 times a year
Great area of town. This is just a cool area of town with a lot of shops, restaurants, cafes and such. Good area to stay, along with the Latin Quarter.

DIsappointing.. Having not been back to St Germain shopping for nearly ten years I was very disappointed about the lack of individual boutiques and so many major chain outlets one after another. I was over H & M, Gap and Zara and wanted something individual.

Interesting ad different pace to see. Whenever you go to Paris usually you go to the same places. Saint Germain is a different pace to go. There are very high end shps like Thw Bon Marche, Churches like Saint German des Pres, close to La Sorbone, the university, close to Montparnase, many restaurants, stores nice ambiance.
Great area. Great area to stroll through. See cafe deux magots, great parisian restaurant, and other historic places where picasso, hemingway and others also lived and visited.

Posh Saint Germain!. I felt underdressed during my visit! It would not have surprised me to find expensive designers being worn by the chic French particularly in that area. The beautiful houses are stunning and very picturesque!

The Soul of the Left Bank. No doubt the immortals are tormented by the gentrification of this neighborhood; but it still has something for everyone. The greatest cafes of Western Civilization: Cafe de Flore, Les Deux Magots and Cafe Lipp; designer stores and elegant boutiques that would exhaust the greatest Diva; and culinary treasures that will make you beg for mercy. It is almost too much! See it, feel it and live it. Its the place where Parisians want to see and be seen.

Like all of Paris: hectic. Paris is crowded and hectic. If you are not used to it, you can feel bullied and abused. Get a sandwich, and try to find a nice park and feed the pigeons. The shops aren't interesting and the waiters are rude.

Beautiful Paris walk. Just walk there and you will enjoy Paris as you should....
The Book stores are amazing, and also most cafe are very friendly and welcoming.

my favorit area to stay in paris. from the first time I came to paris, long ago I alvays stay in this part of the town because of the cinemas, boutiques of all kinds and libraries and shops ofering news or second hands books and other stuff. Also a lot of cafes and small restaurants of divers kinds of food and drinks.

Interesting area to visit. Place St Germain is a n interesting area to visit, beautiful church,you have the most important Cafe des Flores, and aux deuce Magots,this is where Ben Barka was kidnapped.Brasserie Lipp,most famous brasserie where all intellectuals,politicians go.
A nice area for shopping

Beautiful area, avoid the pricey tourist traps. So many bakeries, shops and cafes - one of my favourite areas in Paris. Just steer clear of the pricey tourist traps. Would be the best area to sip hot chocolate and people watch for a few hours.

Classy district. Pleasant walk along one of the most beautiful districts of the city, Saint Germain-des-pres-quarters is undoubtedly an elegant and wealthy where you can enjoy a good French cafe in one of the many cafes. A short distance from the most famous landmarks and tourist attractions of the city. It is worth visiting it.

Best Place to Be. Saint Germain des Prés has the most charming neighbourhood. The main street, Boulevard Saint Germain, has many trees and is on the Rive Gouche. There you can see many different cafés and shops as well as two of the most famous - Cafe de Flore and Les Deux Magots! Small charming hotels can be found and the local parisiens can be seen on the streets because many of them live there. Street fairs, small markets and libraries are also in the neighbourhood that is charming and cosmopolite at the same time.
