There are many restaurants that keep opened till late and many parisiens stay at the cafés drinking their last night cup, making the old saying "Paris is a party", true!

A very friendly place to stay in Saint Germain. There is very little that I can add to the previous reviews about this Hotel.It is very friendly and accommodating having stayed here many times in the past year or two.Highly recommended by me from experience if you want to stay in this part of Paris close to the restaurants around the Gardens of Luxemburg the Notre Dame, Pont Neurf and the Muses Dorsey famous for its Picture Gallery and Station Master's Office now a Restaurant and the picture of the train through the wall.
Loved it!. Enjoyed to walk around in this area, one thing you should do when here is visiting the church. It's also in need of renovation, but has free WiFi!

Quaint and Lively. We stayed at the Hotel de Buci located in this quarter and it turned out great. So many wonderful restaurants to choose from, shopping and close to the Metro. Very safe area, some street vendors near the exclusive shops, outdoor markets, bakeries, patisseries, etc. We'd definitely stay in this area again!
Great for designer shopping.. You have to be in the money to buy anything on this street, but great for window shopping. Some lovely wee boutiques off some of the side streets worth a look.

Fabulous mooching. This is my favourite area of Paris.
Its a little bohemian, with lovely independent shops, some great restaurants & very easy to just wander round the back streets for hours.
so special. strolling window shopping hunting rare products sitting in cafe flore or brasserie leap crossing French artists writers int personalities;
Quirky and cool area. Full of shops, restaurants and cafe' this area is definitley what you are looking for as nice break from all the great museums and monuments that Paris can offer.

over rated. It has become a tourist trap, even the Parisians do NOT go any more.The cafes charges prices which are just plain stupid. The "fashion shops" look like the ones you find in any China town around the world. No Go

One of the chic places to go in Paris. Historical coffee, luxury shopping in the streets, one of the best places to eat pastry and chocolates (rue de Seine) in Paris.
Things are chic and trendy and consequently expensive. It one of numérous parisian faces

Walk and enjoy!. Beautiful old buildings and fab designer shops, great cafes and restaurants, spend some time at the church itself - St Germain des Pres; enter the grounds from the Bvd St Germain and look at the huge tiled wall - Sevres. Keep walking and you come to the Bvd St Michel and head off to the right and you're at Les Jardins Luxembourg - a street map is a must!

Best location in the city!. Wonderful shopping, cafe's, and central location to museums. Enjoyed narrow streets as well as Boulevard de Saint-Germain. We expected to use public transportation more but enjoyed walking to the Notre Dame, Louvre, and even the Arc de Triomphe and Eiffel Tower (20-30 min). We had excellent weather New Year's week.

Great Cafe Walking Tour. We took a cafe walking tour of St. Germain des Pres on Christmas Day culminating with brunch at Cafe de Flore. Although it was relatively quiet with some shops closed for the Holiday, the walking tour was well worth it - plenty of architecturally interesting buildings, nice coffee shops for people warching and some seafood stores with wonderful displays of oysters, mussels, etc.
A busy, nice neighbourhood. It was particularly nice at Christmas time, nicely lit up and some streets had rows of stalls set up with food, wine, and crafts

Excellent!. This is my favourite quartier in Paris. I lived here for 2 years on Rue Dauphine. A trendy, chic and lively area - the 6th is sophisticated Paris at it's best. Restaurants, jazz clubs, cafes, boutique hotels, art galleries, and so on. Lovely green spaces, hidden treasures and an awesome ambience. Highly recommended!

We stayed in Saint Germain. Loved it. Great restraurants, close to all the main attractions you want to see. Right at Odean station for the Metro so easy to get around. Not to far from Notre Dame and St Michael where there are plenty more restaurants for eating.
A wonderful place. Great place / fabulous although pricey cafes / great shops and a wonderful Parisienne ambience - fantastic for a stroll
Great Pedestrian Area. Best stores for shopping along with great food, drink and Entertainment.Site of many beautiful Churches interspersed with shoppes and nightlife

Chic. We spent 5 days in Paris in November and rented an apartment in this area. It was a fantastic choice , it is very well located to allow you to walk to a lot of "must sees" in Paris. The area has a lot of nice restaurants and shops and feels very safe at night , would certainly choose this area when returning to Paris.

Up scale neighborhood, with great bistros and shops. You can wander this area and not spend anything. Just window shopping and people watching, you can while away and entire warm sunny Paris afternoon.This area is where you will buy your pan, fromage and wine for your picnic lunch or afternoon in the Gardens of the Palais de Luxembourg, which is a short stroll to the West.There is also lots of interesting architecture to look at,

Perhaps best neighborhood in Paris. I wandered this area on a Thursday evening & many art galleries were having openings. It was a perfect introduction to the Rive Gauche. The medieval side of Paris has a more intimate scale with narrow, winding streets; plus, ample bookstores & other retail browsing opportunities. If only I could afford the rent...

Stunning area to walk around. Some of the quaintest streets & cafes in Paris. We ate at Les Deux Magots, just because the name tickled our fancy. Ernest Hemingway frequented this cafe. Typical Parisian cafe but great for people watching.

Very nice quarter with lots of small shops and a market hall. I very much enjoy this part of Paris, just south of the Ile de la Cité, with its high number of shops, cafés and restaurants. Very enjoyable to stroll along and enjoy Paris the way most people have it in their minds. There is also a market hall, but I do not find it too impressing. Preferably walk along the boulevards and the small side streets. You will find a lot of little places to stop and have a closer look.
What fun. Cafes, shops and general fun. Great place for walking, having a coffee, having a drink, a snack, and just enjoy the scenery while strolling along beautiful streets

Take a walk. this is a lovely street to promenade don't be put off by a rude waiter if you stop for coffee. Many interesting sites Bon Marche a large department store and lots of other shops just remember to say bonjour when you go in. Check out Hermes store amazing Art Deco ex swimming pool with an entrance smelling of flowers. Great chocolate stops and a boulangerie recognised as one of the best in Paris.
Place to be. This is the hot neighbourhood. Lots of quint boutiques. Nice suroundings. Just to stroll around. Nice chocolateries with reasonable prices
Love this part of Paris. Great shops, dining and architecture all around you. You have to walk the entire quarter and experience Parisian life.

A wonderful stroll. This was my first visit to Saint Germain. In fact, I stumbled upon the quarter on my way to the Musee du Luxembourg.It's a delight to window shop, people watch, take pictures, and see the latest fashion. There were marvelous window displays in the stores. One of these displays, in a stationery shop, prompted me to duck in and sort through antique prints. Further down the street, I shopped for souvenirs and greeting cards at another little store.If you're in this neighborhood, take a few minutes to visit Ste. Sulpice church -- or at least the fountain and plaza in front of the church. The rococo architecture of the fountain lends itself to photography, especially if you capture an image of a pigeon perching on some of the statuary.

Mass at St. Germain-des-Pres. We wanted to visit the Left Bank. Even though we are not Catholic, we attended Mass at the church of St. Germaine-des-Pres. The service was in French, but we could follow the order of service and we felt that we had a meaningful worship experience. The church is the oldest in Paris so it is historically significant. The we spent the rest of Sunday morning walking around the district.
Beautiful neighborhood. We stayed in Saint-Germain on the left bank this trip and will only stay there in the future! Wonderful cafes, less crowds and superb shopping.

Upmarket and fun. Great to wander and shop. The street markets have some lovely pieces of jewellery and cashmere. Get off the main street all the best experiences are in the side streets and lane ways including one shop with original autographed pieces by famous writers. Also visit Rue Mouffarde - wonderful delis and restaurants
The Rive Gauche. St. Germain is not so expensive that it should scare you off. it is a beautiful area with a lot of boutique hotels, like Artus Hotel and Hotel de Buci that are great places to stay.

Very charming !. A great mix of grand boulevards and charming small streets. Jardin de Luxembourg, Odeon and St. Michel church to mention some places worth seeing. Great for shopping with several boutiques. Several excellent restaurants!
Lovely area for a walk. This is a pleasant quarter for a stroll, some interesting shops and a few more upmarket places to eat
Stunning. Not to visit this great area of Paris is like not eating all the desert. The neighborhood is full of shops, cafes and restaurants which must be sampled when in Paris.
Great architecture, gourmet restaurants and lots of boutiques. St Germain des Pres is a great neighbourhood - lots of dining venues and shops and sights. Well worth taking the time to come here
Nicest in Paris. The whole area is cosy, friendly, and full of narrow streets, restaurants and bars. It feels safe and there is also a lot of boutiques and shops. A new favorite.
Beautiful area. This is a lovely area to walk around - it is clearly an upmarket area, with pricey restaurants, cobbled areas, a statue by Picasso, boutiques and greenery.

Perfectly delightful Jane Jacobs neighborhood. Great shops, used book stores, quiet hotels, perfect people watching cafés and best strolling park in Paris- Jardin de Luxembourg, St. Germain at its best, plus fabulous Christmas lighting.

Wonderful!. This is the area we stayed in for five nights, and it was perfect! It is lively, with small alleyways full of places to eat. They Seine is right there, and the metro too. Notre Dame is a quick walk away!
Quaint, fun and great food & shopping. This is a great neighborhood to walk around and get lost in the streets. Quaint shops and good restaurants to explore. We ate Raclette which was very enjoyable.

Gourmet Neighborhood. We found endless gourmet French restaurants within four blocks of the Citadines St German Hotel. Just walk down the little side streets. The small restaurants are the best and most reasonably priced.
The shopping!. Lovely architecture, great shopping, decent food and Le Bon Marche! Go shopping at Le Bon Marche food Courts. Avoid some of the "clip joints restos" ok rue de Buc.

Jetsetters9. We stayed in this quarter which was recommended by family who stay there and will stay in this area again. Walking distance to the Louvre, Orsay, Notre dame, and so close to cafes and other eating places and great for shopping and if you are up to it you can even walk to the Eiffel Tower which we did. We stayed close to the river with its markets on the river banks. A must place to stay for first timers or revisiters.

Stay in this neighborhood if you can. This neighborhood is wonderful in so many ways, the shopping, the restaurants, the sites, the book stores etc. etc. etc. Everyone we have ever dealt with in St. Germain speaks English, or at least enough English, that combined with our very bad French, we can understand each other. St. Germain is also a convenient place to stay (so many nice boutique hotels) because within two or three blocks of the river you have pharmacies and small local grocery stores.

Wonderful Area. Love this area because it is convenient to all historic sites. It's got great shopping, cafes, and pedestrian only streets, and it's ideal for people watching. People are friendly and many shops and restaurants to choose from.

Our Favorite. This section of Pais is filled with amazing shops, restaurants, and people watching for days. It is one of our favorite sections of Paris and is where we always stay when traveling to this enchanted city.

Nice place to chill out after a day of sightseeing. Also known as the Latin Quarter, narrow streets full of bars and restaurants, great value food and lovely atmosphere. We went into a small cosy bar (can’t remember the name) and had some nice wine to end the long day of sightseeing.

Love the area...try some of the smaller restaurants & enjoy the local flavor!. This was my third time back. We always enjoy this area... My fave is the Piolaine bakery on "Rue De Cherche Midi"... Check to make sure it's open, this is the original location & worth the stop! You MUST have an apple tartlet (to die for!)We've eaten at Cafe Du Flore & Les Deaux Magots, but I've never been impressed... Take a chance on one of the smaller brasseries or bistros (Like the Benoit) on a side street & you'll likely get better food & a more authentic "Parisienne" experience.Notre Dame is not too far to walk to... Would recommend a half day to just roam the area...you'll be glad you did!

My favorite quarter of Paris. We love St. Germain! It's got great shopping, cafes, and pedestrian only streets, and it's ideal for people watching. We have stayed here many times during our trips to Paris. We bring our fold up bicycles with us and cruise almost every street in the quarter! St. Andre des Arts is my all time favorite Rue. There are several metro stops in the area, so you can get off on one side of the area and back on the Metro at the other end. Ciao!

Mon meilleur quartier de Paris. I love the open cafes and the cinema odeon . Cafe de Paris and cafe de flore are my best two. . Either for shopping or dining or just going to l Eglise saint germain or trying le beau marche . saint germain des pres is highly recommend . Le chocolatier named dimanche a Paris is one of my favorite after la duree . To my opinion no visit to Paris is complete with out seating at cafe de flore terrasse after dark with a loved one feeling Paris to its best
Nice neighborhood. Great roads for strolls and have a choco or a crepe! This is one of the best shopping streets with a lot of shops to choose from!
The place to be. Saint-Germain-de-Pres has everything from history to very high end shopping and good restaurants in every price range.
One of the best areas of Paris. Charming & individual; perfect for lazy strolls around the bout queues and tea shops. A very stylish area, much better than La Marais.

Great for shopping, bad for food. If you're coming to Paris to shop then this is the area to stay as just south is a huge area of all these small boutique shops. You can spend days here just going from place to place, but we wary as most of the restaurant along Saint-Germaine are horrible.
favorite neigborhood. love the side streets, shops, artisanal displays and products, it is such pleasure just to go around and get lost in the area….

St Germain area.. Shopping - a must. second only to Galerie Lafayette near the Opera Garnier. Lovely shops and really great to walk in this area and just look at everything. Some really good restaurants. I once saw a jazz band playing near mthe St Germain church - sadly not this time. Probably too cold. 2C.

The best part of Paris. Quaint, winding streets, many, many sidewalk cafes to choose from - what's not to like? Its centrally located and easy to get to other areas of the city. My husband and I agree -when we return to Paris, THIS is where we'll stay next time!
Restaurants, shops,. This area is very nice and parts are expensive but nice. Go to Le Precope to eat. Make reservations before you leave. It is a place that you will remember forever.

Magnifique!. We stayed on the Left Bank in Saint-Germain-des-Pres and loved it. We were a 5 minute walk from the Seine, no more than 10 minutes to Ile de la Cite and Notre Dame, surrounded by cafes and bistros and outdoor markets with all the shopping one could possibly want. We loved the Parisien night life and felt very safe and secure walking the streets after dark.

Cute neighborhood with Hotels, Resaurants and Shopping Galore. Could spend days wandering around this area shopping and dining. It is cute, perfectly situated with a neighborhood vibe. Grab a takeaway sandwich and sit in the Luxemburg Gardens. Don't be surprised if you see a random famous person in this area trying to blend in to this great location with an energetic vibe.
luxury shopping. a good selection of individual shops as well as Bon Marche, a top of the range shopping mall, and the best food hall for variety abd quality

Beautiful area. This is such a beautiful area to walk. I suggest downloading the rick steve's walking tour of this area. He will lead you through the streets with interesting information on the history. It was a wonderful day. I would go back and do it again while in Paris. Oooo I just loved it!!

Great place to stay!. Stayed at the Hotel Bel Ami, which was exceptional and we were right in the center of the area. We went last week and the Christmas Market was set up in the center of town and it was magical. Great restaurants and shopping and a metro as well as sightseeing buses available right nearby.
Great for shopping. Loved the variety of shops, boutiques, Bon MARCHE, antique shops, fabulous architecture and Le Pub 'happy hour '.. Great central location.
It's always wonderful...... Doesn't matter if you just walk around ....it's such a wonderful part of Paris. Excellent restaurants.
the left bank. It is a fantastic area, with a multitude of restaurants and bars. It is also not as touristy as the right bank, which is a massive plus. It is more where the Parisians hang out.

Fun experiences. I loved this area for its shopping, its food, and stumbling over activities. It was Friday afternoon, and there was a "snowfest" going on in the square. (Actually, I think it was an even sponsoring something like vacation property sales in the French alpes.) But for me it was picturesque and fun. There was a snow slide for youngsters, a ski slope for skiers, a stand where a young woman was making raclettes (warm, melted cheese on baguette slices) and distributing them to passersby. Something that might have seemed completely tacky in the U.S., but in Paris it was wonderful.
First trip to Paris. I explored the Saint-Germain quarter by L'Open Tour Bus. There are many stops along the way we're you can hop on and off to enjoy the area.

Exciting, people, fun and food.. We loved staying locally. The St Germein area has an authentic French feel even though it is touristy and busy. We felt safe at all hours of the day and night. The public transport was easy to manage and every aspect of daily life was within a few kilometres. I truly thought staying in this precinct added hugely to our trip.

Lively. Great area for bars and restaurants. Great nightlife and area has character and is very lively without being too much. It is a short walk to the Seine and most museums and sightseeeings sites. Great shopping area with lovely shops but also unusual and individual boutiques and art galleries. You also have a number of great cafes for breakfast but also an amazing selection of food shops and stunning flower shops that will stop you in your tracks.
Superbly cooked beef and lamb. The service was outstanding and the prices very fair. The quality of the food and the presentation was wonderful, tasty and a feast on the plate.
famous area to walk around. Many things to see in this area: buildings, museums and galleries, cafes, restaurants, hotels, parks, theaters, the Seine river, etc.. The most lively area of Paris.

Lots of parisian nightlife. We stayed in this area and it is very lively with lots of stores and boutiques and restaurants including the Deux Magot( where Hemmingway hung out) the Cafe Flore, and others. Lots of fancy people and lovely sites. There are churches such as St, Germain de Pres, St Sulpice, the homes of Picasso and Gertrude Stein, parks and museums and the Quartier Latin. Fancy chocolate shps and pastry restaurants and a wonderful place to people watch. Art galleries to the north on the Boulevard Bonaparte are really nice. We loved this part of Paris.

The Heart of Paris. We love staying in this area. There is so much to see and do and most of the attractions are nearby. No need to eat at expensive Paris restaurants when the restaurants in the area are more reasonable and the food is deliciously prepared. Haven't had a less than wonderful meal here yet. It is fun to sit at a café with a beverage and watch the street life. For me, this area really is Paris.
Go to Champs Elysee. Really very expensive shops. I went there after going to the Champs Elysee and was dissappointed I expected more.
parisian authentic atmospher. the little streets are ready for christmas, all bars and brasseies were full, very sophisticated and cultural feeling!

nicer neighborhoods in paris to see. It was okay. The nice stores were the kind we have in the States: Cartier, Prada, etc. The rest of the stores seemed to carry cheap, made-in-China items that were not unique. Still, there are some very pretty buildings and a few nice cafes, though many are packed and run out of food (Cafe Les Flores and Deux Magots, for example).

2nd time staying in this area. and I would stay there again. You are close to everything and if you don't feel like walking there are many metro stations nearby. Once you figure out the metro system its easy to get to wherever you want to go in the city.
Great location to stay. We were so close to may good Metro connections and the streets were fun to explore and quiet off the main St Germain Blvd. Would stay here again.

A nice neighborhood with plenty of cafes and shopping. Saint Germain is most identified by all the cafes. If the first floor is not a shop, then it is a cafe. Actually, it seems like there are more cafes than shops. The shops range from very high end retail to affordable book stores and food stores. If you are a chocolate lover, then you must check out Richart (reviewed separately); their chocolates are amazing. If you want to shop expensive, but want to avoid the Champs-Élysées, then many of those shops, aside of the auto dealers, are in this district.The only downside is that there was a lot of traffic, so the noise and smell of exhaust was strong at some points.If you get the L’Open Bus Tour (also reviewed separately) one of the lines has a variety of stops there.
Shopping. This area has lots of nice boutique stores to shop from. Really a nice area to walk around aside from Marais.

The coolest area on the Left Bank. We stayed at the Hotel Madison in the Saint-Germaine-des-PresQuarter because we love the area. The boutiques and restaurants -- and overall area itself is truly a Paris at its best.

If you've seen St Germain, you have seen Paris. They are currently setting up the Christmas market on Place St Germain, it will definitely be one of the highlights over the holidays. You should definitely check it out!

A Neighborhood to Fall in Love With. A charming animated historical neighborhood.If you love to wander in the streets looking at the architecture of century old buildings, doing some shopping, discovering an art gallery here or a bookshop there; if u just want to sit want to sit in a cafe enjoying a drink, watching passersby, or reading a book, then Saint Germain it is!From the busy Boulevard Saint Germain & Rue de Renne, to narrower streets of Bonaparte & Rue du Vieux Colombier to the charming square of Saint Sulpice or to nearby landmarks of Pantheon or Luxembourg Garden in the Quartier Latin; Saint Germain offers something to everyone.Discover and enjoy!

Artists, cafes and ambiance. Saint Germain is always busy and something is always happening here. If you start at the Fontaine Saint Michel as there is always some kind of street performance here, and then wander through past the church of Saint Severin and really - just wander the streets.You will discover very talented buskers (some sell CDs), great cafes, florists, and a plethora of galleries - some of which do have a good selection of originals from local artists at prices that won't give you a heart attack.There are a number of very good chocolate shops on and near Boulevard Saint Germain, and a few good bars (Chameleon is one), and more restaurants than you can poke a stick at.If you are after the more traditional restaurant head for La Procope - the oldest restaurant in Paris, with a very traditional menu and some very good service - a bit of treat in such a historic site.There are also a few really good local jewelers if you want to invest in an original piece as a souvenir of your visit to Paris.
THE LATIN QUARTER. A favourite of mine with a plethora of restaurants to suit all budgets. There are also some lovely little shops

Wonderful wandering.. Lots of small shops, some exclusive, some very ordinary, all interesting. Rue de Bac and the Musee D'Orsay - one of the stops on the Hop on-Hop off Batobus river "taxi" which make eight very convenient stops. 2day pass 18euros pp; good value.

Fabulous area!. Cafe de Flore (famous), art galleries, many cafes, markets, upscale shopping and fun to just walk around. St Thomas Aquinas Church is beautiful and not to miss. Easy access from here to tourist spots and metro
Brilliant locality. It was by sheer chance we landed up staying here, but what a great locality, close to "everything" and a quick walk over the bridge to the Louvre

Pleasant, rich neighborhood. There's not much more I can tell you about this neighborhood that you still didn't read around... So, what I can recommend is: take a look yourself and form your own opinion about it. I believe you will love it and it's shops and small treasures!
Not what we had hoped for. Our guide book promised us something special here but we were very disappointed. Not a lot of atmosphere, generally rather soulless and frankly rather disappointing.

Our hotel was here. Best quarter in Paris. No shortage of great food. Walkable to locations such as D'Orsay, The Louvre, and Cluny. Metro stations dotted around. Bustling nightlife. Slightly older crowd than the neighboring Latin Quarter streets.

Stayed here, ate here, shopped here!. It was a good choice for all three! There are at least two Metro stops easily found: St. Michel and Odeon. We felt safe walking throughout the day and evening. Restaurants too numerous to name, little boutiques, etc. We felt the pulse of a real neighborhood and love our stay here. We only left it once to eat dinner and were please with all our restaurant choices here.
Nice area ... safe and gorgeous!. We rented an apartment near St. Germain Blvd. It was close to everything! We were 6 people, renting was cheaper than hotel.
Wonderful Location. Great place for food and nightlife! Had a great time walking through and looking at all they had to offer.

If you don't visit St Germain, you don't visit Paris!. The St Germain-des-Pres quarter is in my opinion one of the most authentic and nice quarters in Paris to have a meal, a coffee or a drink with full confidence that you are doing it right in the heart of Paris. Landmark cafes there such as the Deux Maggots or great drinking bars like the Rhumerie provide ample offer for a great night out with friends in a relaxed environment. During day, it is the gateway to many attractions such as St Sulpice Church, the Senat and Luxembourg Gardens. Unmissable in my opinion.

One of our favorite places to walk in the City of Lights. No matter how often we come to Paris, we always find time to walk on the beautiful boulevards and elegant streets on Saint Germaine-des-Pres. I love the ancient Abbey where you can enjoy wonderful concerts, nice restaurants, cafes and boulangeries, antique shops with remarkable treasures, such as autographs of Emile Zola and Salvador Dali. We always try to stay on the Left Bank to be closer to our favorite neighborhood in Paris and enjoy our familiar leisurely strolls and find something new and delightful.
Worth a Visit. The oldest church in Paris, it is well worth a visit. The interior is impressive and very pleasant. We actually enjoyed seeing this church more than Notre Dame.

Mediocre Marais. Hmmm, this is tough. I used to love the Marais but having not been here for about five years I felt it's lost its soul to retail, trendy cafes and so on. I think this might be the last time I bother but I'm pleased I got to know it 15 years ago when it was a much more interesting place.

Take a stroll down this beautiful Boulevard !. Stroll down St Germaine des pres Blvd enjoy the store fronts ... Window shop or stroll in ... Sit down at one of the numerous cafés and enjoy a shot of expresso ! People watch and enjoy the hustle and bustle of this beautiful tree lined wide boulevard ! It leads you to Jardin Luxembourg and onwards to Notre Dame Cathedral !
Très chick. Beaultiful, expensive, clean, sofisticated, a place To take a walk AND go AND go..................Prada AND Grenede 7 like the book
Pretty but expensive. I liked this neighbourhood however I didn't expect the cafes and restaurants to be as expensive as they were. It is pleasant but I preferred other areas of Paris.

Great Shopping and Cafes. When I think of shopping in Paris my minds drifts here. There is pretty much every name. So much style inspiration mixed with beautiful architecture. And the charming and very busy classic French cafes! It's postcard Paris at its finest.

too full of shops now. When I first started coming here it was very much the student quarter. Whilst they are still there, of course, you don't seem to see them, other than at lunch time. That aspect of the Rive Gauche seems to have moved to up by the Pantheon and to near the Institut Arabe. St Germain is full of VERY expensive shops, Armani, Cartier, Ralph Lauren etc. Baby cardigan for Euro 85 anyone?!

Jean Paul Sartre/ Simone de Beauvoir district. I lived in this district when I was a student.I returned recently... It did not change much .. it is a mixture of art galleries, little shops of clothes and others.. including the famous Poilane bakery ... It is a great district to walk ...around without a specific aim..
Love this part of Paris. Similar to Le Marais, SGDP is a happening area. As you wonderful around the neighborhood, you'll find great little bars and restaurants, and incredible boutiques!
Beautiful. A must to visit. A beautiful place where you are able to relax and watch the world go by. Beautiful scenery to walk around and admire the many views. I loved this place.
Amazing place to stay. The best place to stay in Paris. Near everything, smack in the middle of the city. Has some of the best restaurants and shops
Taste of Paris. The smell of a real Paris, and image quality, along with cafes Paris has every essential travel!Sundays at 14 to street jazz concerts in the corner of the church after the spectacular

Another great Cathedral. This Cathedral may not be as big as some of the other famous cathedrals but for a small admission price highly recommended to visit and walk through yet another Cathedral Masterpiece.

great food at chez fernands. the waiter was so funny a bit cheekcy very witty, and using his perfect english. it is close quarters there so everyone is talking about your food. i had the bone marrow appetizer and it started a conversation with the woman next to me. go there.

Great area to stay. We rented an apartment in this area from Home Away for a great price for four nights. It was a perfect location for exploring Paris. It is a nice neighborhood, with lots of wonderful buildings, restaurants, bakeries, grocery store, laundromat, dry cleaners, etc. People were friendly, though their directions were not always helpful. We were within walking distance of so many places - Notre Dame, The Orsay Museum, the Louvre, Jardin des Tuileries, boat rides on the Seine, Luxumbourg Gardens, the Latin Quarter, the Sorbonne, the Pantheon and even where our friends work! There are several metro stops in this neighborhood and a train station. We didn't have a map of Paris and did get a bit "lost" a few times, but there are large maps in various places, which really helped us get our bearings. There were several parking garages and we left our car in one of them; we found out later when we got the car that we would have gotten a cheaper rate for staying as long as we did IF we had come to the office when we arrived.

Vibrant night life, an electric environment.. We stayed in an apartment in St. Germaine and found it to be a wonderful experience. Restaurants, shopping, bars, the Seine - whatever you want is only a few steps away. This area is very popular with young people, and the only warning is it is noisy at night - but we enjoyed vibrant nature of the area.

Has everything you need and then much more.. Stayed in this area and found it to have everything I needed and all within walking distance. Metro, RER , post office, hotels, restaurants, shopping. It has everything!

I Love this area of Paris. The cafes are great the shopping is great and the whole vibe is wonderful. Just walking the streets , getting lost and exploring . Its a place where Paris is Paris and I advise all visiting Paris to experience this wonderful district . Be careful of the Gypsy girl pickpockets posing as tourists asking for directions with a map in hand , they work in twos , have you up against the wall reading their map while the other one is taking stuff from your handbag. They look like real tourists just like you..be careful . Don't be put off going there , just be careful and don't help anyone asking for directions with a map
A must visit in Paris. It is artistic, fashionable, nice outdoor and indoor cafe and restaurants. A lot of shopping for sure. Good for city explorer. You will love what you see.
This is where it is at!. Food, shopping, attractive people, upwardly mobile feel.The Saint Germain des Pres district is where it is at!

Very Upscale. There are so many upscale shops and classy hotels and restaurants in this area. I wish I had spent more time in this part of Paris but I will go back. It's trendy and artsy with a fun vibe. It's a safe part of town as well. There are lots of cute cafes where you can people watch and relax. It's not filled with tourists but definitely gives you that Parisian experience.
Italian Quarter. Really loved the atmosphere here and lovely restaurants and shops. So near to Notre Dame Cathederal...

most trendy arrondissement. The st germain des pres area is for me personally the most cosy left bank area of Paris; nice shops, good restaurants & bistros, antique shops, art galleries, breakfast at La Durée , etc ... a marvelous place to stay !
Lovely area. Lots of great places to eat and shop. It's just a short walk from the Louvre, find a cafe and enjoy the people watching.

No existential crisis here. Don't miss the breath-taking St. Chapelle stained glass windows! We stopped by Les Deux Magots but actually had lunch at Bar Du marche. We had our first salad nicoise, and croque monsieur of the trip.

A great place to be.. I like the area,the vibe and the people....did not experience anything negative. Especially if you bear in mind all the great artists in the quartier,I personally sat next to Jeanne Moureau years ago at the Flor, when she asked me to pass the salt!!!Also if you read about all the great musicians(I am a professional jazz musician)

Ambient and Classy Neighborhood. This area of town captures the spirit of Paris in my opinion. The ambience, the cafe's, the food, the people all add to an atmosphere that is very romantic and authentically Parisienne. There are lots of world known restaurants and spots here (most were referenced in Hemingway's last book - A Moveable Feast), and great writers and artists such as Hemingway and Picasso were all rumored to have spent lots of time in this neighborhood. A leisurely walk through the streets in this side of town revealed plenty of delights, and treasures. It did not feel very crowded or touristy when we visited, but felt like the famous city of lights. It was truly an amazing experience.

Great area to explore!. There is so much here to see and taste - tons of restaurants of all kinds, lots of unique shops, nightlife, and just a very fun vibe in this area. We spent quite a bit of time just wandering and discovering.

The Heart of Paris. This is the best area of Paris to stay and to dine. We love the lively ambience both day and night. With the proximity to the Sorbonne, there is a great student vibe. It is cool, artistic (full of art galleries), great cafes, not to mention the Cluny Museum and its beautiful garden. There are not as many tourists here as in the other areas of Paris, so you feel as though you have entered Parisian life during your stay. The shops are great browsing, it is a wonderful area to spend time just strolling.
St. Germaine Walking Tour. Our guide arrived about 20 minutes late, which was unsettling, but she was very personable and kept us engaged.
My favorite area. From the metro stop that can take you anywhere, to the cafe's lining the sidewalks, to the shopping that rivals, if not exceeds, Champs Elysees, this is my favorite area of Paris.

Real Paris. This was our favorite place for browsing, looking around corners, dawdling. Go ahead, be sentimental. You can drink coffee or a beernin Hemingway's favorite bar. And the medieval museum, the Cluny, is not to be missed. You really get a feel for the time, the people. It's a lovely place.

Good overall. Left bank of Seine,more relaxed,local,artistic and cool.More Parisian now that Right Bank is very international and overrun with nouveau riche from places afar.Close to sites and good classy shopping(including Bon Marche,the "Harrods" of Paris.Hotels tend to be small and charming,lots of places to eat.drink and party.

High end street - good time pass. Stayed in this area for four nights in May 2014. Had rented an apartment, a well furnished one !Cafes line the streets and one can look at the crowds passing by while having a cuppa. Les de Maggots is also in the area and for Hemingway fans, it's a must visit. You name the brand and it's there - Armani, Gucci, Hermes, Salvatore Ferganno etc.Musee de Louvre is walking distance, just across the Siene, In fact, one can sit on the benches along the river and look at passing boats.

best district. For me this is the best district in Paris and we walked them all. You can easily access all the main attractions from here, and there are great restaurants and little bands playing on the streets at night.

I'd never stay any where else.. We toured the entire city and I couldn't find an area I'd rather stay. Our apartment was so convenient to everything we needed and the daytime shopping and nighttime activities were just outside our doorstep.

Best neighborhood in town. Safe place, nice stores, everything in a walking distance.
Hotels and private apartments for rent and among the area.
Plus many city attractions and metro to go any where in Paris.

Ancient History. This church, the oldest religious structure in Paris, is reeking with history and spirituality. Be sure to read about its history and walk around slowly, take a seat, and soak it all in. Oh, and then there's the surrounding area, loaded with shops, restaurants, etc.

Cool place. You can walk around the streets with lots of shopping options, go to Musee d'Orsay to see the impressionists, seat in many cafes full of people until late in the night, hear people singing in the street...
It's a wonderful neighborhood to visit or stay.
So fun!. My favorite part of the city! We just wandered around and took in the sights. Restaurants and street food are both delicious.

Best Area to stay in Paris . What a great area to stay in . Close to many attractions. Walking distance to Louvre . Fabulous night life and restaurants . I stayed at an expensive hotel but I am sure there are more reasonably priced one to stay .

Lively, fun and very Parisian.... Anyone visiting Paris should venture onto the Left Bank for at least one full day and evening. Of course, you’ll be there if you visit the Eiffel Tour, the D’Orsay Muse, the Rodin Gardens, the Pantheon and many other famous sights. But take the time to “connect these dots” with a nice long walk along the Boulevard Saint Germain or any of the smaller streets that zigzag on either side. Don’t miss the Luxembourg Gardens - it’s the best place to relax in the middle of your trip and simply take in the sun, the sights and a lot of people watching. Enjoy...

Sunday Morning treat. Exploring in Saint-Germain, We found a Sunday open market... What a treat! Even though it is opened til 9:00 PM it is perfect for Sunday during the day and at dinner great restaurants from different cuisines.

A fun neighborhood. Our hotel was located in this area which we fell in love with. It has quaint bistros, shops and cafes. A number of the sites are located within walking distance. I would recommend staying in this area, at least pay it a visit.

Great location to stay. We stayed two weeks in an airbnb apartment in rue perronet. We got our bearings very quickly. Walking distance to many of the sights. We felt very safe. Good eating and shopping. Luxembourg Gardens are a must for relaxing.

Nice to walk around. Visit this section after visiting Notre Dame and it has tons of shops and restaurants. Do not buy from the souvenir stores. They are expensive here and they do not bargain with you. If you even dare to bargain with them they will say you are cheap and pay no attention to you. They are simply rude! I learned quick and didn't spend a dime to be treated poorly. Great for picture and to walk around the tiny streets.

A night (or afternoon) in Paris. I cannot think of a better place to walk around the multitude of cafes and shops while people watching. The architecture and ambiance of this area is amazing. Get off of the main streets and head down the small streets and alleys to some amazing restaurants, Bistros, and Cafes (follow you nose and the Parisians)

It has changed.. On a previous visit several years ago, the outdoor cafes were filled with older adults, very quiet conversations and much class. Now it is filled with young people, very few of whom showed respect for elders on the streets.

Can't be more romantic. If you tune to its character, you get carried away and lose your head wandering around until you drop. The quarter is magical with its quaint shops, galleries, cafes, etc. The very essence of Paris for me.

Dissapointing. The pictures online looked nothing like our room. I paid nearly $300 for one night and got a shabby motel kind of room. Small, old, and lacking in luster for all the money we paid. I paid much less for a hotel called Hi Matic (also in Paris) that was actually worth my money. I would recommend going there instead if you're a couple.
Must see. This is area is what you think of when you go to Paris. Lovely buildings, quaint cafes and wonderful strolling along the boulevards and side streets.

Lots to see, do and eat. A very busy and bustling area and you couldn't possibly be bored. A stone's throw from Notre Dame, the Louvre, Musee D'Orsay, Luxembourg Gardens, the Pantheon, hundreds of restaurants, cafes, art galleries and right next to the Seine. What more could you ask for?

Nice stroll with classic cafes. This is the paris we know and want to see, little bistros, street life even it has clealy become tourist, babalon street the house of french fashion guru YSL, Saint Laurent a great area to soak up paris

Experience Paris in a heartbeat.... My wife and I were directed to Saint-Germain-des-Pres by a close friend, seasoned travel agent, and frequent Paris visitor. We've stayed in the area twice and can't wait to go there a third time. It's quaint, lovely, romantic, beautiful and within walking distance to many interesting attractions, including the Cathedral of Notre Dame, the Louvre, Shakespeare & Co, etc. You can hop in and out the bateau and watch from a distance or visit the many popular attractions along the river Seine -- the Eiffel Tower, Champ-Élysées, the bookstands, etc. Or you can wander around the neighborhood and simply experience what makes Paris what it is -- it's people, its sidewalk cafes, the boulangeries...don't miss sampling coffee or hot chocolate at Cafe de Fiore. Or millle-feuille (Napoleon) at any pastry shop. Bon voyage!
The always bustling Latin Quarter. This area had a large variety of restaurants, bistros and shops. We enjoyed this location for easy access to the Luxembourg Gardens and museums.

St. Germain-des-Pris Quarter. We stayed in an apartment a few blocks from this area, and no matter where we went for the day, we found our footsteps takine us right back here. It feels like the heart of Paris to me.
Cafe Central. Lots of great cafes and restaurants in this district. Less touristy and more locals which generally means better food and better prices.

It's an OK visit. We had to ask people to get to the location as it's not on main street. The cathedral is not as big as Notre Dame. If you want to hear the history of the cathedral you have to buy and app (iphone, android) for 4.99 euros. We didn't spent much time there.
Bouvelevard St Germain. Charming part of Paris. Academic and lots of students. Good eateries and bars. Pleasant place to wander around.

Wonderful part of Paris. I love the left bank. The first time I came to Paris this is where our hotel was. I knew I would like Paris, but I didn't know that I would love Paris the way that I do. I have been coming to Paris over the last 44 years and I never tire of this city. St Germain de Pres is center of so many good and wonderful things to do with Paris. The Church of St Germain de Pres is one of my favorites because it is so old and the main part is so intact. The cafes are legendary and between Sartre, Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Stein, Frieseke, Wilde, and others, this was their part of Paris. The Church of Saint Sulpice is very special too and its plaza with the fountain and the lions. I try to pick out my favorite parts of this city, but that is too hard. I love so much about this place. If you go to Paris be sure to visit this part of the city. No trip is complete without it.

Left Bank Discovery. Located on the legendary Left Bank, this section of Paris contains almost all a first-time traveler would need to see and experience: the Louvre, Notre Dame, La Chappelle in addition to countless shops and restaurants. An exciting and bustling environment not to be missed.

Quintessential Paris. Located on the Left Bank in the Sixth Arrondissement, Saint-Germain-Des_Pres is the Paris that most people imagine when they think of the City of Lights. Charming cafes and specialty stores line the many cobbled streets and the overall pace and feel is far less frenetic than other neighborhoods. There is plenty to see and do (and especially taste) in this neighborhood and I highly recommend staying here during your visit if you can. If you're in the central part of the neighborhood, you will be walking distance to the Seine, the Louvre, Notre Dame, Luxembourg Gardens, Saint Sulpice, and much more. I've stayed in a few arrondissements, and this is without question my favorite. Safe, charming, and pure Parisian perfection.

Stay in this area if you want to see a lot of Paris in 3 days.. This area of Paris has so many restaurants and bars. You can pretty much walk to most attractions. The alleys come alive at night with bars and people. If you don't speak French, the locals can be snotty.
A Must. This area has many little cafes, shopping and is easy walking from many tourist sites. We found that the people here were also very friendly and enjoyed the area
Wonderful. The oldest part of the city with cobblestones streets and little cafes that paint a picture that most tourists imagine when they come to this city for the first time
Cafe life. The center of Parisian Rive Gauche cafe life, stay off the main boulevards and duck into the little cafes and bars to spend an afternoon or two. Quintessentially Paris.

Art Galleries are Overwhelming. I was fascinated by the number of art galleries. I was there on a Monday or Tuesday night and there must have been some sort of open house of the art galleries handling African and primitive art. There must have been 50 galleries specializing in that type of work. It is like Alice's Restaurant--you can get anything you want. I walked into one gallery that only handled Eileen Grey furniture. It was essentially a pop-up store with about 70 pieces from a private collection. Don't expect to furnish your apartment with this furniture unless you are a hedge fund manager, but as a fan of Grey, I enjoyed the experience and the manager was very friendly even though he knew I wasn't a buyer.As for food, this is an expensive area to eat. One night I stumbled into a Chinese high-end restaurant. Quite good, but my bill came to 70 Euros for one, with no alcohol. At the end of the day, this area of town is a window shopper's paradise.

Really interesting part of Paris. Saint Germain des Pres is a very interesting part of the city, situated on the left bank of the Seine. There are lots of famous cafe/restaurant in this part of the city. There are also open-air markets which are really interesting to walk through. The Saint Germain des Pres church is certainly worth a visit.

My favorite area of Paris: beautiful, lively and authentic.. Go to the west bank and enjoy a true feeling of what Paris is: wonderful residential and student area with iconic terraces such as les Deux Magots and Cafe de Flore. I love the Abbey and its surrounding. Unchanged from centuries ago.
Exactly what you'd expect of Paris. Relaxed atmosphere. A wide selection of bars and restaurants. Walking distance from all the major attractions. Good Metro connections.

Great fun. This is the life in Paris. It is the cafe life, the bistros, the restaurant. Walk to D'Orsey and Louvre. Stay at Hotel de Seine or Hotel la Perle. Drink at Cafe de Marche. Dine anywhere. Enjoy.
Great area to stay. This is the first time that we stayed in saint Germaine ..Now I'm hooked. This is the area to be in. Great restaurants, shops and not too touristy.. This is Paris!!!!
Lovely area. Great street vendors. Streets are narrow and lively. Watch vendors make crepes ...they are delicious

A favorite neighborhood. Many fine art galleries and tiny eateries are located in the neighborhood. Fun to stroll the quiet side streets and window shop. several fantastic higher-end chocolate and pastry shops as well.

Has it all. This fashionable residential area has lots of shops and restaurants. Parisians like to sit at sidewalk tables with their coffee or drink. This is where Les Deux Magots and Cafe Flore are found, two very famous restaurants. One evening, we ate at Les Deux Magots for dinner and had dessert at Cafe Louise across the street. There are many fashionable stores like Ralph Lauren and Louis Vuitton. After admiring the shop windows, go into the St. Germain des Pres church to admire its frescoes. It is one of the oldest churches in Paris.This area really has it all.
Best part of Paris. The most exciting neighborhood, with wonderful streets, markets, a beautiful church, great nighttime Friday jazz.

Very Safe and Attractive Area to Base Your Paris Stay. I recently rented an apartment for over a week in this area, specifically rue de Rennes. I loved this area. I always felt safe and was close to many great attractions. Here a few tips if you should stay in this area. There is a nice grocery store with many pre made take out dishes, including cooked chicken. It is the Monoprix at 50 rue de Rennes near Cafe de Flore. It doesn't look like a grocery from the street, but if you go down the escalator and through the clothing to the back you will discover an area where the locals shop with decent prices. You also can dine there and get bread from a bakery. Speaking of bakeries you must visit Poilane made famous by Julia Child. They also have Poilane bread at the Monoprix. There are great second hand stores called Cherchemineppe on rue Cherche Midi. My friend got a steal on a vintage Hermes scarf. Visit Luxembourg Gardens. Some think it is the most beautiful. Don't miss the Medici fountain. Walk by Procope, the oldest restaurant. Also visit St. Sulpice church. It is where the rose line is made famous by the movie and book The DaVinci Code. I would stay in this area again in a heart beat!

Lovely neighborhood. Great location for our vacation apartment. Shopping was too pricey but food was excellent and the energy of the area was great. Open air market on Tuesday and Friday morning at Raspail was fun too.
Lively. Stayed right in Germain des Pres & loved it. Plenty of cafes to choose from. Very central. Beautiful buildings.

Great area of Paris. We walked around the Saint Germain Quarter on a couple of days while we were in Paris and ate here one evening. Great for walking and browsing and a good area for shopping, eating and people watching.

Books galore!. This area of Paris is world-famous for all its book stores and other eclectic shops. I can recommend Gibert Joseph (32 Boulevard St. Michel) if, like me, you are interested in classic films on DVD and Blu-ray. They have a fantastic selection there. And also the Cine Reflet bookshop (15 Rue Victor Cousin) is well worth a browse for a good selection of film books.

Lively, and beautiful!. We walked through the Saint-Germain quarter a few afternoons and really enjoyed it. Wonderful shops, restaurants, art galleries, and people watching. It is hip, lively, and a definite must-see. We also ate lunch one day and dinner one night in the Saint-Germain quarter and thoroughly enjoyed it!

Magicl area and charming streets. Lots of charming little streets, lots of coffee shops, very "Parisian". Walk around at all the small streets and sit in one of the Restaurant to drink champagne arond 4 PM.
St. German des Pres. Wonderful vibe, huge election of cafes, bars, restaurants and lots of music venues. My favourite base for exploring Paris, night and day.

Best place to stay and to shop and to eat. We have stayed in St Germain both of our visits--14 years a part. The best was the most recent since the weather was better and we had the lay of the land. Hotel Millesime is a true find and an ideal location in the quarter--two blocks to food, two blocks to the Seine, two blocks to the Metro.
You have to include this on your visit. Fun to walk, good shops, cute cafes, great little churches. A must, but don't spend your whole time there.

Very nice area.... beautiful area to walk around and though we were able to walk through it on our own to see the items of interest, a small group tour would have been very helpful. The large gardens & park is a must see.
GREAT WALKING. The area has many many many great restaurants and shopping. Day or night there is a lot of activity.
fascinating. still a fascinating place to walk around with the lovely broad avenues. quaint little shops also, LOVELY NEIGHBORHOOD
Quaint area. This was one of our favorite areas to explore. The streets are quaint with lots of cafes and shops. We hung out in an Irish bar in St. Germain one night and had a fabulous time.

The oldest church in Paris, and it shows!. Saint-Germain-des-Pres Cathedral has the aura of an ancient place with blackened walls and ceiling and very simple, austere interior. One gets the sense of centuries leaving their mark on this remarkable place in Paris. Very peaceful and magnificent. Don't miss it.

Mighty touristy and crowed!. I am afraid that this area is soon going to be one of those places "you must set to" for no other reason than to just go...I saw many people walking the streets of this area crowding it jsut because it was the thing to do..I sure did not notice too many tourists going into shops and patronizing the stores....it was almost like going because someone had told them to be sure and go????...just way to crowded...people just walking and talking but not sure of why they were there or what were they supposed to see or do but check it off there list. While there is such great shopping there, so many missed it!!

what more could one want. Bistros, brassieries, restaurants, boulongeries, wine shops, boutique shops for men and women, the huge Bon Marche department store, gourmet foods, meats, cheeses, breads, fish from Le Epicere, Cafes Flores and Duex Maggot, and not to be missed chocolates by Patrick Rogers!

Love this quirky area. This would have to be m favourite visit. Young and fashionable people with quirky shops. Narrow streets with lots of uni students enjoying their break. Much more affordable then other parts of Paris

My favourite district. SaintGermain has something for everyone and every age. There is soooo much going on and Sooo much to see and discover. Great shopping, culture, food, people watching a special attractions

I stayed here for a week. I rented a studio in this area around the corner from Les Editeurs and I was HAPPY happy happy, all restaurants markets and attractions are within walking distance. I even walked to Eiffel Tower and Arc of Thriumph and back from Saint-Germain-des-Pres. It was my very first trip to Europe and all by myself. I always felt safe in this area, most people speak English and are always willing to help. I had a very pleasant stay here. I would definitelly go back and book another apartment here
Too many souvenirs. Not too bad, if somewhat spoilt by tourist shops, lots of places to eat and drink and watch people go by both during day and evening.
Shopping & Cafes. This place is really nice, relaxed atmosphere with lots of nice botique shops and cafe's. Plenty of variety and pretty as is all of Paris really

Gastronomic heaven on earth. A day spent wandering through Saint-Germain-des-Pres is a day spent among the best shops, sampling the best chocolates and pastries in the world, experimenting with an abundance of palate-pleasing wines and mouth-watering cheeses. Yum yum!
Lovely area to be wandering. Lovely to spend time just getting lost and popping into the boutiques, cafes and book stores in the area
Shop, Shop, Shop. I always bring my wife back to this area for the boutiques. She is happy here and finds French fashion with the Champs de l'Eysees prices. Lunch at Les Deux Maggots is a treat.

Chic area in the heart of Paris. In every city there is bound to the that one area that you will always and forever gravitate toward. For me in Paris that Saint Germaine. Bustling with life and character, steeped in historical charm, plenty of shopping, tons of cafes and our favorite spot...Rue Furstenberg. What a beautiful area that you can walk around and discover and after leaving feeling like you still have more to see the next time around. If you ever visit Paris do yourself a favor and stay here and you will feel like a true Parisian.
The best place to stay while in Paris. We stayed on Rue St Andre des Arts. It was great to be able to walk down from the apartment and have a great choice of bakeries or restaurants right there.

Want to go back, loved it. We were lucky enough to rent an apartment in St Germain de Pres for 5 nights. How we wish it had been five weeks. We became part of the community bought produce from local shops and markets , meandered through the streets, sat at cafés and people watched. After a couple of days we felt part of the community , how we love the French. We were close enough to enjoy Luxembourg Gardens a delightful respite from the hustle and bustle of the city. Can't wait to go back and we are already planning our next trip. Our little bakery a few doors down from our apartment had croissants to die for. How I miss St Germain de Pres.
love love love !. my favourite district in paris , so chic and so much character and history at the same time ... cafe de flore is defintely my favourite cafe in paris ... just lovely !
Great place to stroll. Love everything about this little area. Little hotels, cafes and restaurants, shopping and walking about.

Great people watching and wandering!. This area was especially fun to just meander and watch. Another favorite thing to do is sit in one of the many sidewalk cafes, drink champagne, eat French fries and watch the people!

5 days of bliss!. Rented an apartment in this area and was charmed completely.
Lots of cafés, shops, art galleries, restaurants, night life and entertainment.
Close to RER and Metro, walk to river Seine, Norte dame luxenberg gardens, and prices were not as expensive as in other areas of Paris.
Great vibe!

A visit here is a must. The term Lost in Paris has never meant so much as it did in this fabulous area.Wander lovely streets lined with cafes, bars and specialty shops. Stop and listen to street music and visit the gorgeous Luxembourg gardens. Eat steak and fries at the famous St Germain restaurant Le Relais de l'Entrecote on Rue Saint Benoit, you wont be disappointed. Locals line up, but the food is worth the wait. if you can, stay in this district. You will love it!
Historic cafés. The Café de Flore and Les Deux Magots are right next to each other, where all the historic literary personages hung out. Prepare to pony up if you want to join the intellectual elite.
Walking, window shop and eat. This was our favourite place in Paris, little winding streets, charming cafes and store fronts, people watching, great food..

Something for Just About Everyone. This is a lovely area of Paris, filled with wonderful shops, restaurants, museums, markets, patisseries, churches, bars, art galleries ... and the list goes on. I often hear people say that this quarter is "too touristy," but it is touristy for a reason. Much exists for tourists to see and to do. Two of my favorite churches loom here -- Saint-Sulpice with its Delacroix frescoes and St-Germain-des-Pres, which shows off a mixture of styles, including an 11th-century bell-tower. When I'm in Paris, I sometimes get food to go from one of the shops on nearby rue de Buci (a market street) and eat in a garden behind St-Germain-des-Pres. Les Deux Magots, Cafe Flore and Brasserie Lipp stand nearby. Though historically interesting, these establishments serve only average food at high prices. When I want to sit at a cafe, I head to Cafe de la Mairie in front of Place Saint Sulpice. I like the ambiance of the shade trees and the church view better than the atmosphere at the more famous places. And about a block away, Pierre Herme with its famous macarons and chocolates beckons. In the opposite direction, the beautiful Jardins du Luxembourg signal a place of respite from the throngs of people on the sidewalks.It is possible to wander aimlessly through the district and never be bored. But I recommend picking up a walking guide that includes a tour of this area. A couple of possibilities are "A Paris Walking Guide, 20 Charming Strolls" or "Walking Paris." The district is easily reached by bus, metro, and, depending on where you're staying, on foot.
Good. We arrived via the Metro. Paris is easy to get around in via bus or Metro. The area was busy as is all of Paris. Reminded me of NYC.

where we shopped most. Unplanned, we found ourselves returning to San-Germain-des-Pres several times. We took a small walking tour of chocolate makers and bakeries. We shopped at tapestry, lingerie, vintage accessory, and perfume stores. We ate lunch and dinner and sat in cafes. There is so much here, this quarter is on our "want to return" list.

Aussie travellers. Rue Jacob area was lovely.We stayed at Hotel Thomas D'Aquin and enjoyed the breakfast in the street level breakfast room. Walked to Le Louvre in the early morning.Lovely shops nearby. Good selection of cafés,.
Wonderful. I have visited Paris many times and have stayed in lots of different areas, but this is the best. Everything is here that you could ever wish for.

Old Paris at her finest. This is a beautiful, quality, refined area of Paris. I loved sitting on a bench watching elegant Parisian ladies walk past, and young energetic businessmen hustling to appointments. The Deux Maggots restaurant is located right across the street from St. Germain-des-Pres church. This old church is well worth a visit and we spent about an hour looking around and talking to some very helpful ladies about geneology as we have ancestors from that parish. The metro stops right beside the church, so visiting is easy.

Next time, we want to stay here. We love the neighborhood, which is busy but not with the commercial feel of other parts of the city. We have come here before to browse the art galleries, but enjoy it so much that we want to stay in this area on our next visit.

Make sure you have a crepe!!. This is a really vibrant area, with an outdoor flea market on Saturdays a bit further down the road. There are many outdoor crepe windows, and they are amazing!! It is a tasty treat that is not expensive to keep you going all day!

My favourite neighbourhood in Paris!. St Germain des Près is such a lovely neighbourhood; full of life, small cafes and restaurants, shops, boutiques and small hotels. It is definitely my preferred area to stay.
Near Cluny. Historic and beautiful. Shops, Churches and Museums nearby.Short walk from Cluny Hotel and Metros. Luxemburg Gardens and D'Orsay Museum are favorites
Best Neighborhood in Paris. This is by far one of our favorite spots. We love the cafes, people watching, gardens and stores. A must see area in Paris
Charming neighborhood to stay. I love this neighborhood for its small and lovely hotels. The neighborhood is also filled with shops of character - from local designers to unique antiques.

Favorite Neighborhood!. If I lived in Paris, this is where I would live....forever! I love this area...the ambiance, the location, the people, the energy...it's all so amazing! I completely understand why a lot of the grewtest artists hung out here because it's just perfect!
Great walking Area. We enjoyed our walk through area, bustling area, lots of shops and restaurants and pastry shops. Weather was perfect which made it all a great day

Rive Gauche. Each part of Paris is different and the Saint Germain des Pres Quarter is definately bohemian in its heart. The smell of Gauloises cigarettes, long haired serious musicians, artists - people sitting in cafes discussing politics, life and the whole Rive Gauche style is still there....long after smoking has been curtailed!

Oldest building I have ever been in. It is not as famous outside of France at Notre Dame but the Church of Saint-Germain-des-Pres was built about 1500 years ago and it still standing gloriously today. Worth the detour if you love history and have time.

A great place to stay.. We stayed in this area for 8 nights and had a wonderful time. It is close to everything via foot or Metro and there are plenty of restaurants and eating places. It is a very good location for staying in Paris.

Touristy. This is quite touristy and too quiet, but I was there in August. When the students are around, I'm sure it's more fun, but it just felt like a tourist district more than a neighborhood. It's convenient and close to the major sights - including the Eiffel Tower.
Good shopping. Good place for shopping famous brands and to eat local menus during lunch while watching people on the move.

Awesome ambiance. Sixth Arrondissement (neighborhood). This is the place where writers used to lived. Excellent bookstores, including Shakespeare's Bookstore (No, is was not Shakespeare's Bookstore, it is a bookstore named Shakespeare). Cousy and well sorted. Check out Rue de Buci (market street) and Cour du Commerce St. Andre. Get a hold of a good map, plan your walking tour, get there early via metro station St. German des Pres and start walking. You will not regret it.
Art galleries and decor stores galore. Many art galleries, street cafes and in Rue du Bac furniture stores. We had lunch at the famous Deux Magots where the setting was great but the food not so.
So well located. Stayed in this area and it was central to everything with plenty to do at night, lots of restaurants and famous cafes. Good to walk to most sights and wonderful shopping.

Saint Suplice and Saint-Germain-des-Pres Are a MUST. My favorite walk in Paris includes Saint Étienne du Mont, the Panthéon, the Gardins de Luxembourg, Saint Suplice, and Saint Germain-Des-Pres. If you are in Paris on Sunday, you should go to Saint Suplice to hear the massive organ. It will be an experience you'll never forget. Unfortunately, of the 3 cathedrals, Saint Suplice ranks at the bottom from an architectural perspective.

The heartbeat of Parisian life. If you really want to get to the heart of Paris stroll around Saint-Germain-des-Pres. The quarter is steeped in literary and artistic history. Famous in early post second-war era as a meeting place for the likes of Hemingway, Scott-Fitzgerald and Sartre, the boulevards bustle and fizz with trendy bars, street cafes, sophisticated designer shops, museums and markets. Linger for a while.The famous Deux Magots (where Hemmingway was said to do his writing) offers a fine vantage point to people watch. Wander down the boulevard and loose yourself in the the chocolate heaven that is Maison Georges Larnicol chocolate shop. Boulevard Saint Michel cuts across Saint-Germain so hurry to the square and eat your chocolate before it melts! Tip: Very crowded in July and August

Perfect place to stay. Our hotel was in the quarter so we had a lot of fun investigating the shops, restaurants, cafes, alleys, gardens and museum and also the Dentist (that's another story!). Great area to use the Velib (almost free bike system). TIP: Visit Musee d'Orsay - buy tickets on line and get a double pass to Musée de l'Orangerie as well. Its cheaper that way and the other museum is just over the river. The Luxembour Gardens is a great place to bike to - bring food as there is not much available in the gardens although there are cafe's around the gardens. Hotel Quai Voltaire is on the Seine and just down from the Musee d'Orsey and there is a Velib docking station oposite - excellent location. Check it out here on TripAdvisor (ive done a review for the hotel as well).

My favorite in paris. great for shopping + so beautiful!!!
Our hotel was in this quarter and it was fun and amazing - a lot of good restaurants and shops.
Fun area. We had a lot of fun exploring this area. It was our first time here and it was very easy and fun to just walk around. There is a lot of activity, shopping and restaurants to explore!

A STAR AMONG STARS IN PARIS FRANCE. You will enjoy Saint-Germain Quarter for so many things! It has the world class Musee d'Orsay Impressionist Museum for starters. We spent 5 hours there counting lunch. Then do not neglect Paris's most beautiful garden park, The Luxembourg Gardens. There are many other museums to enjoy, e.g., Cluny Museum. Some of the joy here is just walking around and soaking up the atmosphere.
Lovely area, lots of food. Fun area covered in restaurants and shopping. I stayed near the hotel on the same street, it was lovely!

Nice to wander. Love to wander here browse the little shops or sit outside a cafe and chill , imagine what it was like in the impressionist era when the artists painted what they saw very much as it is just cars instead of horses

So much vibrancy. Loved loved loved St Germain. So many little laneways to walk up and down. So many shops, eateries, wine bars. Found a pub with a guy singing Halleluah in French and had the best Onion Soup I have ever eaten. A great place to stay in!

Eat, Shop and be Seen. Direct Metro from Gard du Nord (Line 4 to Marie de Montrouge). All the French high quality shops are here alongside many other excellent outlets. Cafes, bars and restaurants abound . I can recommend Chez Fernand in rue Guisarde,Impeccable French cuisine at a reasonable price.
Shopping Area. A variety of brands, international and Parisian Brands. You can find all the prices You can also try the massage
Walk it!. A must to walk through and window shop, stop for a coffee or lunch. Beautiful neighbourhood. The area is clean with lots of curiosity shops, upscale shopping and cafes.

The essence of Paris, a perfect a visit .... I had never been to Paris but my wife has been several times and brilliantly selected the Saint-Germain -des-Pres area for our recent five day visit. It was everything I had always dreamed Paris to be - old and charming buildings, sidewalk cafes with rich histories and stories for people watching and sipping expresso or wine, wonderful small bistros and restaurants with outdoor seating and often music and street musicians performing. And best of all friendly and warm peolple who are fun and enjoy life and who are eager to share their wonderful community with vistors. The variety of ethnicities and nighttime options - restaurants, clubs, chocloate shops, bakeries ... make this area vibrant and alive and a great experience. Very romantic too. Don't miss it!
vibrant area of Paris. Full of markets, restaurants, small boutiques, fantastic book stores, great shops, beautiful churches, gorgeous museums. what else...Interesting people watching..
Must see. Visited most of the tourist spots and this by far was the best for food and atmosphere .........................

Professional. This area of Paris was a bit more sophisticated. It had interesting boutiques and shops. Nice restaurants ..a bit empty in the afternoon but all decent crowd. One can sit and relax in one of the many cafés

Explore cobble stone streets packed with boutique shops and eateries. Great area for beautifully appointed small retailers and huge number of cafes and restaurants. Some of these have become a little formulaic. I found the best places to eat were the less pretentious, almost obscure places where a pleasant surprise is always better than a sense of disappointment. Look in some of the back streets for tiny public gardens and of course lovely buildings.
A wonderful taste of Paris. Narrow streets full of eateries and stores. Charming and interesting area - mixture of elegant and funky. So much to do and to see.

Famous. St-Germain-des-Pres is located in the lovely district 6, nice to have a drink facing the church is the Café des Deux Magots which, like its neighbor the Café de Flore both are famous and good !

Our favorite area for strolling. Beautiful architecture, old cobbled streets, hidden allies, little shops, cafes, and restaurants. This is our favorite part of Paris. Lovely to stroll around in and especially nice for eating dinner.

Two month stay in Saint Germain de Pres. My husband, baby and I stayed here for two months this year. We loved loved loved this little neighborhood and felt like it had become home when we left. There are so many different neighborhood cafes and fabulous boulangeries. It is very centrally located, so with the use of the metro you can really get anywhere in the city within 20 minutes. It is a bit pricier to stay here, but if you can afford it, I highly recommend it. Our apartment was a 2 minute walk to the metro, 10 minute walk to the Seine, 15 minute walk to Notre Dame, 30 minute walk to the Eiffel Tower. We love Saint Germain de Pres and will stay there whenever we can.

Action Central. This is the most lively part of Paris. lots of restaurants, shops, cafe and interesting people to watch from your seat at one of the many outdoor cafes . You might want to also head up to the Latin Quarter and see the University area with lots of historic buildings
french essence. Many boutiques that french style and essence, able to find antiques of interiors.
Historic old Paris. Be sure to visit the church and research it's history. Wander the streets, visit the sidewalk cafés, and shop Louis Vuiton, Escales, Armani ...

Wish I'd Had a Destination in Mind. We got off the Metro at St Germain des Pres and visited the church, but then didn't know which way to walk. There were many tents and street vendors that looked interesting but we walked in the other direction, sadly missing the heart of the action. Advice: have a couple of specific destinations in mind because you can stroll for a long time and not find what you've heard so much about.

A beautiful part of Paris. If you are into Art Nouveau styles, do visit this area - it is filled with the most stunning buildings many of which are apartments but some are open to the public - you can wander around this area admiring the architecture which is positively grand - and this is all free of course.
Haggling with the street vendors was fun. An interesting part of Paris, we enjoyed the less crowded and relaxed atmosphere the best was the street side vendors.

Paris Nostalgia did it change much?. When I was a student in Paris in the sixties, I was walking around three areas: Montmartre, and of course in the Latin Quarter, rue Mouffetard and rue de l' Odeon in the saint Germain des Pres area. Montmarte because that is where the love of my life lived, otherwise despite its charms I found it a bit too devoted to tourism. Now I am a wild tourist myself so I should be more understanding... . The rue Mouffetard was an absolute jewel, you still had "bougnats cafes", bougnat stands for people from the Auvergne who opened shops and cafes in Paris, where they sold coal and drinks. A hidden working class street smack in the middle of a most praised area in Paris. An ideal location for poor students, with an atmosphere of the early 1900's. And then the rue de l' Odeon. We lived in a one room "concierge apartment" 10 rue de l' Odeon. Next door was 12 rue de l' Odeon where, for half a century people like Scott Fitzgerald, James Joyce,Hemingway, Gertrude Stein, Alice Stoklas, Henry Miller and many others were coming at Sylvia Beach's iconic "Shakespeare and Company" bookstore. What an atmosphere, so many world class monuments, galleries, restaurants, day and night...........why did we leave???? (well we could not afford it maybe :( and we wanted to see the world. I went back often to Paris since, but each time for conferences, family reunions, I did not have time to visit casually my old student haunts, after more than fifty years.... Well Montmartre had not changed, still charming if you could erase from your mind the hordes of tourists. Rue Mouffetard was an absolute disaster. Instead of the "bougnats" lots of shops selling t shirts with "I love Paris", Banana Republic, McDonald and so on. Nothing wrong with these stores per se of course, but not in the location of my dreams. Fortunately rue de l' Odeon had not changed, and Saint Germain des Pres was still as I remembered, I walked through it for hours, stopping here and there at a café, not so much for a drink as too look at the crowds, happy Parisians and happy foreigners who did not look like tourists even if they were, great art galleries, great everything. Maybe because of its history it is a place where American intellectuals can feel at home in Paris. Elsewhere in Paris Americans intellectuals join the club of French "provinciaux" and other riff raff foreigners who do not belong and are told so.
