If it's your first time in Paris..... ...then this should be your "base of operations." I spent two years in this forum reading about the "too many tourists" negativity...and, for that very reason, this is the best area for a first-timer to Paris. The shopkeepers and sales people, the wonderful person at the metro, even those who live in the area...all are lovely and forgive us our lack of language ability (as long as we try) and our knowledge of "things Parisien"....Their economy is, obviously, enhanced by us and, yes, we do tend to "clog up the place" as we stand around and take pictures and read our maps....but to be central in Central Paris is perfect.....the locals and expats might deride this area of Paris; for that very reason, it's wonderful.
Paris in a nutshell. This area is true Paris life - so much going on - beautiful people, cafes, fashion outlets - an absolute must for people watching.
Existential. Just nice to wander around and recall some of the famous philosophers of a bygone age and stop in Les Deue magots etc for a coffee and pretend to be an intellectual!
10E Meals. Fun shops and many rest. in the area on little winding streets. Near the Church on Saint-Germain-des-Pres there is a row of shops that are there for the time.
Best area in Paris. We stayed at Hotel D'Aubsson in the 6th, best location for restaurants,museums, Notre Dame, all within walking distance, great street markets day and night.

My favourite area in Paris. This quarter reminded me of the Paris I read about in books. It has everything! Great restaurants, beautiful shops, winding streets, art galleries, music in the streets, great wine...what more is ther?

Fanastic location. My teenage daughter and I stayed in this area which was central to so many attractions. Less than a 10 minute walk to the river and the Louvre, and the adjacent gardens are a must to see. Beautiful.
Le Marais from yesterday. Many restaurants, good atmosphere but many tourists. Too busy, still nice, especially on the calm streets and places
Just for the atmosphere!. My favorite café of all is there, the Flores and so I come back to it all the time. Saint germain is a taste of exquisite Paris, I love it!
Beautiful. Take time to stroll this neighbourhood. It's just lovely. You can shop here without the crowd. Don't forget to go to Pierre Herme to get some macaroons and have coffee at Café du Magots.

The icing on the macaroon!. This is such a great area. It's central for many museums, on the river and although some parts have very expensive shops, there are also plenty of streets which have interesting and affordable shops. In particular around Sant Andre des Arts. I travelled with 3 children (9,13,15) and enjoyed meandering the streets , interspersed with Nutella crepes and macaroons of course.
Great place to walk, look, enjoy. Winding streets, plenty of cafes, interesting shops, take out food - felafel! - just a great, great way to get the feel of Paris. So much to look at.
gorgeous. lovely spot to eat, drink, walk and relax. In summer a lot of the galleries are closed but it is still so very pretty, and good shopping too.
The best of Paris. We loved the neighborhood lots of small motels we stayed at Agora St Germain tons of small cake and pastry and cafeterias. We felt like Parisian for sure:)
Nice place to stroll. After a visit to the Ile de la cité, best place to go and grab something to eat. Try Chez Gladines...

Tres, tres bonne!. Saint-Germain has to be the best place to stay in Paris. For a SOFT - single, older, female traveller - it has to be the safest and most convenient. I stayed in Rue du Bac just off the Boulevard Saint-Germain and it was the perfect base from which to explore both the left and right banks. The area is also well served by buses which visitors often forget to use in favour of the Metro stops of Rue du Bac, Saint-Germain and Saint-Sulpice. This area is filled with French literary history being the site of Cafe de Flore, Les Deux Magots and Bistro Lipp. Don't worry about being a tourist - practise your French beforehand and take your place among the ghosts of writers past. I have always found the French wonderfully sympathetic with my French tinged with an Aussie accent - they respond in impeccable English! Saint-Germain is home to the most amazing charcuteuries and boulangeries so you can always pick up provisions to take back to your apartment to be washed down with some house brand French champagne from your local Nicholas bottle shop for 16 Euros. Forget all the hype about the Marais - personally I think it's grotty - and find an apartment of hotel in Saint Germain. I can't wait to go back to see my "old friend".

For lovers. This is such romantic place, the small street, the stores, do not miss the chocolates at Patrick Roger on St Germain boulevard, the church, the beaux arts, the small boutique hotels, the many cafés and restaurants, the boutiques, the people, what a marvel in Paris

If you want to feel like a parisian Local!. You can come here to feel what it's like to live like a local, there are alot of shops, restaurants, cafés and pubs... perfect for any night of the week! One of my favourite areas to hangout in, for sure!
Excelent options for food and art. Many dining options, including Deux Magaus, Café de Flores, L'Entrecot and numerous choices of studios and art galleries.

Right Place to Stay. Just a very happening area at all hours, the later the better, numerous cafes, bistros, plenty of boutiques, etc., etc., metro close to everything you want to see; if you are a walker even better.

Historical coffeeshops for writers. Cafe Deux Magots and Cafe de Flore- coffee shops that were frequented by important writers and philosophers.Cafe Old Navy- frequented by Julio Cortázar and Gabriel García Márquez.
Shopping. I love this place for inexpensive shopping, the is a multitude of cute shops. This place is also home to many small and ancient chapels. Check it out after you see the many sights.

Shopping, food, people watching. This can become a very busy area with many tourists, but take a seat at one of the many cafés, have a drink and watch the world go by. I was here in August, it was a hot day and we had walked around for a long time looking through the trendy boutiques. We had a Monaco, relaxed, and recharged the batteries.

love Saint-Germain Quarter. So many sites, shops, cafes - you can find something for everyone here. My favorite part of Paris. There is something around every corner. Best place to sit at a table in a brasserie and people watch.

Great Area, Eat, Snack, Shop, Dine. You have it all here. This Trendy lovely area has lots of Paris charm. Great shopping, amazing restaurants. Brassiere Lipp, Cafe de Flore & one of my favorites Les Deux Magots which is across the oldest church in Paris just to name a few. Safe(all of Paris central is) and central area to many other hot spots in Paris. The architecture is lovely. You will enjoy walking the lovely streets in the area.
Nice area. Nice little shops/ stalls and cafe's to go in. Had the best hot chocolate and ice cream. The bridge where tourists write on padlocks is really nice too.

Nice area of paris St. Germain des Pres, Beautiful Old Church across from LV Shop. I was attracted to this area because of Louis Vuitton Shop LV outside from 101 Des Champs Elysees....turned out.....a very nice old area...Le Deux Magot Cafe is a nice cafe with many nice foods and many nice souvenirs in the basement......try to buy the fabrique en Francaise Umbrella and you will stun by the high quality of the craft man ship....I was buying a duffel sailor bag in paris shop, turned out it was Made in China....Sorry, I am not flying to Paris to buy Made in China stuffs....Made in France is what I am looking for....in Paris shopping....trips.....
Quaint and relaxed. The oldest Church in Paris is in this quarter across from the new LV store. I wouldn't miss this area, so make time to see it.

Trendy. This is a great area for cafés and bars - it has a trendy vibe. It is pretty central for tourist attractions and travel links. Hotels are pretty good value for money if you want to stay in a part of town that has a variety of eateries and shops that isn't too busy. Also there is some great architecture if you look up while you wander around.

Superb Area. A great area near many of the spots you will want to visit. The restaurants/cafés are numerous and outstanding. It is a very trendy area with good shopping and you feel safe. We stayed in the Tulleries area but walked to St Germain a few times and really enjoyed it. We'll stay here he next time we come to France.

A Golden Journey. We walked from the Cafe de Flore (which is also near Les Deux Magots) on Bd Saint-Germain to Le Bon Marche and then to La Grande Epicene de Paris for shopping. We also stopped along the way. From there we walked down Bd Raspail to Fromagerie Barthelemy on Rue de Grenelle and to lunch at Le St. Germaine. We then walked back on Bd Saint-Germain towards our starting point stopping again along the way. Lots of walking, but lots of shops.

Great Base Location. Before we went here, which was for the first time, I struggled to figure out best part of Paris to stay in. We wanted to be near cafe's and restaurants, as well as tourist attractions, Metro, etc.. We also wanted to feel safe and comfortable. I choose well. While I'm sure other sections would have been fine and probably cheaper, this really fit the bill. It was a great place to stay. The area is just beautiful and it gives first timers the true Parisian experience. Can't wait to get back there.
mix of locals and tourists. You can find anything and everything in st germain des près...You can not get lossed but it is a great way to try!!!

Lots of individual boutique/artisan style shops. A wide range of choice a bit out of the ordinary.. Love the nooks and crannies and the small individual shops. No mass market production and everything tailored to your needs.
Best area of Paris!. Loved this area. It had the typical charm and feel of Paris. Many local spots, non touristy, and the food is fantastic! Clean and safe.
Beautiful place. I wandered around the place and it seemed nice from the outside, so I decided ti come in. The church and the area are both lovely, definiately worth a visit.
Delightful Part of Paris. There are small hotels, cafes, bars and restaurants in a vibrant part of the city. It is within easy walking of major sites of Paris and the Metro is available if desired..

So Parisian.. I loved the busy streets, the vendors, the mix of people. I spent a few rainy afternoons sitting in a little cafe, watching Paris walk right past me. It was how I always dreamed a rainy Parisian afternoon would be. I loved the little winding streets, and enjoyed getting caught up in all the foot traffic on the main roads. We found so many little restaurants and neat shops everywhere. The energy of people was almost electric. It was touristy, but for me, the mix of people was incredible. We bought a cup of vin chaud, and it was amazing....we went back for thirds. It was nothing short of splendid to hang out along the Blvd St. Germain and sip warm wine and smell the fabulous street food and watch the world (literally) go by! LOVE!

Great area for food and close to Notre Dame, Musée d'Orsay. Stayed 4 nights in July 2014 and was very happy as we found ourselves in the centre of so many great restaurants and within easy walking distance to the major attractions. In any case the metro is so easy to get anywhere quickly. Very clean and safe district. "Entrecote" steak restaurant a standout in Rue Saint Benoit.
A stroll through Saint Germain.... A most! Get the feeling of one of the many interesting, historic, beautiful places of Paris by simply walking this interesting area.

lovely. Great shopping and restaurants, also street jazz bands and coffee shops. You can walk to the Natural History museum and the famous oldest street market in Paris. Great local foods and cake shops galore. We hung out in this area more than once. Must go to Laduree on Buca

Best place for shopping. My favourite neighborhood in Paris for shopping and eating. Even at night window shopping is a must in this neighborhood. Make sure you stop by Cafe St. Suplice for a cocktail aperitif!
Wonderful. My favouite area of Paris is scattered with beautiful cafes, restaurants and scenary. Walk around to the bridge with the love locks and around to the mix of different restaurants.

Takes you back in time. The small alleys and old buildings of yesteryear take you back in time. So close to the large monuments, extremely wide roads and even wider sidewalks with four rows of trees lining them is this quaint little neighborhood with small alleys and old town feel. While all areas in Paris are nice, this is really special and charming. The eateries are run by family owned businesses, and was able to get a 5 euro falafel sandwich, the best I have ever eaten!
My favourite quarter ever. When in Paris this Quarter is my home. Love the energy, the shops the cafes, the people watching, the restaurants, the buildings. Everything.

Great area!. I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed this area. I stopped into Les 2 Magots Brasserie for a late afternoon glass of wine and people watch. Highly recommend it! Great shops, and fun restaurants.

A wonderful walk at any time of the day. This area is a wonderful walk to experience everyday life in Paris. It´s true… it´s full of tourists like myself, but this is is real life in Paris. A walk during the day is nice and at night, with the city illuminated, is precious.The area I´m talking about is the 5.o and 6.o arrondissements. There are plenty of department stores and alternative shops (the up scale shops are in other area), very good not expensive restaurants and brasseries (my favorites are: Brasserie Balzar, Petit Pontoise and Che Fernand restaurants), some boutique of just small and cosy hotels (try the hotel Des Grands Hommes or the La Sourbonne boutique hotel). I think that this area is what is considered the Latin neighborhood, "Quartier Latin". It has also the Luxembourg gardens, the university La Sorbone buildings, the Patheon, the Middle Age Museum, the Notre Dame church, to mention some of the interesting places to visit.It´s my husband and my favorite area in Paris. We try a different hotel every time we visit in order to choose the best spots. On Saturdays there is a small precious street market that sells vegetables, cheese, bread, foie gras and other foods, as well as incredible African masks. We never miss it when visiting the city.
Love this area. We love to go to this area every time we are in Paris. All of the famous designer shops along the Boulevard. Great place for people watching.

The best place to be!. This quartier in the 6º arrondissement is the place to be! With its countless cafés, brasseries, boulangeries/pâtisseries and boutiques, there are so many wonderful options. The ambiance is upbeat and fun. It is also close to so many historical buildings.
Quaint area. I loved St Germain. So beautiful. There is lots of good shopping in both stores and on the street. There are lots of good restaurants around too. Definitely a place to go in Paris.

Beautiful buildings, cool vibes. Beautiful neighbourhood with old buildings, fancy shops and boutique hotels. Exactly how I imagined a french inner city living- cool! Lined by cool cafés, boulangeries and ice cream parlours, you miss time passing. Busy but not crowded nor did it feel touristy. Coming from Venice, we noted the queue for Grom was looong:)
Interesting. Lots of cafes always go there in the off season cheaper and easier to get around. There are many nice hotels in the area, at reasonable prices.

My favorite. Don't miss This quarter, so so French , little cafe, bistrot, no words to describe how I feel when I walk true the street of Saint-Germain ! Just try , walk walk walk, you will get addicted !!!

Our favorite part of Paris. We loved this part of Paris. From the shops on the boulevard St. Germain, to the market and the churches, St. Germain and St. Sulpice, and its cafes, St. Germain des Pres is the most charming part of Paris.

Best part in Paris. Wonderful restaurants, interesting history/ buildings, good shops, nice Frenchmen...just love this place. Even if there are many tourists e.g. at Cafe de Flore it doesn't disturb at all - athmosphere is just incredible. If I would move again to Paris I would choose this place to live in.
Lovely to walk at night. Loved to walk in the area at night. although the area near the Seine was packed, it was fun to walk about and feel the atmosphere. Loved it during the day also.
Lovely Neighborhood. Our hotel was in the Saint Germain area and it was quiet but had just enough shops and cafes to keep us happy. The tube was nearby to take us all over London. Loved it.

Character everywhere !. The sights and sounds of St. Germain are nothing less that enchanting. High end stores, centuries old brasseries and restaurants dot this mile long district built around the cloister of St. Germain des Prés. You may want to way down a side street to find a less expensive place to sit and have a drink. We chose 'Le Petit Zinc' and were pleasantly surprised. We had great sandwiches 'Croque Monsieur' a warm ham and cheese sandwich. Don't forget to see the art moderrne interiors of this restaurant. It is really stunning. Beer on tap '1664' is quite good. Before you leave the area, take a peak into the St. Germain church. It is worth a short visit.

Paris as I imagined. This area of Paris is quaint yet you were afforded any convenience. I liked the quiet and peaceful demeanor of the neighborhood, the many bakeries, brasseries, and availability of transportation. It didn't seem "touristy".

awesome neighborhood. i spent half a day here. just wandering the streets, stopping to buy macaroons as gifts to go home with, and then stopping to have canard, and wine. then walking around a little more, stopping for more wine... you get the picture...

If I won the lottery . . .. If I won the lottery and could afford a pied-a-terre in Paris--this is the place. Its narrow streets are graced with art galleries, restaurants and cafes, which is how I imagined Paris should be. Visitors to Paris should plan on spending a couple hours wandering around this older section of the city. I had coffee at Le Palette. Location is great. The coffee was good, though the service, even by Parisian standards, left something to be desired. Not sure I'd go back for a meal. Plenty of other cafes to try. Palettes used by artists decorate the walls.

Always stay here. Every time I visit Paris I stay in this quarter. Its close enough to the Latin Quarter to enjoy your evenings there yet far enough away to be away from the crowds. Lots of small restaurants to Michelin starred ones. The market street Rue de Buci is amazing. Sick of dining out? Take some of Paris finest back to your room from any one of the lovely little market shops. Be sure to pack some picnic supplies into your checked bags - picnicking in your room is one of those small pleasures of Paris. Fabulous food for less!

St Germain is the place to stay!. We have been in Paris for three weeks and we've not regretted electing to stay in St Germain. We're close to Rude Du Bac and Boulevard Raspail. This is a very trendy area with a lot to offer...... It's very close to some good bistros/brasseries, metro stations, high end department stores and smaller select clothing stores. Easy walking distance to the Place de la Concorde, Louvre, Notre Dame and a little longer walk, the Eiffel Tower. We've been to other areas in Paris, and we have not found any areas that have as much to offer as the St Germain area. We highly recommend it and will stay here when we are next in Paris.
Vibrant. So much to see & do. Artists, restaurants, winding narrow cobblestones supporting gothic architecture! A dreamscape. Go there.
A great area. Always buzzy, day and night, plenty of good restaurants, great little pubs, interesting shops. We always felt safe and relaxed wandering the streets here.

buzzing. Wonderful area of Paris in close reach of many attractions. Great place for buying and seeing art works by local artists. Great for cafe's and churches. Good shopping area and a good all round area. Very pleasant at night.
sabotuer. what a fantastic,historic place.Spent ages looking around and wallowing in the ambience.Would have loved to have been there 50 years ago
atmospheric. good shopping, bars , cafes etc...lots of winding streets, with interesting book shops, restaurants and plenty of souveniers to buy.

My favourite place in Paris. I can not be more glad for choosing to stay in the Saint Germain district. Very close to supermarkets, shops, the metro, river Seine, the Louvre and there is an abundance of restaurants and bars. It has it's own feel and I have never experienced anything like it. It is very trendy and a great place to explore. Restaurants are open early in the morning and close late in the evening. The nearest metro would be Saint Germain des Pres, Odeon and Saint Michele.

If you read books then this is the place to go to.. The cafe's here are famous. You can read about them. It is a place that will bring you back to earlier times. Times of culture and literary history. I suggest you walk up to the L Hotel and have lunch there. That is the last place Oscar Wilde lived. A historic place.
Great place to stay. We rented an apt with our children in this neighborhood. It was a perfect location with great restaurants, bakeries and a nearby supermarche. Highly recommend the area.

Perfect to people-watch and eat authentic cuisine. We had a great experience strolling through this area and stopped for escargot and Nutella crepes- all delicious (at Cafe Louise to be precise). Good place to go when you don't have anything necessarily planned but want to be around people, restaurants, and shopping.

5 Girls in Paris in Fall. Saint-Germain -des-Pres is the best place to stay. We choose this on line and it was the best. We choose to rent an apartment and that is the only way to go. This is a very safe area an is close to a lot of attractions. Its more quite at nite ,but with our windows open that was great. The only thing when it says 4 levels to the apartment .. That means 91 steps to you door and with suitcases that is a lot. You check your apartment for a lift.. But we did get exercise and our buns were tight..

Everyone has favorite areas in Paris, this is mine. It is the main boulevard in the Latin Quarter. It dissects the Latin Quarter. It is at the base in the valley of the Seine River. Up the hill you will find the Pantheon, the Sorbonne, the University of Paris and on top of the hill the Luxemberg Palace and the Park that surrounds the Palace with statues of the Queens of France a huge collection of flower gardens and a pond for your miniature sailboat.Between the boulevard and the river is a great collection of boutique hotels, street cafés and restaurants. It is the "Latin Quarter"

Browsing heaven. Paris locales often are a mix of extremes and things of varying quality and this is really a key part of its charms. St Germain has it all: classy apartments, interesting places to eat in great variety and endless shops to explore and browse. It is a great place to take first-time visitors to Paris. The other thing of course is proximity to Jardin de Luxembourg. Towards the St Michel area, the other bonus is all the book and music outlets of Gibert Jeune.Paris is great for picnics on a fine day: explore the area but take some ham, cheese and tomatoes and pick up some crusty bread. Jardin de Luxembourg cannot be beaten in the general area.
My favorite part of Paris. We have stayed in this area 3 times now while in Paris. I love this area. So many shops, restaurants and energy of the city.

Loved it. Just what a fancy Paris neighborhood should be. Beautiful buildings, great people watching, many cafes with all types of food.
Once we found it, we kept going back to the same area.
Visit to see Paris life pass you by.... Great place to just wonder around,stop and have a coffee and people watch.lots of shops and places to sample fine french cuisine

Best district in Paris. I like this district. My wife and I stayed in a one bedroom apartment here, costing 300 euros a night, for 3 nights. There are plenty of restaurants to choose from and several tourist attractions (Louvre, Notre Dame, Saint Chapelle, Seine River, Pont Neuf) within a short walking distance. The famous Shakespeare and Company Book Store is also in this area.

Love, love, LOVE this area!. Can't say enough about St Gemain des Pres. Great shopping and the most awesome display or restaurants you'll find. Whatever you are hungry for, you'll find it in this area. Bustling yet quaint at the same time. So much to see and do it's worth it to spend a day here.

favorite area. so many tiny streets with boulangeries and gelato and street cafes from near the Seine to Montparnasse - so much to enjoy and history of artists and writers. can walk to Luxembourg Gardens, Dorsay, Bon Marche, Montparnasse Tower (in the neighboring 7th Arr.)

Great place to meander and shop!. My friend and I absolutely loved this area. We walked around and found unique and interesting shops to explore. Even came across a fantastic antiques market. Highly recommend exploring this area.

Great shopping and food in this part of Paris. I adore this section of Paris! Great stores (name brand - Sonia Rykiel for example and small shops) abound. No, this isn't rue Faubourg St Honore, so you won't be window shopping at Hermes. However, there are beautiful and unique stores in this area along with great food and people watching. Paris, like New York, is a great walking city. This is a great walking area.

Lots of Options. This gem of a neighborhood has it all. Great restaurants of many ethnicities, cafes galore, gorgeous architechture, churches, shops, etc. We stayed in the Latin Quarter but wandered here often. It was great to do a few self guided walking tours to discover where famous writers lived (and died) and check out the local flair. St, Suplice Church, featured in The Da Vinci Code, is in this neighborhood and we checked it out one of the times we walked though. A local told us that before the movie, this church was kind of forgotten. Nice to see that it has so much interest now and is being appreciated. So many enchanting little alleys to wander down and discover food and shops. We loved a soap shop where we could have a piece cut to order. The smells were divine. Oh and don't forget those macarons!

Much loved area of Paris. Day or night St Germain is what Paris is all about. Beautiful shops by day and a very alive place at night. So many cafés and restaurants the mind boggles. Head a few streets back from the main strip and you will find some of the best places to eat in Paris.
Amazing area to stay. Highly recommend the Hotel Signature St Germain des Pres on Rue Chomel. Feels like home, staff is awesome! Great location, close to metro Sevre Babylone.
Lively neighborhood. Nice place to do people watching. Very lively at night. beautiful shops and many lively restaurants.

Great neighbourhood!. Le quartier St-Germain-des-prés on the left bank is a great place to stroll hand in hand with your loved one. This is one of the romantic places in Paris during the evening. It is also nice during the day but doesn't have the same feel. The streets are lit up at night with all the hustle and bustle of the bistros and restaurants. Great neighbourhood!

Paris. I've been to Paris many times and have family there, so we always go to Saint Germain, it's definitely a great neighborhood, in the upper end with boutique shops and great restaurant. Come here to walk around and window shop maybe eat at restaurant but everything is expensive (unless you are uber rich, you wouldn't be checking out Trip advisor) If you are not staying in Paris for an extended period of time or are return traveler, spend time to see other monuments and great world class attractions that this beautiful city has to offer first, unless this is already nearby what you are doing. If you like the metropolitan, designer high end kind of feel, then come here and walk around to soak it in.
Fabulous. Lively and wonderful - lots of cafes and restaurants - open late with lots of people around - where great writers and artists used to hang out. Fun, fun, fun.

My favourite region of Paris. Having visited Paris a few times and twice stayed in the Saint-Germain region I can honestly say this is favourite bit of the city. It is not full of the most famous sights, but it is just a lovely region full of quality shop, restaurants, bars etc. There are also a number of really cute smaller hotels that are full of character. Getting around the city is easy with numerous metro stations in this area.

St Germain des Pres. We stayed in this area and really loved the buzz. Lots of happy people enjoying sitting in cafes and restaurants. Great shopping if you are that way inclined and a very clean area of Paris. We stayed here for 5 nights but ventured further afield as well. Head down the side streets for some more authentic and not quite as pricey restaurants. We were here during a World Cup match and the French atmosphere in the cafes was fantastic!
Lively nightlife. Outdoor cafés in every street ,fresh fruit markets,lots of street performers,and souvenir shops even very late at night.Safe and friendly place too.

A must do when visiting Paris!. This is a lovely area with quaint and upmarket stores. Poilâne (http://www.poilane.com/pages/en/company_boutiques.php) , Patrick Roger (http://www.patrickroger.com/en/index.php) , and numerous others are well worth visiting to sample their wares.

My favorite part of town. We always stay I the Saint-Germaine part of town. The people are so friendly and helpful, you will find some of the best restaurants in this part of town and definitely the best shops. It's the place to stay.
Just plain pretty. Great neighborhood for strolling. Clean by Paris standards, quaint streets and shops. Carve a little time and be unhurried here...

Magic Paris. We loved the little boutique shops (clothing, patisseries and chocolatiers). We stayed between the Odeon station and Luxembourg gardens and found this a fantastic location from where we could explore the rest of Paris.

Parisien soul... Lovely stop to stroll around beautiful cafes,tiny shops..if you'd like to feel the real Parisien soul , it is the place to spend some time ; why not to have a cup of coffee or a glass of red wine to enjoy Paris in Saint-Germain-des-Pres? ;)

We can't spend enough time here!. We have been coming to this area for a number of years, and it's amazing to see how it's transformed from a funky, interesting neighborhood on the Left Bank to a vibrant international scene, with lots of different restaurants, cafes, shops and people out in the streets. St. Germain has some famous cafes (Cafe des Flores and Deux Margot), some upscale establishments (Le Atelier de Joel Rubuchon), but it also has a lot of smaller, less recognized places where you can find delicious food and drink, plus lots of galleries and shops. The street cafes in the center of the neighborhood are the place to be after dark here. Pull up a chair and have a glass of wine.

My Favorite Quarter !. Saint Germain Des Prés is my favorite parisian quarter. I love its alleys , boutiques, restaurants, art galleries,pubs, churches, parks etc..... This where politicians,intellectuals ,actors, journalists, writers still meet at Café de Flore, Aux Deux Magots or at the famous Brasserie Lipp. It is a vibrant area in Paris with its streets activities and various attractions. I love it !

Best neighborhood in Paris. We stayed here for 1 week and after getting our direction sorted out for the streets, it was fun just to walk around, not too far from major attractions and lots of great little hotels and restaurants to just hang out in from breakfast to dinner and later to people watch
PSG. What a cool little area. Tonnes of cafes, with chairs all turned towards the sidewalks for people-watching. Most cafes were very friendly. Especially to Canadians, and futbol fans!

Our favorite. Having lived in Paris for a decade in the 80s/90s, it is always a pleasure to go back to St. Germain des Pres. One quartier which still retains it's quintissentially French chic, intellectual, classic vibe. This is where we visit our favorite cafes, art galleries, and beautiful boutiques, complete with interesting people watching. Wear your comfortable walking shoes and enjoy this neighborhood on foot.

Pedestrian street around Le Buci loads of fun. Shops, cafes, street entertainment, it's all here. A maze of narrow lanes lead into each other and you can spend hours strolling along picking out souvenirs, having a bite to eat, and watching some interesting street entertainment.

Nice area to stay!. When my boyfriend and I went to Paris we stayed in this area. It's a grand area with lovely shops and plenty of great restaurants and bars. It's quite grand (wide streets, expensive shops) but still feels like a neighborhood with afordable boutiques and restaurants nestled next to more expensive options. It feels quite safe at any hour of the day ot night.

A visual surprise at every turn!. We stayed in Saint Germain for five nights and only began to experience all that this area has to offer in terms of cafes, restaurants, sights and shopping. We had a number of good meals here and took part in the very Parisian activity of people watching from a side-walk facing table at Cafe Bonaparte. It can seem a bit comical to see the patrons all facing toward the street instead of each other as if they are seated at theater, but just go ahead and do it yourself and you'll see an incredible parade of people, fashion, and dogs go by. We watched young woman arrive by scooter with an enormous backpack. She left for about an hour and then returned and put mallets into the seat compartment and we realized that she was carrying a huge base drum in her pack. Did she have a lesson? A performance? Who knows, but that was just one of many intriguing moments we experienced. To be sure, if you are not a smoker, you'll find sitting outside at the cafes to be a challenge as smoking is allowed at outside tables. And seating is incredibly crowded and your drinks/snacks will be astronomically expensive. But this is life as theater and you'd be remiss not to enjoy it at least once. There are many good shops as well to explore with merchandise that goes beyond the usual touristy fair. This is thriving neighborhood to stay in or visit for an afternoon. Our hotel was the Bel Ami.

Fabulous area to walk around. Saint-Germain-des-Pres may have lost some of its charm through recent commercialization, but it is still a great place to walk around. Go late in the afternoon, stop in a cafe for a drink and try one of the great restaurants. There seem to be some good self-guided walking tours online that share some of the neighborhood's history.
Great Area. I love this area of Paris. Terrific shops, restaurants and people watching. I like walking all around the area, sipping coffee at sidewalk cafes, and experiencing the atmosphere.

Hip area with fun shopping and good food. I love shopping and strolling in this area. Is a must see while in Paris. Good to visit after Orsay museum. I like the crepe place by subway station in front of the church.
excellent place to stay and shop. Closest thing to Fifth and Madison Ave in New York City. Great place to stay, eat, shop, and walk. Buses go along the entire route.
Meañder. Take the time to wander and discover the beauty that lies within the narrow laneways and cobbled streets of Saint Germain. Stop for lunch, buy a book, take your time.
Real Paris. This area is an amazing area to sit at cafe's, restaurants, people watch or just shop around at the amazing stores there.

Great area to stay in Paris. I stayed at the Hotel de l'Abbaye in this area (6th arrondissement) and loved both the hotel and the location. It is right in the middle of Paris, on the left bank and very central to almost everything. The area is beautiful, well kept, offers great shopping, boulangeries, patisseries,great cafes, restaurants etc. I could walk to an amazing number of sights and was very close to the Luxembourg Gardens. St.-Germain-des-Pres is my choice of the best location to stay while in Paris
Fun area!. This place is great fun with your camera! LOTS of beautiful buildings! Pretty much any picture in any direction will turn out great! Be sure to stop by St. Germaine!
This is the real Paris for me. As a first time visitor, just don´t miss this beautiful and historic area. These streets are what Paris is all about for me.
A great district to stay in Paris. Lots of shops, restaurants and interesting things to see. You can spend days people watching and eating your way through a few block area.

Not to be missed. This is one of the landmark areas of the left bank. Great cafes, good restaurants beautiful architecture and great shopping! The antiques street is great and there are a few good art galleries in the small streets towards the Seine.

Lots of action. Loved revisiting this area of Paris. Cafe Saint Severin is a great place to sit in the sun enjoying an omellette and people watching. Strolling along the Seine then come to this lovely part of Paris. Always fun
ooh the shops and cafes :). this little street was superb, lots of quaint little coffee shops but a little on the pricey side. worth a wander around though

Nice but posh neighbourhood. Saint Germain used to be Paris' intellectual meeting point and its cafés are proud to announce Jean Paul Satre & Company used to meet up sitting at those very tables. However, today the place has become a little too posh, with plenty of high-fashion shops at cafés that sell an expresso for 6 euros. Nevertheless, you'll find plenty of unusual, fun places to hang around and a bunch of interesting art galleries.
Loved the location. St Germain was such a great location close to everything and the metro was an excellent way to travel around and so cheep
One of the best neighbourhoods. Always a great place to visit with interesting and high quality galleries, restaurants and shops. Alive at any time of the day (as long as you are not too early!)

food food food. haWe went for a walk and to find a place Hemmingway caroused at.but ended up having a lovely walk and looked at all the shops.we found the cafe at monmarte hahahaha.It was a lovely walk and we bought local food and had a pancake on the way with a beer at an outside cafe and watched the crowds walk around.well worth the walk. Mike
nice bookstores, shops and cafes. one of the best areas to walk. It is nice to see the bookstores full of people to discuss on the latest books.

Lovely Vibrant area. My Daughter and I wandered the street's of The Latin Quarter and loved the look of many Cafe's and Shop's on Saint Germain Boulevard and many side street's off of it. We stopped for coffee at Cafe de Flore' as it looked so inviting and observed that many patrons were drinking the very popular Cafe de Flore' hot cholocate and so we decided to try it too. Oh my, we absolutely loved it!!! Never had anything as good before, highly recommend!! Margot's is just metres along from there and famous as the place where Hemmingway and others used to meet.

The heart of Paris. My husband and I loved strolling through the alley ways of Saint Germain. We stopped at a quintessential Paris cafe for a coffee and listened to all the locals speaking French. The cakes were delicious too. Wonderful atmosphere.

A must for Foodies. The area may be well known for jazz and the literary set but today, it's where foodies congregate. The left bank still retain its bohemian, combine great food as well I'm sold. My last 2 trips I stayed in Saint-Germain-des-Pres on purpose, it's close to my favourite museum - Musee D'Orsay, cross the river to the Lourve and down a few blocks to Notre Dame. Lots of well-reviewed bistro are also in the area, why would I stay anywhere else.The flat we rented on Rue de Seine had most of the food places I wanted to eat in within less than a 1km radius, don't forget proximity to my favourite sites. Here, you would walk or take the Velib to get around everywhere. I also took a food walking tour of Saint-Germain-des-Pres (www.parisbymouth.com) and I was told that anyone who's anyone in the food scene must have a presence in Saint-Germain to be taken seriously. I certainly would believe that. Where else would you find Patrick Roger, Pierre Hermès, Le Chocolat Alain Ducasse, Patisserie des Rêves (just to name a few) in the same area?

Worth a stroll through. This is a lovely part of Paris. Seems like the place to be with chic shops and cafes, as well as lovely little side streets full of restaurants and tourist shops. Don't necessarily bother with the church itself, but definitely spend a few hours walking around the streets.

Ironically peaceful. I got lost on my way to the hostel and I was lucky to be lost in this area :) loved every minute I spent in the and couldn't wait to come back at night and I did come back at night and it was even more wonderful...loved the buildings, the busy people, the Parisienne shops everything...just love <3

Paris at its best. We stayed in a hotel in the Saint-Germain-des-Pres area, not far from Notre Dame. Around the back streets of this quarter, Paris seems unchanged from my first visit 50 years ago. Buildings remain the same with their ornate wrought iron balconies decorated with geraniums, small brasseries (albeit with a few Pizzerias thrown in nowadays) and many cafes where we lingered over a coffee. This quarter is still rather quiet and seems a million miles away from the right bank of the Seine with the hordes of tourists. Highly recommended.

live here love it. have lived in this gorgeous area for 4 months now and love it, it gets busy at the weekend and in the evenings but its well worth it, you literally cant walk 10 steps without something of interest; a little boutique, a cafe, busker, street art. Its easy to see why its been loved by artists and fashionistas for many years, quirky kitchy Paris but why not we all need a little cliche in our lives

Wonderful area! Center of everything!. I have been to Paris multiple times and this is the first time I stayed in this area and it was delightful. Two metros are close, great shopping, great restaurants, and great people watching. It is close to Rue du Buci which has lovely cafe's to sit, relax, and have a drink. Also a must is to have lunch at Little Breizh which is the BEST crepe restaurant in Paris. We went twice and it was wonderful. It is small and gets busy so go right when it opens. It is very central and it's a short walk to the River Seine, Pont des Arts, Louvre, Musee d'Orsay, and Notre Dame. Saint Germain de Pres is the area I will always stay when visiting Paris.
Delightful part of Paris. Saint Germain is wonderful, amazing architecture, wonderful shopping great places to dine, cafe's bistros, etc. It is the Old Paris and just FABULOUS!!!

Stayed here for first time. Hotel Atmospheres introduced us to this up scale trendy neighborhood and we really liked the convenience to cafes, bakeries and food choices. Easy walk to the river and our two favorite Paris islands. There is so much to do in this adult Disneyland and a new adventure every visit. We enjoyed it very much. It feels safe and friendly.

The real center of the culture, science and history. For a change, I decided to cross the River Seine and to be for awhile on the left bank. Beside of the most famous quartier Montparnasse, there is one more equally reknown quarter, that is, Saint-Germain-des -Pres Quarter. It is located in the 6th arrondissement.And what is more important, the glorious Sorbonne University within the Latin Quarter is in the neighborhood, a little bit to the east. That was really spiritual refreshment for me, to see such abundance of bookshops, galleries of art, little bistros, small museums, numerous churches and major among them, the Paroisse Saint-Germain-des- Pres. When I was walking along the streets of such cultural and philosophical inclined milieu, I remembered instantly the two giant figures of the movement of the existentialist, that are, Jean Paul Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir.Also You may enjoy in the many musical venues and in the evening concerts of the chamber music in the churches, as St.Germain des Pres and St.Julien.The cafes and restaurants are also present here in its variety and number.Really pleasant part of the City of the Lights.
Love the history. Love the history and the architecture. Great little bistros, little shops, and the universite de paris at the sorbonne.

If you are looking for music and art, visit the 6th !. Saint-Germaine on the left bank is really in the 6th arrondissement.The Latin Quarter ( the 5th) is just to the east so there are many musical venues and small museums and hundreds of galleries. Many churches, including St. Germaine, and St. Julien have concerts nightly. Theses are young, talented musicians who are given the opportunity to perform in intimate settings to a very appreciative audience. Just be prepared to sit in a rush seat chair for an hour or so. The admission prices are generally very small so it is advisable to get your tickets as soon as you can, usually an hour before the performance. Then go have a quick bite or a drink somewhere nearby until the doors open.If you have seen all the major attractions ( you know what they are), make some time to visit some of the smaller museums in the area,i.e., the Delacroix, or the Maillol. They are generally less crowded and offer a more personal atmosphere. The area behind the church of St. Germain-des Pres is lined with art galleries and bistros. Very lively, young, but sophisticated ( read" post college-age")crowd. If you are staying in the area, The Latin Quarter ( the 5th arr.) is home to Le Sorbonne and other Music and Art Academies so tends to be a bit noisier. The St. Germain, not so much but depends on your hotel/ apt. location.

Compact, Cosy Area with its charm!. I've stayed in St Germain area for my 1 week stay in Paris, the location is great and puts you in walking distance to most attractions in Paris except for the Effiel Tower which can be easily reached by Train or Bus. St Germain area is compact, cosy area with many cafes and restaurants, however choice of cusine is somewhat limited. Shopping is mainly high end brands but less crowded and more comfortable shopping experience as compared to Champs Elysees. You can find the usual Pauls, Amorina ice-cream just round the corner. The buildings of the area has a long history and the architecture gives an old, historic but romantic feel, just sit at a cafe and people watch. In terms of personal taste, I would say that Le Marais is more right for me, but location wise St Germain is the best place to base in for attractions visiting.

Writers Walking Tour. Take a walking tour of this area and see where the famous writers lived in Paris. Hemmingway, Gertrude Stein, Alice B. Toklas, Arthur Miller. In addition see their hangout the Cafe Deux Magots.

Left bank avenue. The Boulevard Saint-Germain was the most important part of Haussmann's renovation of Paris in the mid 19th century on the Left Bank. Going there now its an assortment of shops, cafes, boutiques, street markets and apartment buildings. It might be less frequented than the other side of the river but its worth going for some interesting artisan shops.

So much History. We did a walking tour around this area with Paris Walks for just 12 euros each. It gave us such an insight into this area which you could never get walking about by yourself. Highly recommend to check out their walks schedule.

Favorite neighborhood in Paris. Love this area. It is everything you imagine about a Parisian residential neighborhood....cafés, boutiques, street artist. Wish our hotel had been here. We will stay in this area on next trip to Paris
Heart of Paris. For me Saint-Germain-des-Pres Quarter carries the heart of Paris with its landmark cafes like Cafe des Flores and art galleries. A must visit in Paris.

Saint Germaine. A happening place. Our most fun was people watching while sitting in street-side cafés. Street entertainers were great. Good shopping/food/wine all with easy access to big stuff like the Louvre or Notre Dame.

Excellent Left Bank location. Great chic location. Some fantastic shops & restaurants. Sure there's heaps of tourist joints that are worth staying clear of, but do some research a seek out the goodies. 3 tips; Deux Magots, over priced, ordinary food and packed in like sardines - go somewhere else; Eggs & Co- fantastic omelettes and egg dishes; the boulangerie in rue du Dragon is fantastic!
Thumps up for shopping!. if you have been to so many shopping centres and malls, then it's not really a big WOW to you. felt as a good shopping centre with some awesome artworks.

the latin quarter. we searched for the old part but never found it, years ago it was all pavement artists, now its commercialised. and if like us you wander in to the food streets be prepared to be lampooned by every single one of them plying for your trade, an experience never to be forgotten. totally not like it used to be but worth a visit.

Busy, vibrant, and easy to love!. Home base for us for a week in Paris. Loved it. From east to west, tons to offer. Shops, bistros, cafes, and more. Avoid the tourist traps and use whatever French you have in dealing with the businesses -- you'll see a difference!
Quintessential Parisian. Absolutely gorgeous part of Paris - lovely little streets with great cafés & restaurants - buildings very quaint just a beautiful part of Paris!

active nightlife and shopping. This is a very nice area of paris with many shops and restaurants. There is an active nightlife going on here more so than many other parts of the city. day or night a good place to visit.

Window shop and eat. Walk down the Blvd SGEP and gaze at the window displays in the high-end shops, then stroll through the narrow side streets and enjoy a cafe, glass or wine, or meal at one of the famous cafes or more affordable ones. Went to a classical concert at the Eglise (admission fee for this ticketed event).

St. Germain des Pres - Nice place to visit and stay when visiting Paris. The St Germain des Pres Quarter is located on the Left Bank of the Seine. It merges with the lovely Latin Quarter to the east and borders the 7th District to the west. This is a very popular area of the city for visitors to spend time. There are many hotels and restaurants in St. Germain des Pres Quarter. We recently stayed at Le Perle on rue des Canettes and found this to be a hotel worth returning to (see separate review). Several meals taken in this neighbourhood around our hotel. We most enjoyed Comme a Savonnieres on Rue Guisarde (see review). We also enjoyed walking along Boulevard St. Germain, seeing the shops, chocolatiers and historic cafes. We found the macaroons at La Duree on Rue Jacobe to be excellent, noticeably better than what we have in our local La Duree shop in Hong Kong.As for attractions, we enjoyed seeing St. Germain Des Pres Church, which is the oldest church in Paris. Nearby you can also visit historic St. Sulprice Church. Further, from St. Germain you can pretty much find major attractions in all directions, including important museums like Musee National du Moyen Age (formerly Musee de Cluny) and Musee d'Orsay. This is a another reason it can be nice to stay in this area of of the city. In the end, Paris has quite a few nice areas of the city to visit and consider staying during trips to the city. St. Germain is up there with the best of them. Tip: While we enjoy this district in Paris, it can be very busy here with tourists during the high season. As such, during Summer visits to Paris, we have preferred staying in other areas of the city like Le Marais instead.

Very lively neighborhood. We enjoyed an afternoon exploring this neighborhood. There are many shops ( read very touristy) but it is fun to be there and explore. People were very friendly and the area is small enough to not feel rushed to see it.
So welcoming.... We went here for lunch twice during our stay... The people were so friendly and helpful... The food was delicious.. And it was so nice just to sit in a cafe and people watch...
Interesting. On a Sunday afternoon, it was busy with many of the interesting small stores, souvenir stalls, open for business, the cafes were humming.

A must-visit area for a walk in Paris. A visit to Paris wouldn't be complete without a walk around Saint-Germain. There are many shops, cafes, and plenty of people watching. A high share of people are probably tourists, certainly at the cafes, but that shouldn't discourage a visit.
Alive. This area of Paris was alive with small unusual shops and bustling cafes and bars. People watching was so much fun here and the caffe latte's were great.

What a neighbourhood! . We were just strolling around Paris and looking for a patisserie that was in this neighbourhood. We absolutely loved walking around this area. There was some gorgeous architecture. The place was so vibrant and if sorry WHEN I go to Paris again I will definitely look into staying around here. This place wasn't even in our itinerary but we spent most of the afternoon here and had a fantastic lunch just watching the world go by...

Lovely area. What a lovely way to spend an afternoon, strolling around this area. You must visit the church, St Germain and a wee peek into les deux maggots ( 2 chinese traders) is worthwhile as you can see the photos of some of the famous clientele such as Hemingway.

One of my favourite.... I just really like this district and always go there as soon as I can. Not just because it's Saint-Germain Des Prés, I do not run after that kind of things (luxury shops...) , but because it's really nice... You can go for a drink at Le Café de Flore (I did it once... waouh... You just feel like a star...), or to the Abbaye, the Saint-Sulpice Church

Stay here. Looking for a great area to stay, that is close to major attractions, has excellent restaurants, lots of shopping, lovely cafes, and bookstores then this is definitely the area!! It's an area that is young, happening and has a cool vibe! Pay for the location when in Paris, you will not regret staying here.

April in Paris. Magnifique et tres bon! Atmospheric Left Bank quarter of Paris. Didn't need to use the Metro as we had a two day ticket for the Batobus which has eight hop-on hop-off stops on the River Seine. From the Eiffel Tower to Notre Dame just use the Batobus and experience Paris from the river. Mant wonderful bars and cafes and the coffee is to die for! Smooth and mellow it's soooo much nicer than italian blends from the usual coffee chains. Don't have the breakfadt in your hotel: go to Paul's: fresh French patisseries and good coffee at reasonable prices. Can't wait to go again!

Great area. This is a great area for browsing, shopping, sightseeing. St. Germain church is historic, Delacroix house/museum is close by, famous cafes, luxury label shopping. Great way to spend an afternoon.
cool vibe. Shopping area but with a touch of classic beauty. I like the ambience of the area, the buildings around. SO nice and different.
Shop, Shop, Shop. Recently stayed in this area. It is a great place to shop and dine and just walk. We were here for a week and enjoyed this area more than the Champs Elysee.

cafe life. The Left Bank is real life to me. Parisians actually live and do their daily lives there which makes it so charming. Shopping is excellent and if a favorite pastime in Paris is walking neighborhoods and taking a time out in a café to watch life go byyou've hit the mother load. Spent a couple of hours snapping scarf styling with my cell phone while drinking a glass of red
Great club!!. I can't forget wearing the kit !! In the air of Paris ... Its such a great city Something I noticed that Arabs money everywhere :D cars, shopping, even in clubs !! :D lovely

Wonderful Location. Favourite area to stay in Paris as transport great, hundreds of restaurants within easy walking distance, eclectic shops, wonderful history and relaxed sidewalk people watching. Great Area.

Take a Walk on Saint Germain des Pres. A lovely walk ... Saint-Germain-des-Pres is filled with a sight on every street. Stop at a book store, jewelery boutique, upscale clothing establishment, patisserie, or any of the corner cafes. I love the history behind Cafe Flore or Cafe Deuz Magot. If you love cards and writing journals stop just down the block from those two cafes at L'Ecume des Pages, a small but lovely bookstore. My favorite little boutique this time was Fragonard... a perfumerie with lovely french soaps, scented oils and sprays and gifts.

Great neighborhood. Take a walk around this great area and make sure to visit the Church, the oldest one in Paris. There are lots of restaurants and shops as well, so something for everyone regardless of preferences.

My favorite area of the city. I enjoyed just wandering around the streets of this part of Paris. It comes alive at night. The shops and galleries are varied and it is worth spending a day or night exploring this unique neighborhood. Churches, shops, crepes etc.

Great area to explore for shopping eating and entertainment. We stayed in the neighbourhood, a little closer to the river than the pointer shows, but we really enjoyed wandering around the back streets, eating in the little cafes and seeing the local sights. Even if you can't stay in the area, it is definitely worth an afternoon and evening just wandering the streets, as well as the tours of the Cathedral and the other nearby tourist sites. Easy to get to by Metro open-top city tour bus or cab. Well worth it.
St Germaine. Loved the shops at St Germaine. It was easy to get to by metro. There were lots of good shopping here with a lots of variety and lovely cafes. The people were very friendly and helpful.
Best place to stay in paris. Great neighborhood: restaurants, churches, shops... all the best.Safe and open late night. had a wonderful time there.

This is the place to get crèpes on the street!. Love the crèpes from the vendors on the street, especially the lemon and sugar ones and the Nutella ones. The shopping is high end in some spots and more local in others. Tons of restaurants!

An authentic "parisien" experience. It's definetely one of my favourite places in Paris. It has everything you may want: museums and art galleries, great cafés, beautiful churches, interesting shops and bookshops, amazing buildings. It's so chic and parisien!

A great area to explore. 'Saint-Germain' is definitely one of the best areas to visit when in Paris. Sophisticated with many shops, well-known cafes and amazing restaurants, clean and friendly, will surely not disappoint you! Oh and by the way do NOT forget to visit the oldest church in Paris when you are in the area 'Saint-Germain-des-Pres' : a must. Stroll down Saint-Germain Boulevard or simply lose yourself in its many little streets full of cafes, shops, boutique hotels and restaurants and enjoy every single moment of it! You would want to go back again and again every time you visit Paris. I would highly recommend staying at a hotel in this area when in Paris.

Fashion, food, coffee, people watching. A great arrondissement to walk around, Saint Germain des Pres is more of an upmarket district of Paris teeming with great cafés where you can have a break and watch the world go by, or you can shop in the many independent and brand-known fashion stores. Easy to get to by the metro, it's a great area to lose yourself in and simply explore.
Just Take a Walk Down Saint Germain. A lovely place for an afternoon stroll! Plenty of lunch options and shops. Definitely a must-do for Paris.
Submerse Yourself. Whether in a small boutique hotel or in a rented apartment, spend a week or two submersed in one of the best neighborhoods in Paris.

Excellent Acoustic and beautiful church. We were very fortunate to attend an excellent concert on St. Valentin's Day. They played Vivaldi's Four Seasons, Pachevel Cannon, and other excellent selections. The acoustic was excellent and the Church is beautiful.

Charming area. Stayed in Saint Germain quarter for 3 nights this February. Location could not be better - full of small shops, restaurants, bakeries and cafes. Would stay here again and again when i Paris...

This is What Paris is All About. Love, love, love this area of Paris. Looking to go back and stay again in this section. Quaint, charming, still plenty of privately owned shops, restaurants and hotels make make for a more individualized experience. Additionally, the charm of the architecture cannot be beat. Not as old as other sections of Paris near the Bastille, this is a plus to me.

A large slice of Paris with some great sights. I don't care so much for the shops and cafes….they are more or less, just like the shops and cafes throughout Paris. I do recommend you stroll down a shady section just for ambience and then see one of my favorite Paris churches, the Saint Germain-des-Prés Church. Dedicated in 1163 on the site of a much older abbey, it is fabulously old and I think charming. Perhaps it is like my very favorite thing in Saint Germain-des-Prés, the Cluny Museum, many blocks away. It is more properly called the Musée National du Moyen Age. Read the reviews for it. If you are in any way a lover of history, architecture, Rome, Paris or art, you deserve a visit here.A very pleasant day can be spent in this quarter, seeing the street and these sites.

Nice place in the heart of Paris. This place was near to our hotel so we could walk to see it several times. Its attractions are the church Saint-Germain des Prés and the famous café Aux deux magots but you can also see the tower Montparnass by the rue de Rennes. The river Seine is not far from here either.
Quick lunch during a day trip to Paris. Excellent atmosphere. Chilly day, so the tomato soup was perfect! Great people watching and very helpful staff.

My favourite 'quartier' in Paris. I always seem to stay in this part of Paris packed with it's little cafes, small parks, hidden shops and great cake shops and it's feel, not as touristy as north of the river. There are plenty of tourists, don't get me wrong but they seem to be 'absorbed' by the character of this location, it's history and 'feel'.Love it.

Best neighborhood in paris. Saint germain des pres is for me and by far the best neighborhood in paris. It has a great spirit of it's own. It's an old, highly itellectual and artistic neighborhood. Visit it's cathedral, take a stroll down both it's wide and narrow streets then have a drink in a cafe trottoir for an authentic parisien experience.

A personal highlight. On our first day in Paris, probably within our first two hours in Paris, we happened upon this church, not realizing it's the oldest in Paris. As another reviewer (Andrew T) said, "it has a quality and atmosphere beyond words." There are more "spectacular" churches in Paris, but I liked this much more than the "big ones." Old, intimate, and amazing!

If you are bored in St-Germain....you are bored with life!! Samuel Johnson. This is the Paris that electrifies me. The paris i love. Sure,i like the other bits,as well, but this is the perfect fit for me. St-Germain is the historical center of French intellectialism,as well as, being on the left bank the the answer to the painter's haven of Montmartre. The hallowed names of Satre,Villon,Giacometti,Beckett haunt this precinct,while legions of youthful tourists and students infest the streets and add to the atmospheric charm. Yes,it is loaded with fake-Greek eateries,pseudo -Irish pubs,fake-salsa,pseudo- everything......and a mother-ship of tourist -inspired gift shops. However this zone is not limited to bars,tourists and students. There are fabulous book shops,designer shops,museums,churches,art galleries ,boutique and hotels,as well as,historic cafes and restaurants. Paris offers 10,000 choices. Its impossible not to love this area. As Samuel Johnson said "if you are bored in St-Germain...then your bored with life". BOOM BOOM. The center is focused on the church of St-germain which makes getting here via the Metro dead easy. Station is ST.Germain.. The church is the remnant of what was a large monestry complex. Look at the ivy-covered areas inside the wrought iron fence surrounding the building. So,follow me inside. The interior is painted Gothic style, and while we were here in the evenin,,classical music was performed in the candlelite interior.. Facing the square is the cafe Le-Doux magot,the most famous left bank cafe with its sister,cafe de la Flore around the corner, both of whome entertained Picasso,Simon de Beauvoir,Satre and Hemmingway ,who haunted this area. Stare at the arty-=farty types and mobile -obsessed buisness-types with trophy gals or get-ye-inside and order a vin blanc or coffee. Trying to sit outside would succeed, if a scalper sold you a seat . Scarce as hen's teeth because its tres populaire. There is no shortage of beautiful people walking around with strange looking dogs. Stroll rue Bonapart and choose from more cafes and more interesting people. Ecole des Beaux Arts( bose as in the sound system) is further on and this historic School of Arts has churned out a lot of artists we rever today.:Sisley,Renoir. Monet, Fragonard,Delacroix and Gericault are but a few notables that learned their craft here. Everyone looks at the bookstands on rue de Seine,where you can pick up an 'original' photocopy of a postcard or a sketch by Matisse or a Picasso print. The rue de Seine is lined with small eateries,cafes and bistros as you near the Boulevard St. Germain. For more touristy and noisy atmosphere ,head onto rue Buci where art book shops rule and cafes are habitated by good lookers. Where do the uglies hang out?. Turn into rue St.Andre des Arts which has more sandwhich shops ,bars and eateries than you can shake a stick at.. This is where cafe procope,reputed to be the oldest cafe in Ffrance,1686 served Benjemin Franklin,jJefferson,Rousseau,Balzac,Hugo and Voltaire,to name a few. this was their 'hood.  Come into St-Sulpice church,totally blackened with history's grim and soot on the outside and enjoy a twilight organ recital. Its a blast. We stayed at Louis II hotel which is next vto rue de cannettes and the Birdland Jazz Bar,great for night activity and good tucker,with the Village Voice bookshop crammed with English language books and mags. Rue Bonapart offers a great stroll and coffee break in the square. Lots of musicians and performers here. Dont miss Musee Delacroix filled with memorabilia,sketches and drawings,as well as, furniture and famous corresspondence from the painter's life.  You are near odeon metro station,got yer bearings?

Exactly what Paris should be!. Our time spent in Paris was truly life altering! The sheer magnitude of this absolutely gorgeous city is just too much to explain in print. As many people do... I fell in love with Paris! And, the Saint-Germain des Pres area was a big part of why! As the oldest part of the city it is exactly what you expect Paris to be. In my minds eye, before ever touching down in Paris, it looked like Saint-Germain-des-Pres. We didn't stay in that area, just across the river, but we walked for hours and days through that stunning area... saw some very interesting little shops and cafes along the way! Awhhh.... Paris !!!

Great for people watching.. Touristy, but very animated and in a nice location. Fabulous area for walking around. Tons of art galeries, shops....Better to just have a drink, on the terrasse. The food is expensive and just ok.
If you're passing by..,. A pleasant church and perhaps worth visiting if you are nearby. Not worth a trip for its own sake - there are plenty of more spectacular churches in Paris.

Gorgeous Church. St-Germain-des-Pres is just beautiful. Every inch is painted inside, just as churches historically were. Coming here gives you a sense of what a medieval church was really like, a magical experience. Besides the traditional favorites of Notre-Dame and the Sainte-Chapelle, this church should be on the top of your list.

This was the highlight of my visit to Paris. We stumbled onto this by accident, but this church has a quality and atmosphere beyond words. It is simply beautiful.Of all the places I visited in Paris, this old church left the deepest impression on me, and will resonate for some time.

excellent location. This is a great location for visiting major museums, eating and shopping.Stroll down any of the narrow streets from St Germain to the river for interesting finds or a coffee. You can also reach all the major sites by boat on the river if you want to avoid the metro.

Vibrant, lively, cultural!. I love this part of Paris. Narrow cobblestone streets where restaurants, cafes and shops line the sides. Restaurants are a bit pricey but you could find all types of food here. Still great to walk through and experience even if you're just watching and admiring. Also, it's across the bridge from Notre Dame so easily within walking distance to the cathedral. Great pubs and bars here if you're planning to stay out late and drink and dance. Place is small enough to walk around but not so big where you could get lost.
Oldest Church in Paris. Loved this place! It was very close to our hotel so we stopped in a few times. It's amazing how old this church is, dating back to the 6th century.

The bell chimes get you every time. This is a lovely church to visit because it has a pretty interior and its one of the oldest churches from the16th century,boasting a Romanesque nave and a gothic choir. The tower is topped by aspire that marks it as a landmark in St-Germain-des-Pres. The peal of the bells is melodic and unique. Memorable church to enjoy and revive in.

Still a fascinating area to walk around. Saint Germain des Pres is still a fascinating area to walk around and watch the world go by. Plenty of sites of interest - both eclectic and designer shops, monuments, history and gardens.

A foundation of the Church. Adds to the perspective of the historical significance of the Church in Paris. Today it provides a quiet spot to adore the beauty of past glory. When thinking of the power of the nobility and the Church in the context of the Revolution, this church shows the long history of the influence this collaboration.

Our Favorite!. My husband and I just returned from our 3rd Paris stay, and of course, we stayed in Saint-Germain-des-Pres! Although all of Paris is beautiful, we are truly in love with this area, on the left bank. There are so many cafes, restaurants, shops, churches, and galleries, all within a short walk. So many of the "must see" sights, in Paris, are also within walking distance. Even if you choose to stay somewhere else, Saint-Germain-des-Pres should not be missed!

Magnifique. Well, what can I say? Well I guess I'll start with that I love this area. I rated the main Boulevard only 3 out of 5 and that is because the area is best reviewed as a whole. Covering from the left bank of the Seine and bordering with The Latin Quarter this area includes the Luxembourg Gardens and Eglise Saint-Sulpice as personal attraction highlights as well as top notch eateries and shopping. Overall this area is one of, if not the best, area in Paris. I just love it more each time I go there - I hope you do too.

Quiet Oasis in a busy area. Called in here after visiting Saint-Sulpice. A little underwhelmed due to that must-see place of worship however it is still very nice. The key feature of this church for me is the very simple stone Chapel Saint Symphorien which shows, on a simple plaque, the original burial place of Bishop Germain back in 576 A.D. Parts of this Chapel date from the 1100's although it has been recently modernised. Right in the middle of a fantastic area this Church, with Free Entry, is well worth a visit.

Just walk about, look. Although considered touristy by some TA posters, we thoroughly enjoy strolling about Saint Germain, window shop, making a purchase or two often in Le Bon Marche, and enoy many of its charming cafes.
cool!!. We walked around for what seemed forever but was 3 how really... lots of quaint shops and antique places.

old base but not that much to feel for me. ...they perform Gospel concerts there which are an experience if you have never heard one before but somehow it doesn't feel right here. can't explain it. the 'Gospel dream' group tries hard and without amplifiers but it seems ok and not great to me (tickets in the front half are 30 Euros, you need to be there early to get a good seat). I am not to judge the spirit of a place, it is well worth a visit but if you compare it to St.Eustache for example....see yourself if you have enough time and are in the area, but not if you got only 3 days in Paris.
Peaceful. Located across the street from the Louvre, we happened upon this church. All of the churches in Paris are beautiful so that was a given. Small, but peaceful.

Various versions. My family and I lived in St Germain des Près for seven years. It is a livey suburb with easy walking access to many universities and outstanding museums. Musée d'Orsay, Louvre and many others on the "rive droite" are within walking distance. Historic buildings pervade St Germain.The quintessencial suburb of "Marais" is not far as well. Accessing these places mentioned above means crossing the Seine via idyllic bridges and allowing yourself to experience the stunning beauty Paris can offerThis however is not a friendly suburb for babies and young children . There is Le jardin de Luxemburg right there in St Germain but apart from that it is hard to find a decent park in the area. Taking the pram up and down the steps in the Metro can prove to be a painstaking experience. Unlike many cities in Canada, there are not many indoor places around St Germain to entertain children in the long winter season. sure, La villette is very interesting but is miles away from St Germain. St Germain has changed over the years. Several excellent book shops were gone and unfortunatly have been replaced by fast food shops. Signs of gloal changes.Overall St Germain is an unforgettable lively and captivating experience for adults.

Charming abbey. Eglise Saint Germain is a charming abbey in the lovely district of St. Germain. Entrance to the abbey is free, and it's recommended to pay a visit inside. This is not the Notre-Dame but check the St. Germain if your are nearby.

Great Shopping, Restaurants, and People Watching. We stayed in the Latin Quarter just a few blocks walking in almost any direction of Saint-Germaine-des-Pres which is located around the abbey of Saint-Germaine-des-Pres. In this area you will find people from all over the world. Locals outfitted in the latest fashions going to work or just taking a stroll. Walk along the streets of Boulevard St-Germaine, Rue de Seine, Rued Rennes or Rue Bonaparte. Window shop, stop in a Boulanger for a Coffee Latte and pastry, later eat in one of the outstanding restaurants in the area. Visit the many museums and gardens. We stayed here for two weeks and did not see it enough so in 2013 we will be back to enjoy this wonderful area again and again. This is a place to see and to be seen.
We stayed for a week here. I like St Germain area. It's full of shops, restaurants and bars. There's also a metro and many tourists live here because it's safe.

Paris - proper. Meandering around the streets here is great fun - even on a Sunday when we were here when many shops are shut. It was a bustling place with street musicians and cafes galore. Tres chic!

Shop till you drop. I particularly enjoyed taking side - streets off of the main drag. There are some wonderful bookstores, and restaurants, but the magic for me was 'getting lost' on rue du dragon, bonaparte, rue de rennes (with apologies to any french people who may be reading this and notice my spelling errors). There must be hundreds of shoe stores in this area. Clearly an attraction for international travelers.
So much to see. We stayed in this area and it was a never ending window shopping experience between the clothes and the patiserees. So convenient to everything including three metro stops.

Great street, great location. We rented an apartment at 73 Blvd Saint-Germain. This location is perfect. Wonderful shopping... both high-end and souvenir shopping. Easy access to Metro, buses, taxi's.. taxi-stand, by the way does by no means say there are any drivers in the taxi's!!

Great Paris Location. We were lucky enough to stay in St Germain, and enjoyed the location as a central point to get around many of the main attractions we wanted to see.
It also had lots of lovely restaurants and cafes when our museum legs needed a rest.

Picture book Paris. I stayed 3 nights in the area ........just around the corner from Notre Dame. The bistros, the shops and the ambience - all that hustle and bustle - told you that you had arrived! And with concerts in nearby churches I was suddenly in a different world ... the Paris of 19th. century novels, accordion music and sense that everyone was so relaxed despite the hustle and bustle. I loved it.St Michel Notre Dame on the metro in case you are trying to locate it.

Great place to stay. Parisian life as you know it. If you want to get away from the tourists, this is where you want to go. The restaurants are better than Champs Elysees, and this is where you find actual Parisian.

A quaint centrally located neighbourhood. We loved walking around this area and lived in a hotel there. It has some hidden treasures in terms of restaurants tucked away in the small lanes. Centrally located to all attractions.
so frenchy. Plenty of cafes/bistros, and french boutiques. Also a lot of writers from early 1900 spent time there, it is just so cultural! Good mix of everything...I loved my stay there!

The BEST!. The best neighborhood in Paris! Beautiful and losts to do! THE place to stay for waling to the Louve or Notra Dame. We stayed at Au Manior and it was perfect distance in Sainte-Germaine. Our favorite arrondissment.
Perfect place on the Left side. I just love this area - the small bistro´s, the boutiques, the people.It is so french, and you are not in the main touristy track.
French Culture with Cafes in Abundance!. Metro Stops every half Block and many French Boutiques to shop for that special gift. Many writers from the early 1900;s spent time in this area.
In the middle of it all. I love this area of Paris, its bang in the middle of everything, plenty of lovely hotels to choose from which are still away from any noise.
fun place to walk around. remember the song ? fun just to wander and watch people,bit tacky in places as tourism overdone but hey this is Paris after all

Beautiful street.. Lots of beautiful cafes, restaurants antd shops. Nice bookstores.
This whole area is very nice. Connects to many other nice shopping streets. Not alot of people begging on the street. Close to schools alot of young people walking around. Felt safe in this are.

Incredible Night Out. Went there by Metro with my Aunty and amazing area to visit there!
