At night time you will see colourful of lighting restaurants and the streets, wonderful to walk across Saint-Germain-des-Pres area including the bridges and seen lots of posh cars outside a popular restaurant opposite a main church. Am amazing seen lots of overcrowding in various of restaurants, must be always popular meal in Saint-German than anywhere in Paris. Best go to in afternoon time go to restaurant as will be no overcrowded. :)
Perfect for shopping. This is my favourite shopping place in the whole of Paris, so many trendy shops and lovely restaurants!

Le Bon Marche Epicerie in St. Germain. What a gorgeous dept store...my favorite place in the whole world! The Epicerie is by far a delight to the senses. The bread, the macarons, the take out counters are UNBELIEVABLE! A must see...must go...must eat!
Wonderful to just walk. This street can take you to a slow and relaxed walking trough Paris. No need to run, just take it easy and relax the stores, the people and, of course, Paris.
Bustly and atmospheric.. Narrow streets, loads of eateries in various price ranges, and lots of people. Great atmosphere and the two main churches are truly local features for the community.
the oldest one in Paris.... Humble Gothic church, the oldest one in Paris... If you are interested in history you can´t miss this place.

Fnatstiques place. IF you love books shops, good bars, good life environement S. Germain must be your place in Paris. Lrs deux Magots and Flores places with story with great clients as Sartre are just in front of You, It is a great place to feel french moods life day and night...

Unknowingly walked through. My wife and I were simply wandering around (as is our way sometimes) and walked through (and around) this neighbourhood.My initial comment of "Looks like a French Regent St" could maybe have been a bit more descriptive but basically this is a nice area with shops, cafes and restaurants but beware, prices are at their highest and Paris isn't cheap to start with!

Go and explore the back streets!. We stayed very close to this area and were fortunate enough to walk through every day. We loved the feel and vibe of the area, which had some lovely shops, restaurants, bars and cafes. In particular we enjoyed wondering off the main roads and strolling through the Parisienne back streets, which were virtually tourist free and had a very authentic feel about them. Here we stumbled across some amazing patisseries,which sold the most beautiful macaroons and cakes you have ever seen!I would highly recommend spending some time in this area.

Paris by Mouth Tour. Absolutely an amazing experience. Sarah led our tour and gave us such an insider's view to the bread, chocolate, cheese shops and landmarks of St Germain des Pres. I highly recommend you book a walking tour with Paris by Mouth!
It has it all..... Great place, lots of everything; shops, cafes, restaurants, attractions.....good part of Paris to base yourself in.

Place Sartre-Beauvoir. There is off course the oldest church in Paris. But what is more: this is the place where existentialism was born. At Café de Flore, Les Deux Magots and off course Brasserie Lipp. At the corner of the Rue Bonaparte Sartre once lived. In short: a trip to Paris is not complete without a visit to St. Germain de Pres.
Fav neighborhood. one of my favorite places to stay just because there are so many shops and cafes and restaurants to choose from
Lovely part of Paris. Must visit if you come to this great city. Good shops, good for and drink. One of the best streets to spend a day wandering.

Real Paris!. Even though it's full of tourists, it`s also a place where you can feel the Paris atmosphere! Highly recommend eating (or just for drinks) at the Cafe des flore and Cafe les deaux magos, visiting la sorbonne and the great bookstores next to it, and of course, shopping! It`s a great place to just walk and feel the city!

6th Century Benedictine Abbey and modern church. Though the 6th century started this place of worship, little remains, the 10C rebuild serves as a simple chapel. It is beautiful in the stark contrast to the Victorian modern main nave. The capitols at the rear of the church show several symbols, but the double fish is unusual. They are currently raising money to restore the church and have some suggested first steps on charts on display. It is very dark in the main church. One other piece of history is that the Merovingian King were originally buried here, not at Notre Dame.

As good as the Champs Elysees with a smaller crowd. The shops and restaurants of St. Germain were plentiful and fun to see. They are quite expensive, but this is Paris after all! We did not purchase anything, but window shopping and walking around is a great experience.An example of the fun shops we found include a Parisian umbrella store selling hand-made Parisian umbrellas (one had Ostrich leather - the umbrella cost 1000 euro!!). If you're looking to experience Parisian shopping, this area is a must-see.

Paris Christmas Markets. A very chic part of the city, with lots of boutiques and restaurants. The Christmas Markets were bustling and the atmosphere great. Look at the churches in the area and follow the Da Vinci Trail.
Excellent shopping. The Saint-Germain area is only a short walk from my favourite Paris hotel (Hotel Verneuil - see review). Great for shopping, sipping a coffee or wine, and people watching.
many shops!!. great area to walk, eat at the small cafe, area has many shop if you like window shop and buy. Great day to enjoy and relax.
Nice Walk & Happening Place. We just walked from Champs Elysee to Invalides than to St Germain , it was a nice walk but the restuarants near the cathedral were overpriced.
Lovely area. This is a great area to stay or visit. Plenty of restaurant and cafes with terraces. Walk around to find interesting shops. Great atmosphere.
The oldest church in Paris.. A very special atmosphere here. The churches that I visited in Paris left an impression of a certain lack of maintainence.
Best place to just get lost..... This is one of the best place to just wonder.. go down those side street and you find so many places to eat for cheap.
A great place to have a walk. Unfortunately we went there on a Sunday when most of theshops were closed. However, we have been there before - a wonderful area full of shops, tourists, restaurants etc

A great place to spend the day. Go on a Thursday so you can see all the markets; spend the day visting the shops, stop by an artisan bread market and a cheesemaker for an afternoon snack. Don't forget the chocolate - hot chocolate in the winter months (amazing), lots of shops including boutique shops - browse the antique store, stop by Henri La Roux for the salted butter caramels and don't forget to pick some macaroons.

MUST GO!! This district is full of amazing unique shops. If you're after bucket loads of Parisienne atmosphere along with unique boutique stores and an amazing choice of bistros then take yourself to the Saint-Germain-des-Pres district of Paris. Narrow cobblestoned alley ways, seafood markets, lively bistros and chocolatiers and much much more...you won't be disappointed.

Lively street anytime of the day. I really can't say nothing wrong in this street. First off all, it has numerous café's all around, the famous one is Café de Flore and Café les deux Magots. Overpriced, crowded at times but to know that Hemingway, Satre and Camus once frequented this café to deliver a masterpiece in literature is inspiring. The street itself has full of life, day or night it is crowded with tourist, students and locals. There are variety of stores such as Monoprix, Sephora, pharmacies, restaurants, hotels, movie theater etc, take your pick because you won't be bored in this street at all.
Cafes, shops and cares. Fantastic for a leisurely stroll, window shopping and a glass, or two, of wine. Top end shops and as many Bistros as you could ask for.

amazing area. this was our favourite area in Paris. Discreet high-end boutiques, well-heeled locals, historic sights and beautiful cafes. Puts the Champs-Elysees to shame. Well worth spending a couple of days wandering these streets.

A lovely afternoon wander. This is a lovely area to just had a wander through the windy streets, while stopping off at any cafe for a decent cup of coffee. There are a number of pretty jewellery shops which I liked, and small clothes boutiques at an affordable price. It was clean and buzzing with people, and there are a good number of bars to have a relaxing glass of wine late afternoon. Highly recommended.
Great area or strolling and eating. Loved all the outdoor cafes as well as the shops and art galleries. If you do not stay in this area, it is well worth spending some time here.

Best neighborhood in Paris, charming, fun, quaint, lively. I have not found a better part of Paris.Filled with car-free little stone roads, art galleries everywhere, pubs, cafes, bars, restaurants, people strolling, eating outdoors, locals and tourists, near the river and notre dame, near the lain qtr, near all.Great vibe. A MUST!Make sure you visit rue de Buci and the carrefour de bucci-- day or night, even holidays it is awake and fun

love the area. if you're looking to wonder around with no special 'aim', this is the area to go to. the galleries are all so interesting, new and different on each visit. small cafes are also available, but i mostly go for the art scene..

Oldest Church in Paris!. Saint-Germain-des-Pres is the oldest church in Paris, dedicated in 558. Not much remains of the original church, and its abbey was destroyed during the Revolution. However, there is still a sense of great history as the church was built to house relics of the Holy Cross and the royal tombs of the Merovingian kings. Descartes is also buried here. The church’s architecture is a mix of Romanesque and Gothic, but its most identifiable feature is its large bell tower, which looms high over the famous Deux Magots cafes. The church also shares its name with the street that cuts through the Latin Quarter. You might want to take Boulevard Saint-Germain-des-Pres a few blocks to the Cluny Museum where you can see not only the famous Unicorn tapestries but also some of Saint-Germain-des-Pres Church’s original architecture which has been stored for preservation. Saint-Germain-des-Pres isn’t my favorite church; it’s a quieter, more modest church compared to the sparkly gems of Notre Dame and Saint Chappelle. However, the district adds to the charm of the church, and I highly recommend sitting in the shadows of the church’s famous tower as you sip some coffee at Deux Magots after some serious shopping in the district, known for its high-end and rare-item shops. TIP: The church holds night concerts which bring the building to life in glorious acoustics and mood.

Les Deux Magots and Bon Marchee. It was great to be in St Germain des Pres again. Les Deux Magots didn't disappoint - waiters as they always are, a bit aloof, but good food and great amosphere. Loved wandering around the area and of course, the Bon Marchee. A very enjoyable couple of hours.
Interesting. At the evening, the Parisian atmosphere is more tended here illuminated, café.shops,bostro and brasseries at disposal.
Forget the Champs Elysee. Shopping in st. Germain is far superior to the champs Elysee; you can spend a full day (or two or three) strolling in the area of St. Germain; great shops and restaurants.

Lose yourself in Paris atmosphere. Worth walking along the street and enjoy the buildings, plazas and small places along the bullevard as well the traditionals restaurants
The church is old and beautiful and there are classic music concerts, usually at Wednesday and Fridays .

Great area. We spent a week in Paris in late September last year. Stayed in Saint Germain and loved the area. Cafes, shopping and a lively neighborhood.
While we have never stayed in any other Parisian neighbourhood, we would have no hesitation in heading back to Saint Germain.

Full of awesome cafes and shops....Great place for a leisurely stroll. Great place to stroll through and check out. Maybe even pick up a football scarf to support the local team Paris-Saint Germain (PSG).

Great area to walk, eat and drink.. Loved the atmosphere and the many restaurants and cafes. I loved just walking around and watching the traffic of people or sitting at a cafe enjoying a wine or cafe.

Great location!. While this is a very busy area, it has a lot of great cafes, restaurants, and shops including great little boutiques. It seems a little bit touristy compared to some other areas, but sometimes that isn't a bad thing. We stayed in the 11th, but traveled here to check out a couple of shops recommended by friends. We sat outside at a cafe, had some coffee, watched people pass by and planned our day. I loved this area for it's energy and people watching, and plan to stay here during my next trip to Paris in May 2014!

Excellent stroll on a rainy day.. Window shopping and stopping at my favorite chocolate shop, Patrick Rogers for a sample. Stopped at Cafe de Flore and bought some porcelain cups and saucers to ship home. A little bit of a Paris memory to have each morning.
Very trendy and chic. Very trendy and chic. Lovely shops, restaurants and bars. Great to just wander around and stop for coffee once in a while.

Gooooooorgeous!. We lucked into a great little hotel, the Residence St. Sulpice, and just loved the area. We checked into our hotel, and walked just around the corner to St. Sulpice and enjoyed a coffee and croissant with the amazing view of the church.
Crowded street. Main street for 5 and 6 arrodissments. Always busy but full of cafes, Bistro, Brasseries and restaurants.
Saint-German-des-Pres. Walked many many times on this long Blvd! I had enjoyed the sight, the people, the tourist, the buildings, it is like a piece of art.. watching from every directions...

Funky Area. Stayed for a week in an apartment on the Blv St Germain. Was sick the whole time and still enjoyed our stay.. So many things to see and close to everything. and at night , the place is jumping with bars ,restaurants and plenty of open shops..then there's the night time strolls around gardens and back streets..do your self a favour and spend abit more to stay in this area..You wont regret it.
The best french ambiance!. This is the place to wonder around, great cafes, restaurants and shops in a unique parisian atmosphere, mostly in the evenings.
Beautiful building. Again, a fabulous building from the outside and a 'must see' on a visit to Paris. As there was a service going on I felt like I was encroaching.

Dusk walk was wonderful. We wandered through here at dusk on our way to the Eiffel Tower and following a day of sightseeing in Paris. My husband and I stayed here 20 years before and we were keen to show our kids and to reminisce - the festive lights were gorgeous and the shops were wonderful.

Walk till you drop!. Put on a comfortable pair of walking shoes and spend hours, shopping and window shopping. There's plenty to see and buy. My husband and I determined our favorite spot was Maison Georges Larnicol. Macarons, Kouignettes, chocolates...bought them all, ate them all.

The Left Bank!. It is always fun and lively place to visit,catch a lunch and do some shopping. The area is always full of people strolling and enjoying themselves. Shopping is chic albeit on the higher end of prices but well worth the money if you want the best and the most up to date.
The hub of the Left Bank. The hub of the Left Bank with shopping, cafe's, and lots of people watching. Window shop then stop for a glass of wine or a coffee. A must do on the Left Bank.

Go for a walk, take in the atmosphere and eat elesewhere. the prix-fixe menus are the biggest waste of money and they are so popular in this area of Paris. Order from a regular menu and you may have better luck. If you like the movie "Midnight in Paris", part of it was filmed here - check out the IMDB site and get the details. It was fun finding the film locations (the famous church is in the 5th arr.) If you want action and crowds, this is the place - at any time of day or night.
Best part of town..... Centrally located, safe and close to all there is to see. Many metro stops within steps to get you wherever you want to go.

Nice area of paris. This is a nice area to hang about after shopping to catch up on food or local cafes, sit down and watch the world go by. But beware of the prices, they can set you back quite a bit.

A quaint square, lovely church and nice stroll. Exploring the area around Saint Germain des Pres was a nice afternoon activity. There are a few cafes to choose from and Laduree is just around the corner. It is an easy walking distance from sights in the Latin Quartier and Notre Dame. Recommended.

Fabulous Paris arrondissement. This district is one of my faves...the restaurants are unsurpassed, there are culinary treats one every street and corner...the chocolatiers, patisseries, brasseries, to the fromage shops.
Each visit to Paris finds me exploring the many charming streets inside Saint-Germain-des-Pres..."Oh La Belle vie!"

Great place to visit while in Paris!. This is a wonderful neighborhood in Paris to shop, walk around and people watch. Notre Dame is close by too. Yes, there are tourists, but not as many as other areas. I would recommend spending some time here.

Lovely area to stay in paris. We stayed here for a week in January and I was very happy with the shops around and has an old Paris feel to it. It is close enough to walk to Notre Dame if the weather is nice and is a great place to spend a few hours walking around. There are so many cafes and shops around such as Ralph Lauren and Louis Vuitton but there are also quite a lot of 'Normal' shops as well around as well.

We are very happy we stayed in this neighborhood.. This is a lovely, happening area...kind of touristy, but that's what we wanted. We ate at several of the nearby restaurants and never had even a mediocre meal - something that many times is not true in a touristy area. The people watching was great and the location perfect.Restaurants, shops, galleries, Notre Dame, the Metro ...everything we needed was within blocks.

Mini Shopping Street Area on the South side. The St Germain Market is a nice visit and you can do some nice shopping there. What is more remarkble is the surround streets which are full of smaller Shops of all kinds and restaurants

Saint-Germain-des-Pres. For a true feeling of old Paris Saint-Germain-des-Pres has it all. My favorite place. Allards for the Duck with olives is a must.......And ...It is only a short walk across the Seine to Angelina's for some hot chocolate

One of the best areas in Paris. I had forgotten how much I enjoy the St Germain des Pres area of Paris .. i usually stay in the Marais. This is such a lively area full of restaurants, bistros, art galleries, coffee shops, fashion, just people watching. Cafe de Flores and Les Deux Magots are just across the street from each other if you want to soak up a bit of Paris history .. it's more expensive but worth it just once ! also Cafe Procope is on 13, rue de l’Ancienne-Comedie .. it was founded in the 1600's also worth a visit !

Very nice district to stay in hotel. There are a lot of cafes, restaurants on Saint-Germain avenue, try other small streets nearby – really nice places can be found, for example near metro Odeon, they usually offering menus (which is cheaper than to order separate dishes). Just walk through the aria, you will find a lot of shops, gallerias selling modern art paintings and antic stores - look through the windows)) I would really recommend this aria to stay in hotel for group of friends and couples. Quite a safe to walk late at night.

"Historic Center of French Intellectualism". If you are looking for an upscale neighborhood with lots of cafes, high end shops, art dealers that was home to many great thinkers, artists, poets (think "Midnight in Paris") than this is the place for you....a nice change from the Disneyland-ish feel you get in other parts of the city.

great left bank neighborhood. i love this area, great shopping, nice people, cafes are good! If you can stay in this area, go for it! We stayed around the corner from Cafe de Flor and Les Deux Magots--two cafes where literary might soaked up the ambiance of the parisian lifestyle. Have a glass of vin rouge and toast Hemingway while there!

Super cool spot to see in Paris. We love the chic shopping and the architectural triumphs of Saint-Germain-des-Pres. Great restaurants and friendly people. A little touristy, but that's to be expected.

Bach in an ancient abbey. On the evening of a first day of 2013, together with my wife we went for a classical music concert to St Germain des Pres. It was not so much about the music itself (Bach does not require a review) but the ambience that made the evening. Great acoustics, applauding crowd of 500 people, shadows on the walls of holy people sculptures, old frescoes and paintings, dimmed lighting, etc. Apparently, this is quite customary in Paris in some of old abbeys/churches to host such classical music performances - highly recommended.

If you love to shop!. So many meandering streets and great boutiques and cafes. I mapped out some stores we wanted to visit before my daughter and I left home so that we would not miss a thing. Give yourself the entire day to explore!
A true feel for Paris. If you want to get a true feel for Paris, the cafes, the street action, the small specialty shops, this is a great area to visit or stay in.
Quite expensive cafes. The automospher was fantastic however the cafes were quite expensive.

A "Must See" in Paris. This is a neighborhood you must visit in Paris, more than once if you have the time. Surrounded by cafes, restaurants, stores and churches, spending a whole day here worth while. The Luxembourg Garden, Saint-Sulpice Church, Café de la Croix-Rouge (best moelleux au chocolat and assiettes you can ever have), Café Deux Magots, The Restaurants of Rue Guisard and Rue de Buci, and the stores of Boulevard St-Germain are going to make your day be unforgettable.

Left Bank Ambiance. We walked through the winding streets and larger boulevards of this lovely area. Designer shops as well as quaint boutiques. The flower shops and "deli" shops are charming. Very inviting with beautiful displays.
Lovely location. Really lovely to walk around especially with all the Christmas decorations and stalls about. Very expensive quarter of Paris but with some great restaurants and Bistros.
Great place to shop and people watch. Lots of shops,chocolatiers and cheese shops. great place to walk, shop, sit and have a coffee or glass of wine while people watching.

Great Atmosphere. Lovely area to wander around at night and experience Paris. Lots of little shops and cafes, some really nice flower shops. Enjoyed the small laneways and just wandering around not knowing exactly where you were.

Great Neighborhood. In December 2012, I stayed at Hotel de Buci, on Rue de Buci, off of St. Germain des Pres Boulevard. The area is filled with cafes, bakeries, chocolate and pastry shops, great stores, a movie theatre and outdoor markets. It is a great area to stay in since you can walk to many major attractions, such as Notre Dame, Louvre, Cluny Museum; and there are many Metro stops to choose from. Even if you are staying in another area of Paris you should take the time to walk down the Boulevard, enjoy a croissant or glass of wine at a cafe and explore some side streets, you will not be disappointed.
great shopping. brilliant and great for shopping:) good variety from trendy and unique to everyday clothing.Central location, lots of restaurants and cafes on this street
Magical new year's eve. There's nothing quite like sitting in Paris's oldest church and enjoying a world-class performance of Vivaldi's Four Seasons.
Great Area to Stay. Just stayed at Hotel Saint Germain on rue du Bac. Shops, restaurants, museums, and the metro....all close.

Paris as it is written about!. Stayed here (BestWestern Left Bank - Saint Germain) and walked the streets, going from one wonderful museum or restaurant to another, or to our hotel. Definitely an Experience that did not compare to other cities. The culture (museums, art galleries, restaurants, window shopping) of what is Paris is all around you. People are very willing to assist --PROVIDED you at least try a little French in asking for guidance. Don't play the UGLY American by talking only in English. All you have to do is try a little French (even if it is pretty poor) and for us in each and every instance, we were assisted, and made to feel wanted, and welcome.
nice neighborhood. seemed like a nice area with more selection of interesting shops, cafes, grocers and restaurants than the area around the Eiffel tower.

The arty shabby-chic side of Paris. Great to walk around, enjoy drinks in the famous places as Deux Magots and Cafe de Flore. You feel the presence of the numerous writers, painters and intellectuals haunting the place. Some might consider it's overrated but wandering around the places where the cafe society use hang out makes you feel you're part of the real Paris!

Great place. Saint-Germain-des-Près is a boulevard. It's almost the center of ParisIt's a nice place to have a walk, to eat and to have a drink. There is also different movie theaters at Odeon.It's a walking distance from many Parisian attractions (The cartier latin, Notre-Dame Cathedral, Luxembourg, The Louvre, Hotel de ville...).If you go there don't stay on the main boulevard (which is already nice!) go to the small streets around... there is nice pubs, café and restaurants everywhere !It's also a very good place for night life.I won't say its the best place to visit in Paris but it's definitely worth visitingAfter all every corner in Paris has its own charm !

This is it!. Shops, restaurants, bars, activity, people, life, where else can you go? We stayed here for 4 nights. It offered us the opportunity to view the city from a different angle and appreciate it so much more. If you want to feel the vibrancy of Paris, this is where you need to be...
Romantic. The best area to stay while in Paris. This area is romantic, chic, fun, happening! All the galleries, night life, out door cafes, and shops are located in this area.

All the highs and lows of Kensington. In Paris!. Pretty if you like hideously expensive shops, and with a lovely 'Eglise' but not exceptional in Parisian terms. Better value elsewhere (Notre Dame area for example) if thats possible in Paris!!

Walk with history, watch the world go by. This is one of the most glamorous and atmospheric areas of Paris. It's full of literary and historical associations; there are an immense number of cafes, brasseries and restaurants to choose from. And it's the ideal place to stop, have a drink outside and watch the world go by. It can sometimes seem a bit too crowded, but that's the price you have to pay for the opportunity to people watch. If you like Paris, you'll love it.

Great atmosphere. This part of Paris is so typically Parisien. If you had to imagine Paris it would be like this. You can walk to all major sights but if you do not want to walk the Metro is nearby. Great places to eat and watch the world go by.

Saint Germain-des-Pres district 6th arrondissement Paris. Think of Saint Germain des Pres as a pie shape running south of the River Seine, with its pointy end between Pont du Carousel and Pont des Arts. ( the district east of the 6th is the 5th district or the Latin Quarter and the district west of the 6th is the 7th district where the Eiffel Tower is)Streets that run away from the Seine are rue des Saints Peresrue Bonaparterue de Seine becomes rue de Tournonrue de Mazarin becomes Monsieur le Princestreets that run parallel to the SeineBoulevard St Germainrue de Vaugirardat the wide end of the pie is the Luxembourg Gardens.( I have reviewed Jardin du Luxembourg separately.)For Hemingway enthusiasts Gertrude Stein’s house is just west and south of rue Vaugirard off Jardin du Luxembourg at rue de Fleurus. He would walk from his first house in the 5th just of Cardinal Lemoine across the Luxembourg Gardens, often stopping at Stein’s house on his way to or from one of the cafe’s near St Germain des Pres.good Metro stops to arrive at:I would start a walking tour of the district at Metro Odeon because there is such a pretty view up the road to the Theatre Odeon. On another street close by (rue de Tournon) is another pretty view up to the Senate building in the Luxembourg Gardens. (good restaurant Les Editeurs, reviewed separately)From this Metro stop you can walk east along rue de l’ecole de Medicine. If you cross Bd St Michel (boul mich’) the road becomes rue des Ecoles (but you are now in the 5th district or Latin Quarter - reviewed separately)However, if you go west along rue St Sulpice you come to St Sulpice church. Beyond there it becomes Vieux Colombier which goes to rue du Sevres. If you cross that the road becomes rue de Grenelle which takes you into the 7th district (reviewed separately)Sevres Babylone is another good Metro stop from which to explore the 6th district - this time from the other direction. It takes you close to the Bonne Marche shops on rue du Sevres at rue Raspail just past the parc Sevres Babylone. Bonne Marche is two buildings on two blocks and one of the buildings has the largest food floor you can imagine. Christmas 2012, the Bonne Marche has some lovely window displays to rival the displays at Printemps and Galleries Lafayette on Bd Haussmann across the river.note : the Raspail biologique market is nearby (Tues and Fridays 7 am - 2:30 pm) between rue du Cherche-Midi and rue de Rennes. Another market, the St Germain covered market is mostly mall and shops but there is a bit of a food market through a back door. Why you would need anything other than Bonne Marche food floor escapes me though.If you walk from Bonne Marche towards the Seine on rue du Sevre /rue du Four you come more or less to St Germain des Pres church and that famous corner where Brasserie Lipp, Cafe Flore and les Deux Magots are all located.Rue Bonaparte has two good restaurants. Laduree has a shop there (reviewed separately) and a cheap option for lunch, Paul a sandwich shop chain (reviewed separately)I can't get enough of the 6th district. It is never just a one day visit to this area.

The best neighborhood in all of Paris!!!. This area is close to many of the must sees of Paris and has so many great restaurants within walking distance! You can walk to the Louvre, Saint Chapelle, Notre Dame, Seine River and many others. The night life is fun here with many locals hanging out enjoying the locals scene. There is also lots of great shopping during the day. This is definitely the place to be in Paris!!!
Best part of town. I love this part of town, small restaurants with reasonable prices, boutiques with wonderfully unique clothing...

Wonderful! Wonderful!. This is a great part of the city. We stayed in a hotel in this area. Almost everything is within walking distance. I would stay in this area again. Lots of restaurants, cafes, shops, museums, etc. It's near the Notre Dame Cathedral. Metro stations are also nearby.
Glamour. One of the most envolving churches that i now is just there.The place is a little bit expensive, but much parisien
Go. just to go through the streets sitting in a coffee shop. very nice erea to walk around smell the atmospher of paris.

Great to Experience but Muted in Comparison to Other Districts. Saint-Germain-des-Pres is a long street that spans from the Ile-St-Louis near Notre Dame to the Place de la Concorde. This street shares the name of the district that it cuts through—roughly between the Cluny Museum and Church of Thomas Aquinas. The Saint-Germain district feels a little more urban and modern in energy to me—faster paced with more local Parisians and business men rushing through or crowding at cafes. Having said that, it is also associated with historic artists and thinkers, and has some famous cafes where these intellectuals would meet. One of the most famous of these cafes, Deux Magots, faces the oldest church in Paris—called Saint-Germain-des-Pres, of course! It was founded in the 6th century as an abbey to house a relic of the True Cross. Little of the original structure remains, but the church is still a peaceful spot to recover from the touristy exhaustion of a trip to Paris. The area doesn’t charm me for some reason--maybe because it lacks the sparkle of the other districts. This district is very earthy, very human, very real. I like that, but I guess that I prefer the dazzle of Paris' other districts.

"Walk from Notre Dame to The C-E"!. Hope you have a beautiful day to enjoy this wonderful walk! Make sure you give yourself plenty of time to stop at a few "Sidewalk Cafe's"! Enjoy some oysters on the half shell, or just get an Ice Cream cone on a warm day! Don't forget your camera, and Euro's for shopping as well!
Nice Find. I read about this area prior to my trip. I would highly recommend visiting this area and spending a day here. There is a good mix of shopping and restaurants.
Great street!. Old and really parisian... street markets all around and two very old cafes where intelectuals in the past used to go - Cafe de Flore and Deux Margots

Buzzy with so many restaurants & chic boutiques. Only discovered on the last of 3 days just how many restaurants & shops were in our area - we had headed previously to Galerie Lafayette along with thousands of other tourists but the best was on our doorstep. Lovely area, alive with the Paris jet set!
All dressed up for Christmas.. Crowds, decorations and concerts all contribute to bring a magical feeling to this lovely and historic area of Paris. Do not miss.

Area with history. A very nice area with many restaurants and famous cafes. Always full are Cafe des Margots and cafe Flore (they are almost neighbours). They are expensive because there always had famous guests. The restaurant Lipp is also very known. We didnot visit it. The reviews are not always possitive.

Great walk. I walked around this neighborhood in the cold rain and didn't mind the weather! The art galleries are very interesting as you walk by - you will see everything! There are also plenty of nice coffee shops or spots for lunch. Great area to explore!

Historic. Les Deux Magots, Cafe de Flore, Lipp, the church on the place. Its all here. Still frequented by a lot of literary bobos and a good place to see and be seen. Invaded by Cartier, Armani, Berlutti so cool for shopping as well.

A must see in Paris !. You are right in the center of historical Paris. You must stroll there, have a drink at one of the famous cafés (Café de Flore or Les deux Magots), enter St Germain des Prés church. This is rtomantic Paris at his finest even though luxury retailers are now preempting the best retail locations. Continue your strolling with Notre Dame, le Marais and Le Louvre and you will most probably fall in love with the city of lights. :-)
Rive Gauche. This area is unrivaled for first-time visitors. The shops are intensely individualistic and show the pride of culture that is part of the reason Paris is a magnet for world travelers.

Hemingway and Fitzgerald could not afford it now. SGdeP is on the Left Bank and very posh, lots of high end shops near the church. Ernest Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald could not get a table at Cafe des Magots today, what with all the tourists . The street is worth the walk. Its an ancient road though you's never know it today, the hot springs at Cluny on SGdeP were used by the ancient Romans long before Paris existed.
Procop;). Saint-German-des-Pres is about history and charm. Walk along it. And at least pass by Procop the oldest bar in France. Voltaire used to sit there they claim;)

Just walk about, look, and have a cafe cream. Although considered touristy by some TA posters, we thoroughly enjoy strolling about Saint Germain, window shop, making a purchase or two often in Le Bon Marche, and enoy many of its charming cafes.
Wonderful music. We were lucky when we visited that there was organ music playing and it was lovely. This is the oldest church in Paris and it is beautiful and worth stopping in.
Best place to hangout in Paris. Find a seat in Cafe de Flore or Les Deux Magots and have a cafe while enjoying Paris. Close to Latin Quarter, Luxembourg and Montparnasse.

Cobble Stone Beautiful!. Wonderful Paris neighborhood! Lots of shops and cafes. Worth taking a walk through. Love the cobble stone streets. Shop vendors are very friendly - and it seemed mostly everyone spoke English!
Heart of Paris. This is a busy area with Called the heart of Paris. Great cafes and shops.Alot of locals in this area

great area. good area to stay in. tons of cafes, shops, within walking distance to everything; no crowds and the area was well-lit at night and felt very safe. Traffic is awful, but we don't drive in Paris anyway...

A Favorite. One of my favorite chapels in Paris...it is quiet and not that visited however it is of significant value on many levels. First it is one of the oldest buildings standing in Paris...the first stone was laid in 543. Second if you have the time to come to one of the many concerts you will be amazed by the intimacy of the venue. But more than all of that is the amazing paintings and decorative painting on the columns. Definitely give it a look.
loved it!. The bistro at the end was a wonderful place with delicious pastries and coffee so we could recap our favorite aspects of Saint-Germain

A lazy Sunday afternoon. On my most recent trip to Paris I spent hours wandering the cobbled pavements of Saint Germain des Pres and I was mesmorised with how beautiful and truly Parisian it was.The streets are quaint, quiet and shops are not aimed primarily at tourists which is great for people like me who love to get away from the crowds and explore the lesser known areas.So if you've ticked off the top tourist areas, head down to Saint-Germain for something different!

Lovely place for a walk. if you like to feel Paris, I recommend a few hours walk there and a dinner/ lunch in one of the small cafe there.try the ice cream shop Grom, the have an amazing hot chocolate and very good ice cream
I want to live here. Didn't want to move to Paris until we visited this neighborhood. It's walkable, interesting, fun. Just a real neighborhood in Paris. Loved it
Wonderful Part of Paris. Wandering these streets is a joy. The shops, the Cafe's. I really couldn't find anything wrong except for the small sidewalks and smokers, but that is Paris.

A stroll down Parisian history. Strolling down Saint-German-des-Pres introduces you to the history of Parisian bohemian culture. Now, with many chic stores, wonderful cafes, the street life of Paris is blooming.

Saint-Germain-des-Pres is my favorite neighborhood in Paris. We love taking the subway to Saint-Germain-des-Pres. When you come out of the subway the church is right in front of you and it is so pretty. Lovely little restaurants and cafes in the neighborhood.
You must walk it!. One of my most favorite parts of Paris, is this area. Just a stroll along the shops boutiques, and cafés. This is what Paris is all about!
Our favorite area in paris. A great and safe neighbourhood to walk around in for shopping and the trendiest restaurants to eat at.

Nice part of the city. We stayed just minutes away from De pres and lovely road's around where you can shop in boutiques, see St Sulpice, and people watch in a cafe outside whilst having some lovely food and drink.. what more do you want....

Great Location. This was my first trip to Paris, and we rented an apartment in St. Germain for the week. It is a fantastic location. We were able to walk to nearly everything. We walked to the Louvre, the Tuileries and the Arc d'Triumphe. The walk, one way, is about 2-2.5 miles. Notre Dame and Sainte Chapelle are less than a 10 minute walk. On top of the proximity to these sights, the best part is that St. Germain has dozens of cafes and restaurants, so you can easily walk for any meal. It is also a very safe area. My only caution to visitors is not to watch for the "gold ring scam". This happened to us 3 times in our 7 day visit, though more along the Seine, near the Louvre. I don't know exactly what the goal is (though if you google it there are several opinions), but someone acts as thought they have found a gold ring - looks like a man's wedding band - and tries to give it to you. Do NOT engage in conversation, and completely ignore them. Whether they are looking for money or have an accomplice waiting to try and pick off your wallet, beware. Nothing happened to us since we suspected a scam the first time, ignored them and walked away. It was almost comical when the exact same thing happened two additional times!

Lovely neighbourhood. Not sure if it's as intellectual as it apparently once was, but the small streets and boutiques do make for splendid meandering and people-watching. Make sure you visit Paris' oldest church, the Eglise SGDP.
nice area. Nice area for a cofee, take a break.And perfect to have so good jazz music on evenig.Just walk in and see... and dont forget to enjoy

Beautiful area for sightseeing, shopping and eating!. I had a brilliant day in this area with a visit to the ancient church, a crepe for lunch, bought a shirt for my husband at the Racing Metro rugby store and visited the Kiloshop with my cousin for some vintage clothes shopping.

Just wander. A lovely area to walk - just wander and discover great boutiques, wonderful patisseriers, small, narrow old streets, open squares. As you go you'll will come upon many cafes where you can stop and have a coffee or a drink, rest yourself and watch Paris.
een leuke wijk. that is a small area which full of coffee and restaurants around it. A beautiful building a nice place to look around and take a rest inside of this nice place.

Typical parisien. This a nice neighbourhood to walk and sit on cafes and watch parisiens talking and drinking, u can find there a branch of the relais de l entrecote restaurant which is not busy as the champselyses branch, also near by the famous bertillon ice cream is sold , u can walk along the seine to go to saint michel and motre dame area too

Trendy Area. Saint-Germain is a trendy area in Paris that has a number of nice pubs and restaurants. If you are looking for a good area for shopping there are a ton of boutiques.My fiancee and I spent a few hours just roaming around the Saint Germain area for a few hours and it really gave us the impression that it is more of an older sophisticated crowd.

changing times. although this area as changed alot in the passing years, i think it is still worth a visit, someone once said if you were bored with saint germain then you were bored with life. the church is a wonderful example of gothic architecture

Wonderful atmosphere. Loved walking around the Saint Germain area, the art galleries and shops are so interesting. Also wonderful pastries and all sorts of great cafes. Sat in a lovely little park where the park benches are made from sculptured books - amazing.

Details and Aromas. This is one delicious and visually beautiful neighborhood. it's so unforgettable as everything is a unique find, the small arched hidden spaces as well as the people watching in every cafe.

Very central but fairly governmental. We styed in this area, near the Musee d'Orsay. There are a lot of antique shops and you are very near the Seine. It is easy to get anywhere else on the Metro - we went in the evenings to the Sorbonne area and to the Marais. We loved walking down the Rue Jacob. The pastry shop on the corner of St. God!!

What a lovely neighborhood!. St. Germain is the most expensive neighborhood in Paris for residents, and it shows. It has all the beautiful features that make Paris memorable, with none of the trash. It also has some beautiful and historically important churches, like St. Sulpice and St. Germain.

I can walk forever. If you are a people watcher, a celebrity -spotter, window shopper, foodie, history buff, literary nut, old hippie, or are on the leading edge of all things cool, this should be your Paris stomping ground. In the morning, take your breakfast at the bold name cafes or right down Rue Buci while the morning market is in full swing. Wander in and out of every type of small shop, then settle down for some serious people watching (along with some freebie street entertainment) and figure out how to explain missing your plane back home. Choices for fantastic dining in all price ranges make this an area that you should spend many hours exploring.
Great area!. Love the feel of St. Germain ! Great shopping , lots of people . Must go to Cafe de Fleur to sip champagne and people watch! Love Petite Zinc for dinner. Just a great area!

Best neighborhood in Paris!. This neighborhood was quintessentially Parisian. Tons of little cafes and shopping that can be found nowhere else. It is also within walking distance of many interesting sites.When I return to Paris, I will stay in this neighborhood.

A good place for a Sunday walk and lunch. Away from the metro and the famous name cafes there are some lovely boutique shops and restaurants. Well worth a leisurely stroll and a stop-off for lunch. Try the Cafe de Paris.

Energy, liveliness, shops and cafes galore. A do not miss area. Shops, churches, cafes, people watching and a change to imagine what it was like when ex-pat Americans writers and artists lived here in the 20s. One of my favorite parts of Paris.

An Iconic Neighborhood. Don't miss this fascinating part of Paris. If you enjoy the world of writers, painters, Existentialists and philosophers, this was their old stomping ground in Paris. Don't miss it!

Food, Shopping, & daily Parisian City Life. Before going to Paris (first time) I had no idea what to expect from Saint Germain. Everyone kept telling me it was all about food and shopping. My first night with friends I walked around at night and ate at a small sandwich shop. This place is great- it has everything and is a great place to go see & meet Parisians (and other tourists). The Cafe's are all close to each other, there is an ice cream and frozen yogurt shop that are great, there is plenty of entertainment to see too. The Latin Quarter is very close to it, too. I went again in the afternoon and the area was very cool. Theres a lot of cute stores to go do some shopping.

Great for Shopping & Dining. This area as well as St-Germain-des-Pres blvd, has a TON of shopping and places to eat. This is also home to the 6th arrondissmont part of the Latin Quarter. Be careful though, in that part of St-Germain lies many pick-pocketers in the form of little Romanian girls. I fell victim to a little girl who stole my iPhone right off the table in front of me. Besides that particular incident, this area is great for shopping and taking in the very Parisian way of living.
one of our favorite areas in Paris. this area never disappoints us. Nice boutiques, very good cafés and bistros, not the usual Paris traffic....

Great Walk on the Left Bank. Great place to have a walk.The streets are filled with expensive shops where the vitrines are always amazing to look at, but also little chic parisian shops (cheaper but still very fit in the scenario).Don't miss the famous Café de Flore, classical...Keep walking down to Jardin du Luxembourg and stop for lunch in Rue Mouffetard (already in Latin Quartier): the restaurants have menus where entrance, plate and dessert are included and the prices are very affordable!
Wonderful area!. My choice in Paris where one should stay. Upscale area near all tourist attractions with many hotels, shops and cafes to fill your days. Lovely to walk through and explore.
old paris, upscaled. likes - general feel of the area (Hemmingway wandered around here) Cafe du Flore , Laduree (macaroons) among othersdislikes - prices high, but expected

The hip place to be in. St Germain lacks nothing and offers everything. Chic shops of all kinds. Cafes and bakeries all over. Restaurants everywhere. Metro right there and it touches the Latin Quarter which is a happening place to stroll around. St Germain stays up late!!!

A bustling area. This is a fascinating area to walk around. It is interesting to see all the old cafes with their literary associations and it is worth going down the side streets. We visited the Saint Surplus church, which featured in the Da Vinci code by Dan Brown and the astronomical line can be seen! The St Germaine des Pres church is worth a quick visit as it is the oldest in Paris but not particularly spectacular.

I love. St Gemain is a very good quarter to stay in Paris. Many restaurants, bars, people in the streets until late. Good for walking, and not far from everything you need to see. You have Deux Magots, Cafe de Flore, for a Champagne, The Beau Marche for gourmet food. Is a good adress for rent an apartment

Great historical site but.... It's very, very dark and restoration is ongoing. Cameras of any sort will be mostly useless. Still, this is one of the most important historical sites on the right bank and well worth a quick visit.

A street of many personalities and tourist possibilities!. Of course there is the great corner with the period cafes at Rennes and St. Germain but the street has many other personalities both directions to the Seine! It is romantic and vibrant and do do expect to see some celebrities at the famous corner on the weekend!!

We just love this area. We just returned, it is a perfect location to com and go, you can shop, eat, people watch and head to all the major areas. We walked everywhere and would break at a cafe or go back to the hotel.
My favorite neighborhood in Paris. Just walk around, look into shops that interest you, there are so many to choose from. Lots of galleries, restaurants, bars, and antiques to delight the eye.

Something for everyone. Plenty of great shopping, loads of great eateries and bars, what's not to like...
And for something completely different, we did enjoy the closing off of sections of the street for five or so minutes to allow hundreds & hundreds of roller bladers through.
Feels like an old home. I stayed here in my 29s and in my 50s it still feels like an old friend, I love to stroll the streets to enjoy the cafes and shops. This is still a favorite.

Beautiful area. Lots of nice restaurants and stores for shopping in a beautiful historic neighborhood.
Metro stop places you right where you need to go

Saint Germain Area. It is a wonderful area, we stayed in the Rue du Bac area, more residental, which we liked..and when we return will stay there again or on Ille Saint Louis.. Saint Germain, is just wonderful and probably the best area in the city of Paris to stay or Ile Saint Louis..easy to get around, lots of places to eat, all different prices, shops..just the best!
Lunch at Cafe Varenne. Excellent food and very friendly waiter, who spoke English. We recommend the steak tar tar and salad nicoise.
More relaxed than the beaten tourist track. Great restaurants, bars & patisseries. Verges on the Latin Qtr. Not so busy so very pleasant to walk around and relax.

Becoming very upscale.. Wow, have they cleaned up, gentrified and prettified this area in the past twenty years. The Deux Magots looks like Maxims (well, almost.) Really high end shopping has moved in. It still has the slightly bohemian ambiance--Juliette Greco would not weep for what was.

Great location, central to whole city. My husband and I were happy we stayed in the area. Just down the street from Notre Dame, it's an easy walk or Metro ride to wherever we wanted to go. Tons of restaurant options as well.

Shopping. Second visit to this area and liked the shopping and the pubs for après shopping! Had some difficulty with one store for 'testing' a product that looked like a tester to this American but apparently wasn't. Learned my lesson. 😕

Should have spent more time here. Excellent area to window shop and stop at one of the hundreds of cafes. Very trendy area, but there is still something for everyone. A good area for a hotel so that you can be within walking distance of so many good and affordable restaurants
Chic Shopping. We love Saint Germain Des Pres lovely cafes, furniture shops and of course clothes shops. Have a street crepe on the move they are especially nice in this area.
Great area. Every time you end up in the City of Lights you will be drawn back to this Bohemian area. Take the metro and just get lost!

The heart of the true Paris.. In my opinion this is the neighbourhood which expresses all the charm of Paris.
Cafes, bistros, restaurants and much more in a very pretty and preserved area.
Great atmosphere. incredible neighborhood! Plenty of charming streets and boulevards, cafés, restaurants, stores, street musicians playing great music. It's my favorite Paris neighborhood.
great neighborhood. Great area for hotels, shopping, restaurants etc. Good Metro connections. Our French is pretty bad and we found that we could get along well here.

Over run with tourists. The Times Square of Paris. Parisians don't come near this place. Strictly for tourists with poor food and high prices. It IS good for having a beer or glass of wine, especially if you can score an outside seat and watch the world go by. The shops are filled with clothes (mostly Asian imports) that you can purchase in any store anywhere. I'm constantly amazed how many people come here thinking this is the "real" Paris.

Great for trendy boutiques and narrow streets. We stayed at the Hotel Perle in this district and enjoyed it thoroughly. Shops are trendy and expensive. But the streets are among the oldest in town, and fully capture the charm and magic of ancient Paris.

a memory of the true Paris. Lucky, Paris still have st Germain des Pres. The rest of Paris is under threat of disappearing. Of course the monuments and landmarks are still there , all invaded by tourists , but the true inner suburbs are all but gone, except St Germain des Pres. There at least , you feel you can walk along the few streets and sit at a cafe in a french fashion or shop in quaint little shops . Everywhere else in Inner Paris, this Paris life style have totally gone or been trashed under wholesale import or tourist catering so called restaurants. St Germain des Pres is at the origin of the true heart of Paris and the french people and hopefully will be able to remain so. And then there is the superb old basilique which was the first of the great churches built in Paris in the middle ages. St germain des Pres is a true reminder of the real Paris

My favorite street in Paris. I have been traveling to France for the past 10 years and at least 2 x a year. SGP is my favorite street. Full of really great restaurants, fresh food markets and a few great speak easy bars.

A lovely area to walk through or to sit at a bistro or cafe and enjoy. Just the best place to sit with a glass of wine or a cup of good coffee and people watch. Interesting shop windows, lovely variety of reasonably priced food, so many different people from different places. Do it!

The real Paris. What you would want, and expect in Paris, street artists, the heart of the Paris one reads about, with the Louvre, Musee d"Orsay and many other attractions, or just sit with a coffee, and watch Paris go by.

Bustling, Young Vibe. Have stayed here several times and always love the hustle and bustle and the students who provide life to the area. Cafes and brasseries make for wonderful food, as do the small shops for bread, pastries, etc. Lots of fun!

An oasis in the bustle of Saint Germain. Powerful Romanesque and early Gothic capitals, painted - perhaps strangely to modern eyes - dark colours. The interior thus has an authentic medieval richness.

Great Place to stay. We rented an apartment in Saint-Germain-des-Pres in the Spring. We were a long block from the Seine on Rue dauphineand had everything we needed within a block or two. Pont Neuf was our crossing over to the right bank. Very lively at night. On the day we left we had a an early pick up and at 5 am there were still young people on the streets heading home I assume. I would stay in this area again.

Lovely area. This is a really nice area to just walk around and shop and eat. More Parisian feeling that tourist hot spots and some amazing boutiques with unique items together with some of the more well known stores too.Try and spend a while there so you can really enjoy it at your own pace and stop at some great cafes along the way
dissapointed. expecting bohemian, more like Knightsbridge. Good views of the seine. Great if you want expensive chocolate or unusual gifts
Typical. Typical Parisian area, with small bistrots restaurants and cafès. Enjoy the vibrant nightlife of the Ville Lumière in this fabulous area!

A Great Neighbourhood!. We really liked this area. After visiting Musee D'Orsay, we walked around, found Rodin's former home and than went to a cafe to people watch. You feel more among the locals here than in Les Halles.

Hip and low key at the same time. Such a pleasant place to stay and hang - just skip the Champs-Elysee entirely. The scene is fun and food is great. The shops are unique and galleries nice. Just wander and absorb... A lovely Parisian experience!!

Love the French Quarter. Unless you experienced the hustle and bustle of the French quarter you haven't been to Paris yet. Experience Deux Margot or Le Flore, the cafes even though the price for the drinks are expensive. To see and be seen. Walk around the noisy Rue Jacobs and quieter L'Universite street.

cool place. just a great vibrant part of Paris to walk around & people watch
Bustling & great bars in the area. Don't miss it

This is Paris!. It really is hard to chose a favourite area of Paris, but if we had to, this probably would be it. We have stayed here four times and always want to return; the architecture is wonderfully typical of Paris, the shops are great (goodness only knows how so many make a living, but I'm not complaining) but best of all is the opportunity to people-watch, in style & comfort, at one of the many cafe bars. Love it & never tire of it. Cannot wait for our next trip & only just back home!
The Best of Paris. We LOVE this little area of Paris and visited it four times during our trip to shop and dine. There is also a great night scene, especially on Saturdays.

One of my favourite parts of Paris.... Paris is great with its museums,monuments,parks,but when you want just to walk,enjoy and feel the city,Saint-Germain-des-Pres is a great choice.There are also other fantastic parts of Paris,but this is one of my favourites.With its shops and stores of every kind,famous cafes,nice churches,restaurants,it is really great neighbourhood.It is tourist popular area,very live and interesting.My wife and I spend one afternoon there,and loved it very much,especially Saint Germain boulevard.That is Paris I dreamt about...

Lots of Energy. This is an area of Paris that has a ton of energy and action going on at all times. We spent most evenings having drinks or eating here. Cafe Mabillon is a great spot in the area which is excellent for people watching.

My favorite part of Paris. The 6th arrondissement aka saint Germaine des pres is a charming very approachable neighborhood on the left bank. Little boutiques, cafes, bistros, patisseries, boulangerie, chocolate shops, bookstores line the little streets and squares. Saint Suplice and Saint Germaine desPres are gorgeous Gothic churches. Sometimes there are organ recitals in these churches that are wonderful. It is area that is lively, not overly grand in scale, close to the Luxembourg gardens, Notre Dame, Musee d'Orsay, everywhere really. And if you don't want to walk, there are several convenient metro stops.

really nice. walking through SGP streets looking for some place for dinner just feeling free of the pressure of the clock, just take your time and get lost in this wonderfull neighborhood and find some little restaurant and enjoy
Paris as I thought it would be. We wandered the charming streets, had cafe stops and shopping ventures and so much ambling, arm in arm. Heaven!
must talk a walk. through rue paris st germain! it has a lot of cool stores caffes and so on, very atmospheric and typical paris. defintly a must see!

You cant be hungry here !. This is a very nice arr, this neighborhood is very near the seine river. Great restaurants and lots of locals are in this area. Come down blvc saint germain untill you reach blvd st michel, there you are..a lively area full of restaurants, bars and cafes ! Enjoy !!!
Just sit and watch Paris happening. Superb bars and cafes to break up the shopping and sightseeing. Then as it starts to get dark all the brasserie lights come on and the busy-ness continues
Lovely area of Paris.. Beautiful area of Paris with small streets and all different kinds of shops and cafes. Would recommend a walk around the area for sure.
What a great walking neighborhood. Terrific place to eat, shop, relax, people watch, spend your euros, don't forget to go east to the Latin quarter while there

Very Pricy, But A Lovely Walk. Unless you are a "one-percenter", this is just a lovely walk and an opportunity for some world-class window shopping. There used to be some interesting shops, with occasionally fabulous sales. But I didn't see any of that this time.

Old Paris in the modern world. This particular neighborhood, centered around the oldest church in Paris, never fails to entertain and to remind one of the many famed individuals who made it their haunt in the 20th century. Saint German-des-Pres offers some of the very best people-watching in the city and some of the most famous cafes in life and in literature.
A Modest Ancient Abbey. My favorite church in all of Paris, for its age and simplicity. People started building this church within a hundred years of the fall of the Roman Empire.

Cosmopolitan and full of energy!. Shop, eat, repeat! Loaded with cafes, shops, and pretty people! Grab a spot at one of the top cafes/bistros such as Cafe de Flore or Le Deux Magot and people watch for a few hours!

A great street to roam .... A wonderful street on which to roam and people watch ... especially the rich Americans and Russians and Japanese. There are many designer shops and cafes when you need a break or a glass of wine.

Paradise. Our favorite spot in Paris, what an amazing place to stay. Handy to just about everywhere, great choice of restaurants, fantastic shopping and my wifes favorite, the patissieres, what a choice. From sitting in a side walk bar people watching to fine dining in world class restaurants, the choice is yours.
Lovely and trendy area.. Nice and safe area. A nice little market. Good bistros. Lots of interesting shops and boulangeries, hotels etc. Easy to get a taxi or metro. Able to walk to the Louvre/Orsay.
A place with a lot of atmosphere. This place has always been on our - must do - when in Paris. This is a place to relaxe and watch people around you

endless places to see. What an amazing street to visit. There are endless cafes, restaurants, boutiques, and bars.But let's not forget the fabulous chocolate & patissiere shops.
The choices are endless, it was hard to make a decision about what to eat!
Wonderful atmosphere. Great place to go at night, lots of restaurants, bars etc.Street entertainment , just a great place to go and sit and have a drink and watch the world go by.

This area on the left bank is full of life and variety. It has everything from food to hotels to boutiques. Take a stroll along any street in St. Germain and you will enjoy yourself immensely - day or night. There are dozens of sidewalk cafes at which you can have a beer or coffee and spend a long time just people watching. There are probably hundreds of restaurants of every type and in every price range. This is my favorite part of Paris. When you are there, be sure to visit Rue Mouffetard to see the markets, shops, and many little but outstanding restaurants.

Pricey shopping. This area is filled with all kinds of shopping - something for everyone if you have the money. Most of the shops are very upscale but a kick to visit. Be careful - you need to know your prices. Many items were available elsewhere for less money. Be sure to visit the food hall of the Bon Marche department store - especially if you love to cook.

Perfect place to watch the world. Soak up the atmosphere of paris whilst remembering the history and walk in the footsteps of gear philosophers and writers. Last time saw cantona- this time just beautiful people and warm September sunshineCafe de flore and brasserie lipp both a must

Got lost in this labyrinth. Great shops, tiny ancient streets, fabulous cafes, restaurants, this is Paris at it's best. Avoid the tourist trap centre streets and head out a little further towards the Sorbonne for great chocolateries and patisseries to die for.

Fabulous, chic, lively neighborhood in central Paris.. Lots of chi-chi shops we couldn't afford and lots of great cafes, bars and patisseries to enjoy. Very lively, safe area - rather like upper east side of NYC.

An amazing morning outside Paris just 30 Min by RER train away. Lovely town with nice sorta Castle and park just a simple metro ride away. Can relax stroll have a pastry and be back in time to make any museum.
Always so atmospheric. Great place, always so much going on through the narrow winding streets, beautiful! There are so many cafes and places of interest, you could wander the streets for hours.

Worth a wander. The 'arty' area, apparently frequented in days gone by by the likes of Jean Paul Sartre, Hemingway etc, it does give them the right to charge higher prices, (two coffees ten euro), but I imagine it's more reasonable off the main streets. L'Eglise de Saint-Germain is one of the oldest churches in Paris, and worth a look (it's free), and the cafe to visit is Les Deux Magots.

My favorite neighborhood. I love St. Germaine. I have stayed in this area on both my trips to Paris, once at Le Bellechasse and once at Hotel Verneuil. The reason I love it is it doesn't feel as touristy as some areas, but it has tons of cafes and shops. Getting around is easy because of all the metro stops. It's just the perfect atmosphere. If I were to live in Paris, I would live here.

Best area in Paris.. We chose our hotel to be in this area and we were not disappointed. There are so many cafes and interesting walks around this area. You get a feel of everyday life more than some of the other tourist areas.
wonderful atmosphere. St Germain is full of cafes, restaurants and bars and is extremely lively but is always safe. It is full of designer shops and little art galleries and interesting people
Wonderful area. Love the St. Germain area. Lots of wonderful bistros and shops amongst the neighborhood stores and houses. A great mix of Parisians and tourists.
oldest church in Paris. This church is in much need of repairs, but be sure not to miss it. Just take some time, sit down and observe the beautiful structure.
Shopoholics Unite. Upbeat, busy shopping! I loved it! The vibe and even just window shopping and cafes give it a special feel.

Essence of Paris. Yup, it gets touristy here and there, and yes, the hustle and bustle can be exhausting, but St. G is one great place to visit, especially if you can escape some of the crowds. So much to do and see. One piece of advice: Find a good local cafe and just sit and watch.

parisian atmosphere!. take a walk at this quartiere.magnificent area!so romantic,near to everything,has a market,has romantic cafes,we sat at a corner one,deu magots,very nice.
one day spend here,for coffee,for lunch,walks in the market and by the Seine river.
one of my favourite places in Paris.
Great area to live in. Everythimg is close by, many markets, restaurants, shops and entertainement. Also an easy walk to 1st arrondissement.

Beautiful St Germain. Paris is a beautiful city, but we love the St Germain des Pres area the best. Great streets, restaurants, shopping, churches and friendly people. Very artsey.
We have stayed in this area 4 out of the 5 times we have been to Paris and will again, God willing
Good place to experience. A lot of interesting churches, architecture and gardens, all within walking distance. Le Petite Chalet is a reasonably priced restaurant.

Very trendy!. Lots of stores and places to eat and shop for souvenirs! Loved it!
The shops are not expensive but the food its a bit pricey but then, that is in all of Paris!

Interesting, Old and Musty. You get a sense for how old this church is as soon as you enter the doors. The interior stone work has not been restored probably in centuries, so there is the dark, mustiness. It is well worth visiting.

My favorite. This was my favorite neighborhood, both for shopping and dining at night and day. The night section was very hip, and young with many many restaurants. Wear comfortable shoes, and watch the hills..
Great place to hangout and watch the world go by. This is Parises - Cafes, boutiques, Churches, student life, more cafes, The University...great place to walk and be part of the city
Great area.. I love this neighbourhood. Great people-watching, fabulous shopping and galleries galore. Very safe and fun. Gorgeous!

Dont miss this one. my favourite place in Paris, great cafe everywhere from pastries to top restaurants. Small chic boutiques unique gifts and clothes. Make sure to visit Saint Suplice church, has great book shops and antiques. love the Hotel The bucci on Rue de Bucci small and friendly
gorgeous. The oldest church in Paris, originated in 542 and was a Benedictine Abbey. Has an amazing high roof that is blue and has 6th century marble columns. Very beautiful.
Great vibes. Nice to stroll through and grab a bite to eat at a cafe. Definitely stop at Cafe Lipp. Lots of history behind this place.

I love the 6th Arrondisement!. While getting more touristy every year, I love going back to the 6th arrondisement each time I am in Paris. The museums, parks, cafes, shopping, and nightlife are all so very Parisian. Roam along the Rue de Bac area and people watch from a streetside cafe table. The adroit waiters bound out from the inside bars carrying trays full of drinks without spilling a drop. Have hot chocolate (chocolat chaud) at Paul, it is a revelation.
Beautiful section with great shops and restaurants!. This is a wonderful section for some wonderful sidewalk cafes and shopping as well! Went to the Cafe de Flores for a wonderful cappuchino.

One of the best areas in town. Saint-Germain-des-Pres is fantastic. Studying at Sciences Po, the atmosphere in this part of town is fantastic, with the very lively cafees at the Place, and the extremely upmarket shops along the street.
Eclectic neighborhood. Lots of shops, cafes, also residential. You can get a real taste of real Parisian life staying in this neighborhood. Very nice.

Great Area; where the happenings are. If you want to go to where the happenings are, go to this area of Paris. Food, Drink, People galore into all hours of the night. We are originally from NYC so we felt quite comfortable here. Not the place to be if you don't like crowds.

Wow!. This area comes to life at night when the tables take over the pavement. Waiters try to encourage you in by reading the menu but they take "no" for an answer if you decide not to go in. So many cheap and excellent eating places.

LOVE this neighborhood!. Strolling this street in one of our favorite areas is as important to us as a walk down the Champs Elysees. Famous cafes beg for a stop to sip the cafe...or whatever else may be of interest. And a Parisian ( or Parisian at heart ) always has time to do that. Learn a bit about some of the history & perhaps dip into a few of the books that were written in these storied places; discuss the latest issues & debate the course of the future. Then you'll be doing what made this place the intellectual center. It stil has a certain 'je ne sais quoi' that makes you feel like you are someplace significant.

Fantastic, lively area. One of my favourites in Paris - lots of little shops, restaurants & bistros. Take a walk through the narrow little streets, check out Cafe de Flore on Boulevard St Germain, and enjoy the lively atmosphere of this wonderful area...

The place to be on a fine Paris morning!. Lots of things going on, lots of wonderful cafes and bakeries. You won't be far from the lovely covered food markets and st suplice - please make the effort to visit this great neighbourhood, where every other shop is an art gallery or a cafe :o)

Walking Tour. A day with Catherine Aubin, professional guide, in this area was wonderful. She even took me into the main Cartier store as well as around areas which were Huguenot strongholds 500 years ago. Recommended!

Best neighborhood on the left bank. To me, the 6eme arrondissement of Saint-Germain-des-Pres on the left bank feels quintessentially Parisian: Haussman architecture, small streets intersecting wide avenues, lovely art galleries intertwined with boutiques, cafes, restaurants. A must visit neighborhood in Paris!

Wine waiter !!!!!. Had a meal in this area, wine waiter asked would we like drink, foolishly we didn't ask for list, paid 25euros for 2 glasses of wine!! Unfortunately dont remember restaurant but be aware folks!!!
Great shopping. Great shopping street - even the fast food patisserie was great? Go to the Latin qurter for couscous and street crepes

The place to be. Wonderful feel to this neighborhood with beautiful buildings and interesting shops galore. Add in a number of cafes previously frequented by Hemingway and co and this is the place to stop, shop and take it all in.
The essence of Paris!. If you want to stay and hang out in one area to give you an authentic Parisian experience, you need to spend time in St. Germain de Pres.
Great place for fondue / shopping / bar hopping. We had a fun evening going to different bars for drinks and settling at a cafe for meat fondue while being serenaded by a street band.

This Is The Area To Stay. We stayed at Hotel Left Bank in the heart of St. Germain and the location was terrific! This is an upscale but not overpriced arrondissement with lots of shopping and restaurants. There are some areas that are very touristy, but the "local" areas are plentiful and easily accessible.

Cafes, Parisiene Lifelstye. It's lovely to take int he ambience opf St Germain des Pres.
It is walking distance (althought it is a far walk) to all the major sites of Paris, Notre Dame, the Champ's Elysee, the Arc duTriumph....but it's charm is in wanderingt he streets to find the small cafes and restaurants

Wow!. Spent a lot of evenings here as we loved the great restaurants and the great ambience of just walking and observing everyone eating and having a great time. There were American sidewalk musicians entertaining everyone and you can have your choice of restaurants, ice cream vendors, etc. Just loved it here!
Love this area. I would stay here just to view the architecture. A regular apartment building has charm and beauty. Would adore to live there.

An arrondissement not to be missed. A wonderful upscale area of Paris with cafés, great shops and lots of ambiance. Any type of restaurant is at your feet in this area. There are also grocery and wine stores should your accommodations include a small kitchen. Lots of outdoor cafés means you have your choice of cuisine but keep in mind that smokers love eating and drinking outdoors. A must see part of Paris.

The Abbey of Saint Germain des Pres. This building dates back to approximately 500 and is the oldest in Paris. It was very peaceful to sit and rest in the cool of the ancient stone and ponder the people through the ages that had come to the building for hope, food, or shelter. In my travels, I have found that the best places to visit are those off the 'E" ticket route so to speak. In other words, away from the flocks of tourist. There is so much wonderful history to experience
Lovely neighborhood. We stayed in this area of Paris. There are plenty of cafes and shops around every corner and it is close to many of the major attractions.
historic. lots of history in this church. one could not help but feel this history when inside. would have loved to attend a service.

The genteel side of Paris. After a few years in Le Marais we decided to stay on this side of the Seine this holiday. It is a good change from the busy and fairly crowded Marais. The cafes are slightly more spaced out and the service amazingly efficient and professional, despite the influx of millions of tourists who don't speak French. The trick is to speak 'bonjour' on arrival at a restaurant or cafe and hen wait for the server to come back ith a menu. Then you wait for him to come back to take your order. Please be patient and do make up your mind within about 5 minutes because when he returns he expects you to be ready. Remember, he is serving quite a few tables and can't hang around for you to make up your mind with him at your table. If you relax and respect their system you will love your meal in Paris much more. St Germain has a lovely church, near the few famous cafes like Les Deux Magots, Flore and Lipp. The shops are incredible mainly dotted along Blvd St Germain. Do go to the side streets like Dragon where you will find unique boutiques selling specialty pieces you won't find anywhere else in the world. I still love Le Marais, particularly on Sunday when most shops on the Left Bank are closed.

Really great church but abandoned. Went there to see the church. Outside the church was a drunk guy asking for money. The church itself is in really bad shape. Not clean, dark, not preserved in anty way. It is a shame this is the case. Nothing to see there, no need to waste time to go.

Great neighborhood, classy and historic. I was told by many friends from France that this was the best place to stay when visiting Paris and they were right! Lovely Parisian atmosphere. Very trendy (and pricey!). Great for people watching, cafes and bistros. The main boulevard St. Germain has great shops and historic cafes. Take a stroll at night and it will be very memorable and lovely. We stayed near here and loved it!
antique. this is one of the oldest churches in Paris. it is beautiful, but a restoration is necessary!I watched a beautiful gospel music concert there.

Great area. Wonderful neighbourhood, with many lovely small eateries and cafes providing good value and variety and we had some really good meals...made our trip to Paris really good being positioned in this area.

Absolute Best Place in Town to Stay. We put a lot of research into where we stayed and our apartment in St. German des Pres was well situated. This became our favorite place in Paris, with sidewalk cafes and restaurants, street performers and close proximity to the Seine and other attractions.

It is becoming tackier every year.. I actually booked an apt in this area on what I thought was a lovely street (rue des Canettes) which turned out to have 2 nightclubs opened until 5am.....getting so commercial

Very Parisian. The area of St Gerain was a brilliant choice to stay in. Being in the artists area, we found ourselves excited by the feel and aambience of having lovely cafes and bars lining cobbled streets. This romantic weekend was well worth the trip!
