Cafes. Cafe de Flore et Cafe Deux Magots were fantastic but very expensive. There is a great gift shop next to Cafe de Flore where you can purchase glasses.
Pleasant area to absorb Parisian life. Good to enjoy cafe life and some boutique shopping. The iconic cafes are not much more expensive than the normal Parisian places

Nice area. We staued in this area. I think that this is a more genuine french area. There are less tourist here. St Germain has several good restaurants and cafes. Its has a good metro-connection to all the big sites in town. You can walk here fro the Latin Quarter.

Shop 'til you drop !. The St. Germain des Pres area is quite upscale and crowded with tourists. Not a bad thing at all. The Hotels and restaurants are incredibly trendy (and quite expensive, but worth the experience). There are more small specialty shops that you could possibly visit in a week. But, you should definitely try. The end of June into early July and the end of January into ealy February are their special "Soldes" (sales) dates. You can find unbelievable bargains during this time (at least my wife always does). Great area.

Once a "find", now over-found!. This neighborhood was home to the great writers of the 20's, but now is just crowded with tourists. The great cafes are no longer peopled by anyone but tourists. Sadly, one can no longer imagine long afternoons sipping coffee and writing, as the traffic and chain stores have overwhelmed the area.
Always stay there. a special area of Paris, full of life with resturants, quaint shops, amazing cake shops and florists, a well worth visit.

walking made me wonder.... I visit Paris regularly, and it was some years ago that I last visited this area. When walking there, I noticed it still has the same bohemian chic style atmosphere; with nice shops, little streets, nice cafés... however I was quite shocked by the amount of beggars, homeless and drunks who seem now have moved to this area, especcially in the busier streets.

Here now and it's wonderful. I really like the feel of this eighborhood. Last year I stayed in the 1st arrondissment and enjoyed myself immensely, having stayed at the Hotel du Louvre. This time I chose to be more frugal and rented a one bedroom apartment in Saint-Germain-des-Pres, the 6th arrondissment. So far I've been here only 2 days, and I have to say that the streets are quaint and clean, there are plenty of adorable bistros and very nice restaurants, and plenty of shopping at boutique-type stores. This is a fairly residential neighborhood within walking distance of the right and left banks, as well as Notre Dalm and the Louvre. There is nothing I dislike about this area.
a neighbourhood to experience.. great area to wander and stay. Get into a neighbourhood and feel the day to day life. Fabulous restaurants, cafes and boutiques. Not as touristy as l'opera.
A flanneurs delight!. A wonderful historic area to wander and meander, window shop and drink at a cafe or grab a croissant.
First Time in Paris - Loved the Area. We stayed at Hotel d'Abusson and loved that it was in this neighborhood. It was so charming and near all. Would highly recommend staying in the area.
Paris at it's best!. We stayed in this area and it was fantastic. Everything close to hand, metro, buses etc. Our favorite district when in Paris!
Busy. Seem to be the very typical Paris life.Bustling cafes and lots of laughter, drinking and smoking!Lots of great eats ad shopping.Fun to walk around in the evening.
It has everything. These days - so welcoming. I bought the best dragon skeleton figure for my son in a local toy store, and an wonderful umbrella for my sister. Lovely shopping!
Very interesting location.. Excellent accommodation location with plenty of good shops & cafes. Most attractions within 15-20 minute walk with metro & Hop on Hop off bus if required.

Interesting neighborhood to walk through.. Despite the surfeit of tourists, this a is a nice neighborhood to walk in. There are upscale stores and lots of people out and about at all hours. Many cafes for good people-watching and decent restaurants as well.

Best location to stay in Paris!. We loved St Germaine-des-Pres. Such a lot of character and always buzzing but safe and welcoming. Feels more like being a local than when one is near the Champs Elysees.

Lovely Neighbourhood. Certainly one of my favourite parts of Paris. There you will find a great deal of shops, patisseries, cafés, and the wonderful atmosphere of this good old yet ever changing city. A nice walk from the Museé D'Orsay to the Jardin du Luxembourg is highly recommended!
Lovely Area. If you miss this neighborhood, you've missed the best of Paris. Great restaurants, shops and history.

My favorite neighborhood. I stayed in Paris for 2 months for summer course. I stayed around Trocadero area before because it's easier to go to the school and to go around the right bank. It was nice but then I want to try staying in left bank and I love it. It's very Parisian with its outdoor cafes, little streets, and close to luxembourg garden. Go to Cafe de Flore for thick hot chocolate, great moules en cocotte at L'eon, delicious lunch/ dinner at rue du bac many brasseries. Next trip, I'll choose St Germain des Pres for my hotel (home) base.
Great streets with nice shops. I highly recommend this area as there are a lot of nice shops and is not overcrowded with tourist like the Haussmann area.
Pedestrian friendly. Its a good place to walk around and even better to sit with a drink and people watch. It has the look and feel I always imagined Paris would. To me, it was very French. lol
La Duree. love the macaroons though the line ups for tea are long. it is worth it though. personal favourite is salted caramel.

Love this area. This is one of my favourite neighbourhoods in Paris. Yes, it is touristy but so is most of Paris. There are also many locals who call this area home. It's busy and lively, especially in the afternoons. Don't miss the rue de Seine and rue de Buci area, rue Jacob, around Eglise St-Germain and St-Sulpice. Cafes, restaurants, bistros and bars abound. You are mostly only 2-3 blocks from the Seine. The shopping is great. Finally, it's a fantastic neighbourhood for strolling and taking your time to enjoy Parisian life.

Follow-up on the memorable breakfast at the Croissanterie. This May I went back to the Croissanterie ready to order their expresso (aka fantastic morning starter)... The Croissanterie was closed for renovations and would not open until the day of my flight back.For the rest of you out there who would want to give it a try, I would love to get your feed back if the Croissanterie's Expresso still makes of the daily breakfast a memorable event...Psst.. the place to go for a Salade Nicoise is the Relais de l'Odeon which is upwind from the Croissanterie going towards BoulMich (Boulevard St Michel).Now you have your memorable breakfast place and a fantastic lunch place with its tiny tables at the Relais de L'Odeon...Watching elegant people cruising the boulevard comes at no charge at both cafes...At the end of the day and no matter how and why, Paris will always steal your heart without the slightest warning... and it will probably leave you yearning for more...
lovely neighborhood. we stayed a week in an apartment in this area..very convenient to all things...lovely quiet streets and shopping near by..great eating too!

No longer a moveable feast.. Most visitors 'do' this area because of its connections with Hemingway, Fitzgerald, Nin, and a supporting cast of black-clad Gauloise-smoking flaneurs. That was then, my friends; this is now. T'ain't like that any more. By all means have an overpriced coffee served by rude waiters at the Magots etc, just to tick the box. But don't make a special detour to do so.
Street shopping. Nice to walk around in cool weather in June. As of the other roads in Paris, it's not easy to find your way if you are looking for a particular shop.
Great Location!. Fantastic location close to many things! Great small restaurants near by and fantastic patisseries! Our hotel was nice, room was small, but that's Paris - c'est la vie!
Trendy, expensive, but a great area.... It's a place where you can people watch and write all day. But it's pricey, and after a while it's no fun window shopping.

Favorite area of town. Came across by accident when the train wasn't running through there, beautiful little area and it hosts some great shopping as well as Le Deux Magots. A great cafe on the corner with great ham & cheese as well as a lovely dessert menu.
Wish I gone there sooner. It is so pretty :) we went on a Sunday and a lot of the shops were shut, wish I had ventured there on the Saturday :)
great area to shop and eat. The shops were terrific, and it is a beautiful area to walk around in. We went back there several times during our seven day stay.
Avoid the restaurants with photos of food. .....and walk into smaller less crowded streets. St Germain is a mix of tourist traps and smaller special shops. If lucky one finds the right mix.

The place I want to live. I just love this part of Paris. It has a more relaxed feel than the other side of the river and seems less overun by tourists. Love the book stores, antique furniture and clothing stores, proximity to Notre Dame, Rue Cler, Le Quatier Latin, and La Seine. The architiectual details on the buildings in this area are especially beautiful. I never stayed on this side on the river on my previous visits, but I plan on doing so on my next.
Fun part of Paris. Loved just meandering through this area, and loved the shopping! Great restaurants too. Fun shops, fun people to watch.

Busier, Brighter, but still local. It's a place to discover, to walk around safety and explore. Your close to the gardens, great cafes, good people watching and some good shops, don't miss a morning at rue de Buci for some marketing, and breakfast.
Very alive atmosphere. This is a great place to stay in Paris, close to all tourist attractions, lots of eateries,close to River and a great atmosphere.

Chic, Parisienne, boutiquey!. I loved St-Germain-des-Pres - just the right mix of cafe culture, bohemian crafts and boutiquey shops. A totally different character to the centre of Paris (i.e. Rue de Rivoli) and the kind of typical lovely French atmosphere that you would want. Commercial, but unspoiled.

Crowded, varied and worth visiting.. People watching, shopping, window shopping and siteseeing. Some very classy premises, old buildings, modern cafes and interesting eateries - but always crowded and busy and not much space on the pavements.

For a real parisian experience. A great area to wander around the streets. Lots of boutique shopping. We walked through at night and there were lots of little restaurants with locals and just a beautiful part of Paris

A true shopper's mecca!. This fabulous neighborhood boasts the best shopping in Paris, both for travelers on a budget and those seeking high end designer finds. Also within walking distance of Odeon and St. Michel, both of which boast a vivacious nightlife.
Great area to walk. Walk around Rue Buci and see the cafes,shops and market. Delightful part of Paris
We loved staying here!. It was such a fun scene -- many cute shops, restaurants, cafes, bistros and bars. Every place along the way was a joy.

The Paris of Simone de Beauvoir and Jean-Paul Sartre.. Just walking around here takes you to another time. Even if you don't go in, stand outside Cafe Deux Magots and absorb it. The church of Saint-German des Pres is also worth visiting. Very historic and it seems like a relevant parish to this day.
See and be seen. It's so much fun walking around Saint-Germain-des-Près! Go and see the BCGB!
Quaint Paris. Great restaurants and shops, many things to choose from, traffic can be a problem
Best Shopping. For all the shopaholics, this should be on your must see list. Small shops, full of unique finds from young designers. I love this area of Paris.
Our favorite neighborhood!. Awesome place to walk around and feel the streets of Paris while checking out cafes, street performers, people watch, and just chill out from sight seeing.

My absolute favorite arrondisement in Paris!. I love Paris and find all the neighborhoods to have something about them that I like. But Saint Germain for me feels like home. I really enjoy the ambiance with all the cafes, galleries, the people, etc. There's something about the mood there that I find welcoming and that I seem to connect with. The atmosphere is lively especially at night and there always seem to be something interesting going on in this district. Thumbs up for Saint Germain des Pres!
Very Germain. Lots of fun to shop, grab a bite to eat and enjoy the people watching.

Complete with an accordion player. We wandered every day and took hundreds of pictures. It is so beautiful you want to just keep exploring. One evening we came upon an accordion player who was playing a typical French tune........ we felt like time had stood still and it was 100 years ago.

The Best District to stay. Alwayus stay here now, bored with Ch Elysee,Rue du Rivoli etc this is the real Paris, Paris with Parisiens, Great Restaurants Shops and Bars, Stay a couple of metros away around M Convention and enjoy.
St Germaine. We loved the area! Safe, fun for shopping, dining and just walking.
best place to go to eat. thsi is the best area where you can eat in Paris without going broke.

Great location to shop and eat. This neighborhood has tons of shops, restaurants and bars. I think this is the best place to stay in Paris if you're up to 50 years old. If you're older, go during the day and dinner, but don't get a hotel there!

superb. great place to visit
one of the best area's in paris mont mart is stunning of course
lots to do lots to see fabulous cafe's and restaurants
LE PETITE ZINC is a must to dine in book as you may not get a table seafood out of this world as is all else on the menu

Enjoy!. This is one of the very coolest parts of Paris, filled with activity, great sidewalk cafés, shops, students and the occasional treasure (I was there once and found a plaque indicating that it was the spot where the treaty ending the American Revolution was signed). Not to be missed!

The only place to stay. By far, my favourite area of Paris. The streets are packed with interesting shops, great restaurants and atmospheric bars and cafes. It is also a great place to base yourself because almost all of the main tourist attractions are walkable and there is easy access to the rest (Pigalle, Monmartre) by metro.

I have spent 43 years staying in this arrondisment when i visit paris.. When i go to paris i roam. i am not a foodie so am not helpful there and i do not dine at places simply because of their name.I often walk between 10-12 hours a day and am never bored. as i am often alone i feel totally safe and can run out at any hour should i need something.There are lovely small hotels that (this is a joke anywhere in the world, now) that are affordable, clean and the staff are friendly and extremely helpful. the hotel i stay at (i am not telling!!!) lets me bring my own coffee (fairway, nyc) and allows me to keep cheese, fruit, etc. in their refrigerator.If you walk into any establishment and are polite - Bonjour! is a good start.As i am alone a vast percentage of the times i visit paris i frequently get restaurants that want to seat me behind an open door or next to the swinging kitchen door - i was born with an ability to say NON! and i am seated like a Poodle (they prefer their dogs to people) a the Bon Chic Bon Chiens always always come first. I met an american couple who told me they loved their dog - whom was seated at a chair at their table - more than their children.To stay in this area you have two choices - to act like a rude tourist or simply relax and blend in.I love it, otherwise, why would i go there so often?
Fewer tourists. It was a great shopping district minus the hoards of tourists on Champs Elysees, Galleries Lafayette, rue du Faubourg Saint- Honore, etc.
Lose Yourself. What a fabulous area to walk around or hire a bike and cycle around. Great little street shopping and cafes.
cafes. lots to see, walking around and people wathching and loving all the cafes.

Shoppers paradise. Excellent collection of mid-high range shops in the heart of the 6th arrondisement (BoBo = Bourgeois-Bohemian district)... Personal recommendations include Arty Dandy for fashion accessories, La Hune bookstore, IKKS, Zadig & Voltaire, Pom D'Api, Repetto shoes, Cafe Deux Magots, and of course the famous Le Bon Marche department store (and its fabulous gourmet food dept). There is also a Pierre Herme outlet nearby for the best macarons in Paris!

Beautiful walk down historic district. Very Parisian, lots of cafes (Deux Magot and Florian are landmark literary cafes) chocolate shops like Laduree right by the area, boutiques, and a side street with little Italian restaurants. Very picturesque and historic. Oldest church in Paris right across from Deux Magots and worth a quick visit though not a destination church.
My favorite area. We shopped, strolled and cafe' watched in the area on my latest trip. I fell back in love with Paris with the help of the ambience of this part of the city.
Loved the Saint Germain church too. Eat or have a drink at sidewalk cafe and people watch.
So much to see!. Cool area of Paris - very medieval architecture - be sure to visit Abbey Saint-Germain des Pres, one of the oldest Churches in France, we were completely in awe!
Great fun area. Great atmosphere and visitor friendly. Lots to do, and places to eat, shop and be in awe of.

Charming neighborhood with great shopping, restaurants. We wandered the neighborhood and found so many shops to peek into and explore. There are some of the most high level shopping, as well as many boutiques. There are many historical sites as well. If going to Paris, spend a day wandering here - you will not be disappointed.

Worth walking through. A very historic area with the church of the former Abbey Saint-Germain des Pres and the association with Jean Paul Sartre and the existentialists is certainly worth visiting and spending a few minutes taking in. More popular now because of the nearby shopping and the famous cafes on the corner which are apparently a much-coveted hot-spot for people watching. The local Parisians I encountered on my trip advised to not bother eating in the area and to pass it by for a more enjoyable cafe experience somewhere else. Which is what I did, and I have no regrets about not spending time at the cafes here.
although more touristic than 3 years ago, still a hit!. I rented and apartment for 8 days in the heart of St german-des-pres and enjoy the neighborhood as a truly parisian - fantastic!!!!
Nice area. A very nice and elegant neighborhood with good but pricey hotels, a great location.
not the latin quarter but.... most see during ur trip to paris but expensive not quite as nice as the latin quarter

Best Place to base your trip. This is my second time to stay in this area-once in a hotel, once in an apartment. I think it is the most central place to stay..easy access to transportation, walk out the door for shops and restaurants etc. One of the most interesting areas in Paris...cafe watching just superb here. Will stay here again and again
restaurants! pubs!. great area for restaurants and pubs. in 8 days we went there 3 evenings!
The place to be. Good restaurants lower prices and fab ambience so go now

One of the oldest churches in Paris. With so many churches to see, it is hard to rate which are the best. Since this is one of the oldest, it is worth seeing. The neighborhood also happens to have great restaurants and shops.
Beautiful. This is a lovely place to wander and then stop for a pastry. Very expensive shops but fun to browse through
Vibrant area, lots of restaurants. Busy, busy but fascinating - a must-see in Paris. Enjoyed le Petit Zinc for lunch, unhurried and good food with plenty of atmosphere.

This is the Paris you dream about. We were fortunate enough to stay in this area on one of our trips to Paris. If you can - do -- if you can't, at the very least spend a good long afternoon walking around the shops and cafes. You won't regret it. If you close your eyes and think of life in Paris --- odds are this is what you will see.
wonder about. you have to go into this area, cobbled streets, narrow and ready to meet all your wants. GREAT LITTLE CAFES, BISTROS, ICE CREME PLACES. Night brings music and mingling

Bustling, Lively Paris!. We spend a ton of time walking in St. Germaine.You can make your way from the Musee d'Orsay through the Musee Rodin and Musee d'Army over to the Eiffel Tower and the Trocadero.It's a long walk but totally worthwhile.Restaurants are too numerous to count and we never had a bad meal.Check out L'Epi Dupin, it was excellent. I posted a review for that restaurant as well.

A boemian part of Paris!. It´s the neighborhood that I love the most! Just relax and leave Paris welcomes you to the city... After a long journey watching spectacular views, go have a great dinner in the cozy restaurants and after go to a bar and drink a good champagne with the ones you love or by your own! I am definetly sure that will be the best memories that you will have from Paris!

Saint-Germain-des-Pres. Saint-Germain-des-Pres is a quintessential Paris neighborhood. It has sidewalk cafes, historic churches, trendy shops and cinemas. In Paris, people watching is always one of the top past times. You won't find many better places to do it than here. The core of the neighborhood is the three historic cafes: Les Deux Maggots, Cafe de Flore and Brasserie Lipp. All three of them are within feet of each other and are places to see and be seen.
The oldest one!. Amazing medievel church. Dark and humid but too much history in the air.

Great Lively Place. Great place to go for a meal.
A bit touristy in some areas.

lovely neighborhood. We walked through this area several times on our way to the Seine and museums. The cafe's were a little more touristy (with poorer service) than the cafes near our hotel (near the Jardins du Luxemborg.

A wonderful taste of Paris.... Saint-Germain-des-Pres, with the lively Place Saint-Germain-des-Pres at it's center, was one of my favorite areas of Paris that we visited during our recent trip. It's located in the 6th arrondissement and is surrounded by historic cafes, the beautiful Abbey of Saint-Germain-des-Pres, and an assortment of wonderful shops. The area is anchored by three of Paris' most famous eateries, all withing eyesight of each other: Les Deux Magots, Cafe de Flore, and Brasserie Lipp directly across the street. We had a wonderful meal at Les Deux Magots and spent a lot of time just watching the busy sidewalk and street in front of us.Saint-Germain-des-Pres is a lovely part of Paris with beautiful architecture and great people watching. It's also just a short walk from Saint Sulpice, Luxembourgh Gardens, and more. My only problem with our visit is that we didn't have enough time there. But it's a must-visit when we return.

Unexpected delight. We walked past this church for 5 days and decided to walk inside on our last day in Paris. After visiting Notre Dam, St Chapelle & Sacre Coure, we weren't expecting much when we entered. We were both delighted and surprised at the rustic beauty of this church. It felt more authentic and less "touristy" than the others. Eventhough I am not Catholic, I was deeply moved by the majestic beauty of this church.

in my book the most beautiful part of Paris. I've had a private tour with a guide from City Free Tour and loved it. I'll say the same thing here as I did in a review I've left on their page : this area is so beautiful that you can go with any guide, it will still blow you away. I do however recommend taking either a guide or a local who knows the area because it is a much different experience having someone to point out the most impressive parts that are not often the most obvious.
HAVE EVER EAT THERE?. The place to eat with choices of menus at cheap prizes. The place to feel ambiance française at its best.
charming. nice little community fleamarket on sunday morning close to metro and cafe for lunch
Walk it!. We walked at St Germain des pres and loved it. The little shops and the buzz was awesome. A must do.

Busy, exclusive, unmissable. Since tourism began, visitors have made this part of Paris their destination, for good reason. It has a unique atmosphere, partly due to the Norman church and the famous cafes which surround it, once frequented by... I'm sure you know all that. It's great. Take an early morning walk, visit a zinc bar, imagine what it would be like to be a local!
the Arts live here. hundreds of galleries, print and art atelier, the heart of artistic production

Forever it is the heart of Paris for me. A wonderful neighborhood. The spirit voices of Sartes and Camus arguing philosophy speak less loudly, and it is far more fashionable, but this section of the city of lights remains as charming as ever.

Really buzzy. I always love walking around St Germain. Lovely little shops, old bookshops, great fashion on Rue Saint Sulpice and amazingly buzzy atmosphere on Rue Buci where I ate and drank. Great atmosphere and don't visit Paris without wandering around here to soak up the atmosphere.
The classic walk in Paris. Saint-Germain-des-Pres is the classic Paris of previous generations. It's worth a stroll in the evening.
Not So great. We were a little lost. Maybe we should have taken a guide, or researched the place thoroughly in advance!

A great area to walk around in.. The sidewalks are narrow and can be very crowded. There are plenty of restaurants but be careful they tend to be expensive and are not always the best. Lots of little shops and galleries.
Lovely. A lovely area with lovely people. An optician repaired by glasses for free.

Sartre. This is the literary heart of Paris; as well as the home of Existential philosophy. You will be following the footsteps of THE 20th century legends, Sartre, Hemingway, Joyce, Dali, de Beauvoir. Baker, Picasso - the list is endless. You'll also find da Vinci Code Paris in St Sulpice (if you like that sort of thing). Lovely area, Cafe de Flore, Blvd St Germain, Jardin du Luxembourg close by.
Shop here!!!. Best shopping - with all the shops. Not as crowded.
Wow!. Love this area,if going to Paris stay here (if you can afford it~tres pricey) or at least visit.The true feel of Paris with great restaurants & bars.

Great area...very central. This is a great are of Paris. There are plenty of cafes, shops and there is even a market that pops up just off of Saint-Germain-des-Pres. It's located quite centrally in Paris with easy access to the Seine, Notre Dame and the Louvre

Where the real Parisians are. The Left Bank is known for endless choices of restaurants, from Bistros, Brasseries, and fine dining. Add that the fabulous shopping, museums and the Eiffel Tower, what more can one ask.One large Brasserie is La Coupole which is well known and while many tourists want to visit, more locals area there. Good food, fair prices. A real find was an Italian restaurant, Alfred Positano where we had an incredible lunch. Its a must visit.

No big deal. Awash with tourists, overcrowded and overpriced cafes and upmarket shops that you see everywhere make this area not so appealing. The back lanes were sweet but there are many sweet back lanes in Paris.

Gorgeous place, trendy & Parisian.. We stayed in a hotel close to this neighborhood in February 2012 and had a great time exploring. Charming bistros, famous sites, great shopping and beautiful streets. Do not miss wandering around this neighborhood. Wind your way down to the Montparnasse Cemetery, or spend the day people watching at Cafe de Fleur. Head east along the inner streets at night down to the Latin Quarter for some jazz and festivities.
Glamour!. Love walking this trendy road and then grabbing a spot at a cafe for people watching
a place very ellegant and fashion for everybody. this is for elegants and fashions walks in one of the best places from Paris
Busy area in Paris. This is a great area in Paris with a lot of restaurant, students and places to shop. Have fun.
Oldest church in Paris. Eglise du Saint Germain Des Pres, great history. We attended mass and completed with breakfast at the famous Deux Magots cafe, just in front of the church

Soak up the atmosphere - just don't sit down. Marvellous to wander around the narrow streets and people watch. If you want to have a drink make sure you get there before 9pm - most places have a happy hour which runs up to 8.30 or 9

Vibrant side of Paris. Artists abound at this district which covers the 6th and 7th arrondisement of Paris. Excellently located proximity-wise to the Louvre and the Musee D'orsay. Restaurants and Unique shops fill its perimeters.!
great neighborhood. wall to wall cafes and shopping, great place to walk, sit in the park, sit and sip a glass of wine in a sidewalk cafe. really lovely paris experience

Great balance of activity and civility. We had an apartment on Rue St. Benoit for a week. Tons of restaurants and bars that cater to the family set. An easy walk to St. Michael's and the Latin District if you want to engage in a faster night life. On a great metro line. Close to all the major attractions. What's not to like?
Beautiful area!. Lovely area with all his littl cafes and plenty of designer shops like Burberry and Louis Vuitton

oldest church in Paris. Church was part of a 4th c Abbaye, very little of it to see today. You cannot fail to be impressed by the interior. Sumptuous even by the standards of a Catholic church. Lots of beautiful paintings and chapels and decorated walls. A must see attraction. You are in a fascinating area with a wealth of other attractions. If you like shopping this is also the place for you. Fascinating old area but lots of Paris chic.

Wonderful area to walk around ..... This is a fabulous area to walk around and explore. We're staying in the 7th Arr. but we walk through Saint Germain many days throughout the week. Great neighborhood with plenty of restaurants and cafes.Big variety of food in this area as well. We love it! Definitely worth exploring. There are some smaller neighborhood parks as well which are great if you have kids.

Sartre and Beauvoir sat here. This was bohemian Paris and the jazz festival in the small square was an unexpected find. We sat in the Cafe de Flore and soaked up the atmosphere and enjoying a very reasonably priced lunch of omelette. Service efficient and food excellent. A walk round the streets found us outside the Sciences-Po Faculty of the University. Love the way you pop out at any metro and can be surprised by the architecture of Paris.

Wow ... what a church!. Amazingly, we had not planned to visit this church, but we saw it from a distance and could not resist it. It is truly awesome. Personally, I found it more impressive than the famous Notre Dame.

Worth stopping in. This church is the oldest in Paris, and I'm glad we stopped in. Don't miss the tombstone dated 576 A.D. in a side room. The church is also in an interesting neighborhood. I enjoyed the upscale shops near this church more than the Champs Elysee!

Interesting neighborhood in town. We've been recently in a hotel at this area. It represents everything that's cool in Paris, since people watching cafes, nice boutiques, main fashion stores and proximity with atractions as Sena river, museums and plenty others. Also surrounded by metro stations with connections to everywhere. That's the place to stay or at least spend some time.

Favorite area. We always stay in a small hotel on Blvd. St. Germain which is a great central location. There are so many restaurants walking distance and a very lively atmosphere. If we ever purchase a property in Paris, I would like it to be in this area!

OK, it's another "Must Do". This is a hot area, full of historic bistros like "the Deux Magots" (which is over priced but "de regeur"), the Churches, the sweet narrow cobblestone streets, the extremely friendly people (when I ask directions), the shops, the ambiance, the L'Avant de Comptoir. We are here for 12 days, and will spend more time here.
So much charm. Just a great place to stay, eat and explore. Use Hotel LouisII as your base camp.

Our little taste of life in Paris. We stayed in an apartment on Rue de Seine for 6 nights. We loved St Germaine De Pres. Plenty of restaurants and shops. We love walking so got up plenty of steps to Eiffel Tower, Notre Dame and just loved the whole atmosphere of the friendly locals.

One of my Favorite Areas. I have stayed in this area in the past and have always enjoyed the energy and beauty that I find there. I love the easy access to the Metro and RER, the delicious restaurants, charming shops, and vibrant life found in this area.

Good place to be. This is the main university (La Sorbone) neighborhood. You have a lot of animation and little restaurant open 'till late.
Very nice place to stay, visit or to chill out.

Perhaps Paris's oldest church. There are several churches claiming to be the oldest, but Saint German des Pres is not only built on the site of an abbey from about 550 A.D., it apparently still maintains one or two walls from that abbey. It is a place where you are likely to find evening musical performance that illustrate the amazing acoustics. Its windows are lovely and the soaring Gothic architecture (and the quiet, compared to Notre Dame) is impressive. Part of Descartes is buried there (look for his memorial in the St. Benoit chapel) and the other side chapels also contain much of interest.It is right across the street from the famous Deux Magots. Its flying buttresses can be admired from the pleasant little adjoining park (and shopping nearby is pretty great too). The complexity of the architecture is best viewed both from within and from without. A piece of 13th century sculpture (unfinished) is displayed in one of the side chapels as well (it was found while excavating for a car park). If you're into things Medieval or Gothic, this is a great visit.

A Village Within Paris!. There are several special areas of Paris where I feel like I get to shed the tourist stigma and step into the Parisan, everday chic, unhurried life. I'm sure I idealize things a bit, but thus area fits the ideal. Window shopping yields little shops featuring exactly what you'd imagine to see in Paris in June. The restaurants are plentiful, small, little English spoken and it's hard to find a meal that doesn't make your heart sing or your palate dance. Its the kind of place to leisurely stroll , walking off the last scrumptious meal, or wander with your camera taking artsy shots of colorful doorways, absorbing a very appealing and chic village within Paris.
St Germain area. This is a great area to be based in as you are close to the Seine, the Musee d'Orsay, Notre Dame and Isle St Louis.Nothing to dislike!
Go there even just to people watch:). A lot of good food in this area and just by sitting in a cafe and people watching takes your breath away:)

Perfect for a leisurely stroll. Don't be afraid to lose yourself in the small streets and alleys; it is a very safe area, and you will discover your own magical Paris moment. Since there are so many tourists, there is always people around you and there's always a helping hand to indicate a way back to the boulevards.
Very swish. Lots of interesting shops to look at. Could spend an afternoon browsing.
So much beauty. What a nice place to walk or ride a bicycle, lots of little trails, and easy to access via the subway. it's a must on a beautiful day!

Beautiful area. If you want to get a feel for the beat of the City, spend an afternoon walking around Saint-Germain-des-Pres, exploring the boutiques and book stores, and having a drink on a terrasse.
If you're young and looking or courting, this is heaven. The heart of sidewalk cafes and brasseries and street entertainment. And shopping and shopping, if you're a bit older and wealthier.

Beautiful shopping and attractions!. Walking through the streets of Saint Germain, enter in the Jardin du Luxenbourg, eat in any of its thousand cafes or buy gifts in its trendy shops are awesome. My favorite neighborhood in Paris!
Nice to soak in the atmosphere. Nice shops, restaurants and pubs. Also many smaller streets from St Germain offer great atmosphere.

Chic. Lively and one can find very good bistros, restaurants and bars to relax and enjoy the scene there. There was a jazz band playing and it was a joy to see everyone having a great time without the feeling of being rushed.
Always Charming. I know it's a cliche, but I just love sitting at the Flore or the Deux Magots...
Latin Quarter is fantastic. The whole buzz around this area is fantastic, the food was amazing. One place to visit

Luxembourg Gardens and History!!. Start at Port Royal and walk north through Luxembourg gardens, then walk north on Rue Bonaparte past Saint-Sulpice, make a right on Boulevard Saint Germain, then head north on rue de seine and go over the Pont des Arts. You will Never forget Paris after this BEAUTIFUL walk.
Great place to shop!. Spent a day walking and shopping in is beautiful area! Had a great time! My daughter visited the Longchamps store - needed to buy a pocketbook in Paris! Great time!

Our Favorite Neighborhood. The 6th is our favorite area to stay. Great restaurants & hotels. Lots of shopping. Just across the river from some of the great museums. Excellent Metro access. We are always finding new streets and sights that we missed before.

Great Walking Neighborhood. Our hotel was in this area. We really enjoyed the variety of cafes whether for dinner or a late night drink.
There are many shops. Along St-Germain-des-Pres you will find mostly retail chains, albeit high end chains. But down the side streets are smaller shops with some unique offerings.
Also many galleries around this area.

Beautiful and historical, with amazing food. A must visit!. You can't say you've been to Paris if you haven't been to St Germain. Home to the famous Cafe de Flore, Les Deux Magots (Hemingway's favourite haunt) and Brasserie Lipp, St Germain lives and breathes history. Even if you're not a history buff, St Germain still charms with gorgeous tree-lined streets and delicious food. Not to be missed is Un Dimanche à Paris (a popular pastry/chocolate boutique near Odeon Metro), Pierre Herme on Rue Bonaparte (hint: buy pastries to go and eat them at nearby Place Saint-Sulpice) and, if you're a big oyster fan, Huîtrerie Régis, near the corner of Bd St-Germain and Rue du Four. Near the area to the west is Le Bon Marche, with its huge gourmet food store, La Grande Épicerie de Paris, where you can stock up on Valrhona and the like. From there, some delicious pâtisseries like Hugo & Victor and La Pâtisserie des Rêves are just a short stroll away.To the south is Jardin du Luxembourg, which is a beautiful place to relax, have a picnic and/or people-watch. Do not miss the famous chocolatier Christian Constant, whose shop is just steps away from the west end of the Jardin on 37 Rue Assass.

Great restaurant in Saint Germain. Decided to go to Breakfast in Paris for an late afternoon meal. It was the first time to be in the Saint Germain area and would like to spend more time on the next trip to Paris.

Stay in this Area. My wife and I stayed in this area for the entire week we were in Paris and was the perfect choice. You cant turn a corner without so many food choices and people sitting outside and many shops. At night this place is hopping with outside cafes jammed and music being played and lots of locals so you really feel you are in Paris and not staying on the stuffy champs area or stuffy area by Place Vendome...

Lively and exciting area. It is the center of Paris at its most lively.....The streets are bustling with cafes day and nite. The architecture is super and the story book surroundings describe St. Germain as a hub of activity at its best. People,dogs, flower stalls and boutiques abound. Much fun to be in the center of it all. Nothing to dislike if you want to be where its at!

Great place for a sunny stroll. This is by far one of the nicest neighborhoods in Paris and a great place to get lost in. On our European vacation we wandered around this neighborhood for a half a day and found all sorts of wonderful places, including a fabulous little bakery and a nice little spot to people watch. Definitely make sure to take the time to enjoy Saint Germain des Pres when you make a stop in the City of Lights.

A fabulous street and area!. I loved the myriad of bistros and upscale shopping available on this street area. My husband and I found three of our favorite cafes/brasseries in all of Paris, right along this street.

A wonderful area for an evening stroll. Take time to just walk around the area and have a drink or eat in one of the many restaurants. If you time it right recommend Le Entrecot ,as a place for dinner in a small street around the corner from St Germain church. Exactly one dish on the menu but really excellent, good service, reasonable price, gtreat sauce.
oooh La La!. Nice high end shopping and safe neighborhood, close to everything on the left bank.

"Great area to Browse!". Many; shops, cafes and restaurants. I found it interesting to people watch. We walked thru the area after dinner. It as wonderful little boutiques, as well as artisan areas. Many artists were out painting buildings in the area. The streets are narrow and the architecture is wonderful to view. Worth the time for a stroll!!!
Just wander around and enjoy. There's a little something for everyone in the shops and cafes here. There was a Sunday outdoor antique market in front of St. Suplice.
vibrant!. very vibrant area of Paris, great restaurants, cafes, all very Parisian but not cheap!
LOOOVED it!. We stayed, ate, drank, shopped and walked this area. I would do it all over again the same way. We couldn't have been happier in this part of town.
Essential left-bank Paris. My favorite street on the left bank to sit in a cafe and watch the world walk by.

exelent. something the best!
lot of nice restoraunts, good shopinh area, lot of caffe
have a coffee. Worth strolling down on a nice day; stop for coffee or an apero at Les Deux Magots.
one should not miss it!. liked the history, the narrow streets, the ambiance in general
Very Special. This was right behind Notre Dame. We stopped in on a Saturday and there was a service going on. Beautiful. Make a stop here, even for 5 minutes you can't go wrong.

Highly recommend. Parisien area without the American chains. Everything one could want while visiting Paris. Close to the Louvre, Musee D'Orsay. Nice restaurants, local vibe for cafe's wine and people watching
Safe, Beautiful, calm. Staying in SGdP is a wonderful location for exploring Paris.

So Much To See...So Little Time!. You really need to do your homework here as you could easily spend days seeing the many varied sites in this district. The restaurants are varied, the literary s"spots" are many, the fashion stores are by the hundreds.....then there are the history/church sites to see. But whatever you decide on, this is a marvellous section of the city.

As Paris should be. We liked the restaurants/bars and locals we mixed with. The small, narrow streets and multiple Metro stations made it a joy to explore.
Dislikes would have to be the idiots on mopeds who appear to be oblivious to anyone and anything around them
A Dream. It really is like a dream to walk down the streets of Saint-Germain-des-Pres. I recommend staying in this area, or at least spending a day in the area

Chocolate, Chocolate, Chocolate. When in St. Germain De Pres neighborhood, do NOT miss Un Dimanche a Paris and Piere Herme. They both have amazing chocolates, with Un Dimanche a winner in the overall ambience award and Piere Herme the current winner in the macaron chocolate category--but still tasting them all over to keep the competition going.

The heart of a real neighborhood. Stayed for 6 weeks a block away and it became our main artery to getting everywhere. Lots of tourists, but lots of locals too. It is a fast way to get around because all the streets that are perpendicular are very narrow and crowded. Take time to look in all the boutique windows. great Monoprix (grocery store) on Rue de Rennes near St Germain. On Saturday night go to the church (St Germain) for gorgeus organ music.

Great location. Rented an apartment for 9 nights near St. Germain Church. 1/2 or less miles to the Lourve, Notre Dame, Luxembourg Gardens, St. Sulpice, D'Orsay, Tuilleries. Only slightly further to the Pantheon, Grand/Petit Palais, Orangerie. Great location.
A lovely area of the city to visit. We always make time to visit this area when we are in Paris so many lovely cafe's and restaurants and lots of interesting places to see.

Saint-Germain-des-Pres is chic and affordable. Compared to other parts of Paris, Saint-Germain-des-Pres is truly uniquely Parisian. Free of most of the crush of tourists and souvenir shops, SGdP allows you to explore Paris at your leisure. Spend a day walking around or stay in one of the many hotels. (The Hotel du Dragon on Rue de Dragon is a friendly little hotel I loved). The main streets are alive with cafés and restaurants and bars. The shops are plentiful and run the gamut from high-end designer to very affordable. Easy walking distance to many attractions. My favorite day was my walk to and visit to the Musée Rodin. Great neighborhood worth a visit.

Silver Travelers. A charming, lively, bustling area. Cafes, boutiques, street carts with delicious looking fruits and vegetables, music, and more. Close to the river Seine where you can take a boat ride on the Bateau Mouche on which lunch or dinner is served, or on the Bateau Boat which one can get off at any stopvisit the area and catch the next one to continue the ride.
LIFE OF PARIS. A lively part of Paris--tons of young people, great shops, bistros and life
Great area and church. Many bars and restaurants. Small alleys and shops. The church is one of the best
Favorite Paris Neighborhood. My husband and I really enjoyed walking through this neighborhood and stopping at the shops and cafes.

Explore Paris one neighborhood at a time, and start with this one.. After several visits to Paris and much exploration of many - not all - parts of the city, I have come to the conclusion Saint Germaine-des-Pres is where I would live if I were lucky enough to live in Paris. It's stylish, intellectual, artsy and yet, like other parts of Paris, it offers the feel of a village, not a huge city. I think it was Colette who described Paris as a collection of villages. That is how one should think of it, and set out to explore one village or neighborhood at a time. In Saint Germain-des-Pres, you will find history, cobblestones, galleries, shops, legendary cafes and charm. It's a bit more upscale than the adjacent Latin Quarter (also a wonderful neighborhood), but not as commercial-feeling as the Right Bank. The pace is a bit slower than the Latin Quarter, in my opinion, and the feel is a bit less touristy.

So nice to walk around!. Stroll the streets of Saint Germain to see the little stores, boutiques, book stores, delis, etc! It is ideal - beware, Sunday everything is closed, and many are closed on Mondays too.Have a coffee at Les Deux Magots - the staff can be REALLY rude, but the place (and its history) make you travel back in time, plus you get to see all the sic Parisians go by!

Fun neighborhood. Lots to do, even VO ("voix original", or English w/ Fr subtitles instead of overdubbing) movies. Lots of little cafes, shops, clubs. More young people than middle aged or older, so much so that on Friday eves you can barely get a spot to walk on the sidewalk, the kids are standing there so you have to walk out into the streets. Some areas are a little tacky and some are really nice, changes from block to block. Further from the Latin Quarter are some classy shopping areas. Quite a few nicer restaurants, also, and of course Jardin du Luxembourg!
love this neighborhood. This neighborhood is filled with lovely shops, cafes, and cobblestone streets.
Fun area. We stayed in this area and felt we were IN Paris...the tiny streets, the little shops, the smells, the people...all made this such fun. The food...YUM !
explore off the main streets. travel some of the side streets to see the studio where Picasso painted and some of the important places in the history of Paris.
Walk. Great for shopping and the Cluny Museum. Good dining Cafe Flore or Les Deux maggots

Lovely neighborhood.. It's not the Marais or Montmartre, but if you're looking for those kinds of places, then, well, go there. Saint-Germain is the essence of true French living: sophisticated, somewhat reserved, posh and refined.
I love this little district.. Great crepe place called cite and loved to go to luxembourg gardens. Disliked prices in some places.

Pretty but pricey...avoid Bizuth Bar. We went for a wander round this area one afternoon and stopped for a cocktail and a pint of Hoegaarden which came out at €18..the waiter was more bothered about clearing tables than serving us and spilt a lot of my drink on me when it finally came! This was all at Bizuth Bar so give that a miss but the rest of it is nice :)
Biking is the best way to see it!. We rode our Velib bikes down Saint-Germain, in a bike/bus only lane, and it was magical. One of the best memories I have of my European Vacation!

Lovely little cafes. Try Cafe de Flor if you want to check out how Parisians spend their afternoon and Le Relais de l'Entrecote for one the best entrecote, fries and salad (set menu) and Frenchie ambiance

Great area for exploring. Saint Germain des Pres is an interesting area with lots of shops - both eclectic and designer shops, monuments, history and gardens. The boulevard is packed with big names such as Sonia Rykiel, Burberry and Emporio Armani, and the famous cafes such as Les Deux Magots and Lipp are all to be found here as well. There are small, narrow streets as well that are not as trafficked as the Boulevard.It's a great area to stroll around, shop, eat and watch the Paris life unfold. I think it would be a great place to stay as well as there is so much to see and do.
Run down aristocracy. I think Saint Germain des Pres has lost its glitter as Paris' finest district, if it ever were. In any case, I cannot recall the nostalgic splendor on this visit.

paris like in the movies. Location is within walking distance to everything or a metro ride away. It's looks like Paris in the movies with quaint streets and cafes. The literary and political history is all around you.
Good place to stay. Wonderful location, safe and scenic. Lots of markets, pastry shops, etc. and Bon Marche thrown in. I think this is the best area in Paris.

Middle Ages Gothic at the core. I dearly recomend SG de Press for Middle Ages lovers. This abacial church is from XI century and has a different kind of gothic than Notre Dame, Saint Severin and S Denis. It is darker, with less glass. Go visit, it is hard to describe. And in the avenue at its left there is a street fair also.

ah paris!. I love this area! full of parisian attitude and chic!
sat in la boneparte cafe for a coffee and watched the world go by: lunch at les editeurs up the road, the afternoon tea at laduree!
dont forget to wander down to la grande epicerie for a look at food heaven
Worth it. Lots of interesting side streets, little shops and wonderful cafes.
Excellent atmosphere & restaraunts. Had lots of energy & we are amazing food in the area.

The posh part of Paris = clean, safe and close to all the good stuff.. My favorite part of Paris for its conveniance to all the major sights, walk to the Louvre, eat a baguette on the Seine or walk to the Champe élysées for people watching and shopping. Wouldn't stay anywhere else.

Love this area of the left bank. We walked this area many times on our way to other sites in Paris. It's a wonderful eclectic area of Paris that allows you to window shop and stroll the streets or to do some serious shopping. Several good restaurants for lunch. Loved Le Rhumerie on Rue St. Germain.
Must Do. I highly reccommend a Paris Walks tour through this area!
Sublime Sunday afternoon. As the oldest church in Paris, this is well worth a visit. The interior is beautiful and there is a Picasso monument to Gillaume Appolinaire in the garden
Wonderful shopping area.. This is a great shopping area. There are a lot of shops, that are not so high end as to be unaffordable.
A LOVELY AREA. A great are of the city with lots of art galleries and cafes.
Great Neighborhood. Antiques, cafes, clothing, tourists shops and much more.
Street musicians, jugglers, pain du chocolate, onion soup. Also, Laudree macaroons, Pierre Herme chocolates. Fantastic to walk, sit and watch the people.
good area but just like other similar places in Paris. good area but just like other similar places in Paris

Very pretty and artistic area in Paris. We came across this area, after visiting the Louvre, as it is across the river. The streets are full of small shops, many quaint bistros, art galleries, etc,...The buildings are very charming and there are many stores where you can find unusual home furnishings. I wish I would've spent more time in this area, rather than in Le Marais.
great area of paris. The shops, restaurants and bakeries all just outside your door.
Great neighborhood. Lots of places to eat, plenty of shops, felt very safe, and not too "touristy"
Fun. Great for shops and many restaurants - not so "touristy" though there are so many in Paris of course its hard to tell

Another religious place. Good finding for us during our trip, but why it is so important to us, as foreigners to learn about the costs of it's restoration from big pannels everywhere inside the church?
chrisp. Villagey feel with narrow streets, but oh stylish and sophisticated. The art and book shop and fashion outlets leave you drooling.
Go out and drink some wine!. Fun, full of life place at night. A bit expensive though.
Charming restaurants and gorgeous galleries. We were there on a Sunday at midday, and it's very busy, vibey, fun. Galleries were closed, but restaurants were buzzing.

Feel like a real Parisene. This is a great area to spend a few hours or a whole day wandering around! Up and down lovley shop lined alley ways. The chocolate shops, the pastries, the shopping! Just lovely. Wander to the Seine, Notre Dam, Boul Mich. Not as chaotic as Montmatre, much less tiring.

Favorite Neighborhood. You will really like this charming neighborhood - nice shops and restaurants and close to the other trendy neighborhoods that are also loaded with so much history as you walk along the streets.
My favorite neighborhood in Paris!. Hands down, my favorite neighborhood in Paris. The cafes are a wonderful and the shops are great.

This is the place.. You need to try to remember where and when it was that you fell in love with Paris. For me, it was ducking under the awning of a nondescript brasserie on the Bd St Germain to avoid the rain on a cold April day, and being ushered to a tiny little table for two by the smiling waiter, where I ended up having the best steak of my life. Sipping my second glass of wine, I remember looking outside at all the beautifully stylish French women defying the weather in their skirts and high heels, and thinking that this place must surely be the centre of the civilized world. I could have spent my entire vacation in Saint Germain, and maybe next time I will.

6th Arondesment is the best. If possible stay in St. Germain des Pres or at least have a drink or a meal in the area. Not as pretentious, tacky or shabby as some areas of Paris. Lots of good places to eat in all price ranges

Love it. This is a great area to stroll around in - there are lots of small side streets filled with wonderful small boutiques - great for window shopping. Also the Church St Germain des Pres is the oldest church in Paris, dating to the 11th century and quite interesting, although badly in need of restoration
Always a pleasure to walk the area. But the area in the Marais area, where we are staying this time has better boutiques, small businesses and more reasonable cafes.
fantastic church and view. a excellent place where you have a beautiful church and too a fantastic view of paris .obs -take care with the pick pockets in the stairs and around .
Shopa for all needs and a couple of typical cafes.. Wanted to spend much more than a few hours...just visiting the pharmacies and small cafes was nothing like I had seen or imagined.
Interesting architecture. Great variety of unusual shops in every alley and street.

Nice quartier!!!. Its a nice place to walk around, good restaurants and nice stores!!
Must go!
Great area to stay or visit. very safe and clean area to visit. Great cafes and shops. Transport very handy too.
just walk. This IS Paris, just walk around at your liesure. History and shops, everybodys happy!
Loved walking. I just loved this area! You can walk and walk! The stores and pastry shops are amazing! There is no better pastry than in Paris!!

Very French experience!. We spent several days in an apartment on Rue Cherche Midi, just doors away from Poilane. It was a wonderful experience, so much nicer than the high end hotels which we had stayed in on the other side of the Seine.If shopping is your thing, then there are plenty of high end stores. We enjoyed the location, restaurants, being close to 2 metro stops that got us all over the city. There is such a vibrancy & so much history to this neighborhood. I would definitely stay in St.Germain des Pres whenever I visit Paris. Nothing is far in any European city if you can figure out the transportation system & Paris has one of the best.
Lovely. Lovely area -- a bit too far out for us to think about staying until we tire of the Marais area I think.

Chocolate heaven. Take a chocolate and pastry tour to find the best spots, then come back again and again. Try to walk here, you'll need the exercise. Don't miss the Hermes store in the converted swimming pool. Walking down St. Germain the shops are incredible, especially the home furnishing stores and childrens' clothing shops. If you need a fairy princess costume for a grandchild,this is the place.
Great Area. Our hotel was in this area and there are lots of shops, restaurants and museums.
Great walking and eating neighborhood. 15 minutes and we spent a fair amount of time there. Don't miss Laduree for tea.
Interesting. Interesting arrondisement in Paris. Feel like a parisien walking through its streets.

This is where we always want to stay in Paris. We love this neighborhood b/c feels like the real Paris with local Parisians, students, and fewer tourists. Terrific attractions (St Sulpice, Parc Luxembourg, many restaurants) and yet still walking distance to major art museums and the Seine.
Beautiful. My favourite part of Paris. A lovely cobbly square with lots of restaurants and brasseries to visit, very romantic
Stay here if you can. Plenty to do without being overwhelmed, by far the best area of Paris
this area has everything. Wonderful shopping, historical cafes, great restaurants and people watching at its best
Absolutely the best neighborhood. Fantastic boutiques, restaurants, architecture...Spent a day just strolling thru this area. So much to see!!
St Germain. lots of lovely cafes and restaurants including our favourite, Allard - try the duck with olives!

One of my favourite quartiers!. Between the Seine and Boulevard St Germain here are gorgeous little streets with fine bistros and privately owned shops: art shops, cake shops, antique shops, bistros. An interesting area to stroll around. Start at the little wooden Pont des Beaux Arts and mosey around, be flexible, follow your nose and enjoy!

Our favourite part of Paris. Lots happening here and a really fun atmosphere. Lots of food outlets and interesting shops. Great buskers, jugglers etc, we wished we had longer in the city to get there for an evening as well as the two lunchtimes we spent in the area.
Cool Neighborhood. Realy Cool neighborhood to go aroud and to go out at night. Really trendy and surprisingly traditional.
Get Lost Here!. We constantly were lost on the Left Bank...but who cares with all the sites and cafes???

Too dark. I was thrilled to visit this church on my most recent trip to Paris. Unfortunately, it was a cloudy day and the church doesn't have many lights so it was too dark to see much. Still, I'm glad I finally got to see it and will go back again on a sunnier day.

my favorite neighborhood. Best neighborhood in Paris! Famous cafe's, awesome shops and cute boutique hotels to stay in. I like that is close to the seine, and each street you walk down is different, very much an area of paris where actual residents live.

By far our favorite neighborhood in Paris. This area, known for the history of artists, writers, and great thinkers, is rich and full of life. A very different vibe than the "downtown" Paris. Safe and full of great little shops, cafes, bookstores, and side streets - so much fun to see what's around the corner. We ate lunch at the famous Cafe de Flore, and enjoyed great food and people-watching. We did see the Cafe Procope, but it was closed at the time - the menu looked very appealing and it's the fist cafe in the world. You do best in this neighborhood by just wandering around - there is so much to see here!

A great place to wander around. We spent a fun morning wandering around the shops and markets in this quintissential Parisian suburb. I particularly loved the building architecture, and we had lunch in a small cafe overlooking the street from the 1st floor.
Lovely. Had a great lunch at fancy Joel Robouchon restaurant, drinks at Les Deux Magots, and walked around. It was a nice day.

Spent most my time here. My hotel was here, and I spent most my time in Paris in this area. Can't review any of the cafes because we would just choose one without checking the name. Convenient to the metro. Central to many sights. Beautiful area to walk. Truly what I expected Paris to be. I was traveling alone and felt safe in this area.
Best Area in Town. We didn't go into the Church but we visited the area and LOVED it! I think we'll stay around here next time. Some great restaurants and bars and a lovely vibe
A beautiful medieval cathedral. Set in a lovely square, the cathedral grounds are a nice place to sit a bit. The cathedral itself is lovely iside.
A good location to find a good place to eat. There are many places to see and enjoy but since the Frence know about food the selection in this area and prices is good

History, shopping, charm and style - it's all here!. I fell in love with Saint-Germain-des-Pres when I stayed here on Rue Jacob for a couple of nights for a work trip. I only had one afternoon and one evening to spare for sight-seeing/ shopping, and this was just the perfect location for both. The cobbled streets, boutique stores and amazing cafes are simply wonderful. Go out for an early morning stroll to Notre Dame and see the morning light by the river banks. Watch the boulangeries open up, get yourself some croissants fresh out of the oven and have amazing coffee at Cafe de Flore. For shopping, Boulevard Saint-Germain, Rue du Dragon, Rue de Buci and Rue Saint-André des Arts are just a few of the many great places in the area.

Super fun and vibrant place.. Great shopping and restaurants. And the shops are not the standard same shops we can get in America. Nothing is worse than flying halfway across the country to then be presented with the SAME shops in Paris.

Where the rich people hide. Beside Île Saint-Louis and 16eme arrondissement, this place has a very high money for square meter density. Wonderful stores, charming cafes and the usual Paris bistros. The perfect place to spending your time walking around shopping or just trying to get lost in Paris.

The whole neighborhood. The many small, narrow streets, old buildings leaning into. The cafés, the sidewalk restaurants, the cheerful bars and hot clubs at night. The myriad of shops: clothes, shoes, books, anything. The breakfast places: flute, café noir and croissant. The people. The atmos. The whole neighborhood. Here the journey becomes the adventure. Here you'll soak in Paris.It's a matter of taste, of course, but I prefer this to the Haussmannian grand avenues and polished shopping arcades. (This review refers to the whole area of Saint-Germain-des-Prés!)

Love this neighborhood!. This fun neighborhood is always active, safe and awesome! Lots of young people about. A real mix of students, locals and tourists. Great restaurants, movie theaters and even a large Starbucks if you need a fix.

Great way to spend a day. Walked along the Rue St. Michel to the Luxembourg Gardens, then onto St Sulpice. Crossed to the Rue St.Germain des Pres and window shopped, finally caught a bus to the Tour Montparnassee, terrific views of Paris from the top

True Parisian Shopping. You know you're in Paris when you walk down Saint-Germain-des-Pres. It was at the end of what was already an entire day of walking for us, we literally walked Paris that day, and after about 4 hours of walking back to our hotel, we found this road, and I really felt like I was shopping in Paris. Tired we were, but walk we did. I can't say people "have to go see this hood" unless you staying in the Latin Quarter and it's easy to get there, then yes, go take a leisurely stroll down SGdP.
Woody Allen's Paris. If you saw Midnight in Paris film, you will like this area. It does not disappoint first time visitors looking for "Frenchiness".
FEELING HISTORY. A wonderful place to be, especially during Holy Week.
awesome neighborhood. great shopping, quaint streets to get lost in and have a cafe
Love it!!. Great place. Lots of little cafes, restaurants and bars. What you imagined Paris to be.

Fave area. Loved this area of Paris. Pretty little streets with amazing art galleries and antique shops. Great shopping. Several brasseries etc. Go to Laduree on Rue Bonaparte and have pastries + tea in their tea salon. Lovely

Mozart, in a quiet place.. We entered Saint Germaine for a look and a rest from a long walk, and heard Mozarts requiem being practiced. Wow it does not get better than this. Loved the building and the acoustics.
Small church. Saint-Germain-des-Pres is worth a quick look inside while in the neighborhood.
The best neighborhood to stay in..and hangout. We were the envy of our friends staying here. Food, shops, metros, history..and lots of chocolate..
Exciting & beautiful at every turn.. My favorite part of Paris. The art, the food, and beauty surrounds you. You can spend days in the area and still find new places and things to do.
shhhhhh, leave everyone else to the Champs. while you stroll the new elegance of St Germaine, its many cafes and shops.
Interesting and expensive shops. Fun to roam throughout the 6th. Lots of nice cafes, brasseries & bistros - don't miss the pharmacies as many stock speciality cosmetics and hair accessories.
Great shopping and food. Brilliant area full of eclectic shops and name brands. So many eateries you really are overwhelmed by choice. Worth doing some research to find the true Gems like Le comptoir
Great Neighborhood. You have to take a stroll through there. We went to enjoy some great cafe's there

Stayed in the Neighbourhood. I will stay in the same neighbourhood next time I go. It was great to walk around and go into all the shops, restaurants, cafes, everyone was so chic and stylish, and it was also very safe, the kids (17, 14, and 13) felt very safe walking around and going into the cafes on their own.

Nostalgia. For those who like to go back in time....don't miss the Rue Mouffetard, the Pantheon and a tip: there are some very nice terraces on a small square below the Pantheon, where the Rue Descartes meets the Rue de la Montagne.
Must walk around this area!. Great restaurants, shops, boulangerie, patasierie! So many things to see and experience here. People watching is outstanding too.

BEST PART OF PARIS!. By far the most chic arr in Paris... Stunning streets, classy people, amazing cafes (Cafe De Flore!!!!!), gorgeous little unique boutiques. I felt safe and happy in St Germain.. wish I had stayed there instead.

Always in fashion. My second visit to Le Flour and its neighbouring bookstore (my favorite thing on trip is to visit their local bookstores). Enjoyed being philosophized. Walkig around there is just fun as sitting out and watching people around.
Beautiful Old Church. My favorite churches around Paris aren't the tourist sights...this one was nearly empty when we visited, and beautiful to walk around and feel the history.
Our favorite little neighborhood to explore. Found a little treasure around each corner. Quaint, cobblestone streets, great little cafe's, fun place to explore Paris.

Go down the side streets. The area of St G des Pres is festooned with little side streets, cafes, restaurants, small shops - get off the main streets and explore those hidden gems like place Furstenberg a gem of a square, rue Jacob with its elegant small hotels etc.

Fabulous place to stay, shop and eat. St. Germaine is a fantastic area to stay in and visit, even in the winter time. We ate outside a number of times on heated patios. Fantastic shopping all of the big brand name stores and lots of great surprises in little shops, too.
Great part of Paris. Great restaurants, sweet shops and cafes. We went to Laduree and Léon de Bruxelles, where we got some of the best service ever. www.leon-de-bruxelles.fr
Interesting area to stroll around and people watch. Big choice of bars and restaurants - good value happy hours. Buzzing and lively.

Les Deux Magot or Cafe de Flore. From the Saint-Germain-des-Pres Metro Station you are greeted on the Boulevard Saint Germain first by Les Deux Magots then the Cafe de Flore. Both are iconic eateries but with no preferred tables at the first, I found the second and had a very good, though, I thought, pricey, lunch. Oh, the Caesar salad was superb and the white cheese + red fruit coulis sublime but the wine was, I thought, overpriced. Perhaps a turist trap on it's hostory but very popular with locals?? Whatever, I enjoyed it.
True Parisian ambience.. Loved the architecture, shops, restaurants in this area. Visited the traditional haunt Les Deux Magots!

Left Bank area...and hotel. Upon my return to Paris we stayed in Saint-Germain-des-Pres area. Wonderful streets, restaurants and lovely boutiques. I will review our hotel and restaurants on their sites.

Nice area to stay in. We stayed in Saint Germain while in Paris. It was quiet, yet let you see another side of Paris. There were plenty of places to eat, though many weren't open late. We would definitely stay in this area again.
Better than champs area. Real neighbourhoods, and great places to explore off the street
Great Neighborhood. We traveled all through Paris by foot, metro and vespa and this is definitely one of my favorite areas. Great place to visit and stay.
The best area to stay. I love this area of Paris and would recommend staying here. It is always very lively.
Beautiful arrondissement. We walked around Saint Germain des Pres and had a nice lunch in a small restaurant
Wonderful walking experience. One of the most beautiful sections in the most beautiful city in the world. Fabulous cafes and restaurants. One of the best places to people watch.
lovely. This church didn't seem to get much tourist traffic, unlike the large ones, but it is beautiful. They are doing some restoration on the interior.

borderline tacky. Well,
I'm not saying it's a letdown but it sort of is, the pubs are mostly tourist traps, and the souvernir shops sell some of the most tacky stuff you can see, I mean it's ok, but not mind blowing
the best neighborhood. this is such a central location, it is clean and vibrant with activity
Worth the visit, but very "dark"!. In a gothic style, therefore, very dark. Old and well preserved, it´s a nice visit. Surrounds are very nice too, since the quarter is worth a stroll.

Lovely area for walking and both window and real shopping. I love walking around this area. You can window shop to your heart's content and feel comfortable stepping in and out of the shops. I try to find a cafe on one of the side streets when I need to stop for a coffee. I usually visit the Monoprix department store and find a variety of reasonably priced clothes that I have to buy.
Expensive. Steer clear, this is the most expensive of all the areas of Paris.

This is paris. Saint Germain is the heartbeat of Paris. It has it all. Great location as is close to many major sites. The energy and vibe you feel here is what you dreamed Paris would be and it does not dissappoint. It is buzzing with people and food and bookshops and cafes and history. However it is not pretentious just very casually cool!

One of the best spots in Paris. Saint-Germain can be overlooked if you are not staying on the left bank, so take the time to venture along the streets filled with character, history, restaurants and shops. Eating in St Germain is really easy as there are lots of restaurants, but I would suggest booking one in advance as the better restaurants book out quickly.
The Spirits of the Artists. I got tingles down my spine as I walked around the same area as Simone de Beauvoir and Jean Paul Sartre, etc.

Great old atmosphere inside. A lot of churches in Paris have been restored by the government. This one has not been so it's one of my favorites. It's hard to tell which if any of the abbey church are leftover from the 6th century when it was built. I like this church also because all of the walls are bit dusty but they were painted in patterns popular in the medieval time period. Also I recently saw a a group of singers called 'Gospel Dream' perform there and the acoustics are good because the church is medium sized.
forget the map just explore!. pretty little cobbled streets, lined with cafes and restaurants - stop for a crepe and watch the world go by !

Couldn't see much. It was being renovated when we were there, so we didn't see much, but the cafe's adjacent to it are famous, so even if you don't see much, you can still get a mean Croque Madame at the Cafe Deux Magots.
Love this charming street.. Enjoyed walking on this street which you can find beautiful stores and cafes. I had diner at Cafe du Flore and wonderful food and service.

This is Paris. Away from the Eiffel Tour, the Champs Elysees, and the crowds of tourists, Saint-Germain-des-Pres has the feel of Paris. Parisian cafes are everywhere. Bistros, restaurants, galleries, give you the feel of real Paris. La Sorbonne, Luxembourg gardens, Latin Quarter, it is all amazing. A must.

Left bank art shops, cafes, shopping, restaurants. I really enjoyed my latest visit. Although I'd been to Paris many times, I always discover something new. This time, my secret find (well it was a secret to me) was all of the affordable art galleries in and around rue de Seine. Great way to spend an afternoon!
Go the the restaurants. Yes touristy but cafe flore and the other 2 in the triangle are great. Just order coffee at one. Wine at other and maybe a soup at third. Great people watching spots
Relaxing. Nice area and very relaxing area. Nice parks and teh architecture is gorgeous.

Away from most tourists but close to the center.. Hardly a bohemian neighborhood that it used to be. Cafe de Fiore and Les Deux Magots are still here, more like a people watching venue than anything else. High end shopping minus the crowds. Noticeably lively from Rue St Benoit all the way to the Latin Quartier. Great area to base a Paris visit. Less touristy. Central and walking distance most major attractions including the Louvre, Musee d'Orsay, Jardin Luxembourg, Pantheon, Musee Delacroix, Eglise St Sulpice, Seine River, Notre Dame, Des Invalides, Pont Neuf, etc.
Shopping. Great shopping! A very pretty street with lots of other buildings to just see.

Too much post WW II architecture. As if Hussman hadn't done enough architectural "damage" to this supposedly swank neighborhood, we had a unit that was a war remodel...lots of glass and glam. And the neighborhood had no "personality". Not the historical European experience we had come to enjoy in prior trips to Paris, in the Pyrennees, in Spain. Having said that, a very safe neighborhood and close to Luxembourg Gardens and easy access to transportation to Versailles.

SGdP. On a saturday morning,being in SGdP is a pleasant expirience,enter a bistrot get an apperitive,go for a stroll, and find a nice restaurant to lunch, finish with a walk into the Jardin de luxembourg or visit musee Rodin with a perfect isolated garden, and yet again finish your day with a coffee in another bistro. Bonne appetit.......
Peace in the city!. This is a wonderful place to find quiet in the bustle of the St Germain district. The history and ages of worship just ooze out serenely

Great shops and souvenirs. I bought most of my souvenirs from Paris in this area - it's just very pretty and has a great vibe to it...BUT expensive to eat around here so don't come on an empty stomach! :)

Beautiful suburb in Paris. We recently stayed in Saint German and very much recommend the area. You have a real fell for the "posh" side of Paris with the large streets and boulevards. Very central and in the middle of various historic site - its a very pleasant location.Just careful when choosing an hotel in the area as it is a very locally populated area a and in week days as the communal day starts it can get quite noise quite early.

If you have some free time, worth a look. If you have some time to spare, then wander around the cafes and shops and streets and take in the atmosphere. Not as it used to be, but still plenty to see and very pretty area.
Well worth it. Be sure to include this if you are in the area. No need to go out of your way, but worth a drop in.

Has to be seen ; yet decay and tourism !. It used to be a marvelous place to live or stay during the day, until the 80's; now just shops for tourists instead of book-sellers. Tourists instead of "intellectuals"; junk food or tenth of greek restaurants.Of course, you can see the Deux Magots and the Flore where famous writers used to go ; now chinese tourism and people who put their feet on the chairs ! Visit the Church : great ! Rue St André des Arts, still typical and paved. Go quickly somewhere else !
Such a great area. Great area to walk around and get lost. So many cute shops, restaurants, cafes

walk down some of the most iconic streets in Paris. I go to Saint-Germain-des-Pres for several reasons. I stayed here the first time I came to Paris and so many wonderful memories are tied up here. I also like visiting the tiny Delacroix Museum and sitting in the perfect courtyard garden. Then I visit Flamant the fabulous home wears store close by the museum. Mainly I come here to go to the many well known restaurants that are scattered around. These alone offer a variety of different moods and experiences. I can not imagine coming to Paris and not visiting Saint-Germain-des-Pres

Seeking the Golden Years.
